partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"http://www.theinvestigativefund.org/","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"137149,137227,69755,117499,107115,101874","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/07/16/financial-advisers-want-to-rip-off-small-investors-trump-wants-to-help-them-do-it/","https://theintercept.com/2017/07/15/trumps-team-overseeing-wall-street-brings-in-more-goldman-sachs-alumni-docs-reveal/","https://theintercept.com/2016/06/23/confessions-of-a-payday-lender-i-felt-like-a-modern-day-gangster/","https://theintercept.com/2017/03/15/donald-trump-isnt-even-pretending-to-oppose-goldman-sachs-anymore/","https://theintercept.com/2017/01/20/donald-trump-preaches-angry-nationalism-while-practicing-goldman-sachs-capitalism/","https://theintercept.com/2016/12/09/trump-makes-america-goldmans-again-maga/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Trump's economic adviser Gary Cohn is giving Goldman Sachs everything it ever wanted","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"goldman-sachs-gary-cohn-donald-trump-administration","thumbnail":{"ID":146603,"alt_text":"","content":"","credit":"Photo: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images","excerpt":"","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"720","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214.jpg","width":"1440"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Moneyman-cohn-goldman-3-1505494214"},"title":"Gary Cohn Is Giving Goldman Sachs Everything It Ever Wanted From the Trump Administration","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/17/goldman-sachs-gary-cohn-donald-trump-administration/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"At Goldman Sachs, Gary Cohn nearly wrecked the economy. As Trump's top economic adviser, he's dismantling the rules put in place after the financial crisis.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"How Goldman Sachs Took Over the U.S. Economy","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"146827":{"ID":146827,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":7,"brief_bio":"Glenn Greenwald is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Glenn Greenwald","email":"glenn.greenwald@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/glenn.greenwald.5","full_bio":"\u003cp>Glenn Greenwald is one of three co-founding editors of The Intercept. He is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law. His most recent book, \u003cem>No Place to Hide\u003c/em>, is about the U.S. surveillance state and his experiences reporting on the Snowden documents around the world. Prior to co-founding The Intercept, Glenn&#8217;s column was featured at \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> and \u003cem>Salon\u003c/em>. He was the debut winner, along with Amy Goodman, of the Park Center I.F. Stone Award for Independent Journalism in 2008, and also received the 2010 Online Journalism Award for his investigative work on the abusive detention conditions of Chelsea Manning. For his 2013 NSA reporting, he received the George Polk award for National Security Reporting; the Gannett Foundation award for investigative journalism and the Gannett Foundation watchdog journalism award; the Esso Premio for Excellence in Investigative Reporting in Brazil (he was the first non-Brazilian to win), and the Electronic Frontier Foundation&#8217;s Pioneer Award. Along with Laura Poitras, \u003cem>Foreign Policy\u003c/em> magazine named him one of the top 100 Global Thinkers for 2013. The NSA reporting he led for \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> was awarded the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for public service.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/02/Glenn-Greenwald-Original_350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"glenn-greenwald","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/GlennGreenwaldPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"734A 3680 A438 DD45 AF6F  5B99 A4A9 28C7 69CD 6E44","pgp_key":"Glenn Greenwald Public Key","twitter":"@ggreenwald","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/glenn-greenwald/","user_group":"founding-editor","user_title":"Co-founding Editor and Columnist"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2wAuWeq","categories":[{"name":"Donald Trump","slug":"donald-trump"},{"name":"Glenn Greenwald","slug":"greenwald"},{"name":"Media critique","slug":"media-critique"},{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"332","comments_open":false,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>Sean Spicer&#8217;s\u003c/u> \u003ca href=\"http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/emmys-sean-spicer-makes-surprise-appearance-riff-trump-crowd-size-presser-1040224\">playful, glamorous appearance\u003c/a> at last night&#8217;s Emmy Awards and being honored as a visiting fellow at Harvard&#8217;s Kennedy School (the honorific which the CIA vetoed for Chelsea Manning) has prompted a mix of shock and indignation. Former Obama speechwriter Jon Favreau \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jonfavs/status/909576992315424769\">wrote\u003c/a>: &#8220;Harvard fellowships, Emmy appearances, huge speaking fees: there&#8217;s just gonna be no penalty for working in Trump&#8217;s White House, huh?&#8221; Slate&#8217;s Jamelle Bouie \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jbouie/status/909575973481394177\">added\u003c/a>: &#8220;The degree to which Sean Spicer has faced no consequences is a glimpse into the post-Trump future.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>There should be nothing whatsoever surprising about any of this, as it is the logical and necessary outcome of the self-serving template of immunity which D.C. elites have erected for themselves. The Bush administration was filled with high-level officials who did not just lie from podiums, but did so in service of actual war crimes. They invaded and destroyed a country of 26 million people based on blatant falsehoods and relentless propaganda. They instituted a \u003cem>worldwide torture regime\u003c/em> by issuing decrees that purported to redefine what that term meant. They spied on the communications of American citizens \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/bush-lets-us-spy-on-callers-without-courts.html\">without the warrants required by law\u003c/a>. They \u003ca href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/02/14/outsourcing-torture\">kidnapped innocent people\u003c/a> from foreign soil and sent them to be tortured in the dungeons of the world&#8217;s worst regimes, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jun/21/lawsuit-muslims-september-11-roundup-abuse\">rounded up Muslims on domestic soil\u003c/a> with \u003ca href=\"http://glenngreenwald.blogspot.co.uk/2005/11/true-tyranny-defined-bush-admin-v-jose.html\">no charges\u003c/a>. They \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/17/sami-al-haj-al-jazeera-guantanamo-bay-journalist\">imprisoned Muslim journalists\u003c/a> for years without a whiff of due process. And they generally embraced and implemented the fundamental tenets of authoritarianism by \u003ca href=\"http://glenngreenwald.blogspot.co.uk/2006/01/ideology-of-lawlessness.html\">explicitly positioning\u003c/a> the president and his White House above the law.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>We&#8217;re supposed to all forget about that, or at least agree to minimize it, in service of this revisionist conceit that the United States has long been governed by noble, honorable, and decent people until Donald Trump defaced the sanctity of the Oval Office with his band of gauche miscreants and evil clowns. Many of the same people who, just a decade ago, were depicting Dick Cheney, Karl Rove, and Paul Wolfowitz — remember them? — as monsters of historic proportions are today propagating the mythology that Trump is desecrating what had always been sacred and benevolent American civic space.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Not only were all Bush officials \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/aug/31/obama-justice-department-immunity-bush-cia-torturer\">fully immunized from the legal consequences\u003c/a> of their crimes — in D.C., that&#8217;s a given — but they were also fully welcomed back into decent, elite society with breakneck speed, lavished with honors, rewards, lucrative jobs, and praise. Those same Bush officials responsible for the most horrific crimes are now beloved by many of the same circles that, today, are expressing such righteous rage that Spicer is allowed onto the Emmy stage and a classroom at Harvard.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-right  width-fixed' style='width: 222px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/fromaut-1505729137.png\">\u003cimg class=\"alignright size-medium wp-image-146839\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/fromaut-1505729137-222x300.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>The speechwriter who churned out some of George W. Bush&#8217;s worst lies and most obscene justifications, David &#8220;Axis of Evil&#8221; Frum, is a senior editor at The Atlantic, a CNN contributor, and one of the most beloved and cited commentators by the self-styled, anti-Trump &#8220;Resistance.&#8221; With a straight face, he wrote a long, somber Atlantic article earlier this year, which the magazine put on its cover, in which he postured as someone qualified to warn of the dangers of authoritarianism when his only real qualification would be to write a manual on how to implement it.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Sean Spicer of torture and the Iraq War, Ari Fleischer, is a regular CNN contributor and makes many millions of dollars on the speaking circuit and \u003ca href=\"http://www.fleischercommunications.com/\">providing communications consulting advice\u003c/a> to large corporations and sports teams. One of the most vocal proponents of torture, former Bush and Rumsfeld speechwriter Marc Thiessen, was \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/marc-a-thiessen/?utm_term=.281b82bab904\">hired as a columnist\u003c/a> by the Washington Post shortly after his torture-advocating book was published, and he remains employed there.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>John Yoo, author of the memos justifying torture and lawlessness, is on the faculty of Berkeley Law School, where he holds an endowed chair. Condoleezza Rice, who \u003ca href=\"http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/LawPolitics/story?id=4583256\">literally chaired the meetings\u003c/a> inside the White House where torture was choreographed to the last detail and crusaded for the invasion of Iraq, is not only on the faculty of Stanford but serves on the boards of multiple Fortune 500 corporations and is virtually universally beloved.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Darth Cheney himself, after leaving the Bush administration, made millions from a book that he was able to promote by being welcomed onto all major television networks, where he was treated like a wise, old statesman. When a marble bust of him was unveiled at the Capitol, Joe Biden — whose administration had previously immunized Bush officials from prosecution for war crimes — \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2015/12/04/u-s-first-shields-its-torturers-and-war-criminals-from-prosecution-now-officially-honors-them/\">attended to pay homage\u003c/a> and heap praise on his predecessor, gushing: &#8220;I actually like Dick Cheney.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The rehabilitation of George W. Bush has been as widespread as it has been nauseating, culminating with a recent appearance on the talk show of liberal icon Ellen DeGeneres, who hugged him, hailed him as a personal friend, invited him to denounce Trump for sullying the office which Bush served with such honor, and then posted warm and loving pictures of the pair to her 48 million followers on Instagram.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/ellengw-1505723221.png\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003c/a>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/elleninst-1505723305.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-146836\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/elleninst-1505723305-540x368.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/ellengw-1505723221.png\"> \u003c/div>\u003cbr />\n\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Hillary Clinton, in her new book, fondly recalls how &#8220;George [W. Bush] actually called just minutes after I finished my concession speech, and graciously waited on the line while I hugged my team and supporters one last time. When we talked, he suggested we find time to get burgers together.&#8221; She added: &#8220;I think that’s Texan for &#8216;I feel your pain.'&#8221; We&#8217;ve put all that Iraq War, torture, and rendition unpleasantness behind us — just some good-faith policy disputes — and now see him as a nice, kind, decent, and honorable statesman.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In a \u003ca href=\"http://www.vulture.com/2017/09/joy-reid-wants-to-argue-with-you.html?utm_source=tw&amp;utm_medium=s3&amp;utm_campaign=sharebutton-t\">recent interview with Vulture\u003c/a>, the weekend MSNBC host Joy Reid, a former Obama campaign aide, gushed about the favorable views she now holds about, and the alignments she has now formed with, the Bush-era neocons who helped justify and usher in some of the most repugnant abuses and war crimes in American history:\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"clay-paragraph\">\u003cstrong>Vulture: On the flip side, it has to be a bit heartening that some conservatives who used to be sort of MSNBC &#8220;villains&#8221; are now on your network trashing a Republican president.\u003c/strong>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"clay-paragraph\">Reid: One of the most amazing outcomes of the Trump administration is the number of neo-conservatives that are now my friends and I am aligned with. I found myself agreeing on a panel with Bill Kristol. I agree more with Jennifer Rubin, David Frum, and Max Boot than I do with some people on the far left. I am shocked at the way that Donald Trump has brought people together. [\u003cem>Laughs\u003c/em>.]\u003c/p>\n\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>So if initiating an aggressive war (which the Nuremberg Tribunal \u003ca href=\"http://www.economist.com/node/14205505\">called\u003c/a> &#8220;the supreme international crime&#8221;), instituting an international torture regime (which Ronald Reagan \u003ca href=\"http://www.salon.com/2009/05/01/shifts/\">called\u003c/a> &#8220;an abhorrent practice&#8221; that no circumstance can justify), and embracing the full model of presidential lawlessness does not result in ostracization, sanction, or exclusion from polite society, why on earth would anyone expect that Sean Spicer would face any sort of actual recrimination or consequence?\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>If you&#8217;re someone who employs David Frum or hires Ari Fleischer or treats Bush-era war criminals as respectable and honored sources, you really have no standing to object to the paradigm that has ushered Spicer into the halls of elite power. This is the \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00603PI3U/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&amp;btkr=1\">precedent of elite immunity\u003c/a> that has been created, often by the same people who are now so upset that Sean Spicer and his fellow Trump functionaries are the beneficiaries of the framework they helped to install.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-09-18T10:10:44+00:00","date_local":"2017-09-18T06:10:44+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"If aggressive war, torture, and illegal spying didn't result in Bush officials getting ostracized, then why should anything?","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/18/sean-spicer-is-honored-because-as-bush-officials-showed-dc-elites-always-thrive/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"146167,139580","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/09/13/the-clinton-book-tour-is-largely-ignoring-the-vital-role-of-endless-war-in-the-2016-election-result/","https://theintercept.com/2017/08/31/nyts-newest-op-ed-hire-bari-weiss-embodies-its-worst-failings-and-its-lack-of-viewpoint-diversity/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Sean Spicer is honored because, as Bush officials showed, D.C. elites always thrive","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"sean-spicer-is-honored-because-as-bush-officials-showed-dc-elites-always-thrive","thumbnail":{"ID":146830,"alt_text":"","content":"","credit":"Photo: Danny Moloshok/Invision/AP","excerpt":"","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"3000","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803.jpg","width":"4170"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":143,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/AP_17261114183887-1505718803-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Sean Spicer"},"title":"Sean Spicer Is Honored Because — As Bush Officials Have Shown — D.C. Elites Always Thrive","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/18/sean-spicer-is-honored-because-as-bush-officials-showed-dc-elites-always-thrive/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"If aggressive war, torture, and illegal spying didn't result in Bush officials getting ostracized, then why should anything?","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Sean Spicer Honored at Emmys and Harvard Because D.C. Elites Always Thrive","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"148473":{"ID":148473,"article_length_type":"Long","authors":[{"ID":7,"brief_bio":"Glenn Greenwald is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Glenn Greenwald","email":"glenn.greenwald@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/glenn.greenwald.5","full_bio":"\u003cp>Glenn Greenwald is one of three co-founding editors of The Intercept. He is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law. His most recent book, \u003cem>No Place to Hide\u003c/em>, is about the U.S. surveillance state and his experiences reporting on the Snowden documents around the world. Prior to co-founding The Intercept, Glenn&#8217;s column was featured at \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> and \u003cem>Salon\u003c/em>. He was the debut winner, along with Amy Goodman, of the Park Center I.F. Stone Award for Independent Journalism in 2008, and also received the 2010 Online Journalism Award for his investigative work on the abusive detention conditions of Chelsea Manning. For his 2013 NSA reporting, he received the George Polk award for National Security Reporting; the Gannett Foundation award for investigative journalism and the Gannett Foundation watchdog journalism award; the Esso Premio for Excellence in Investigative Reporting in Brazil (he was the first non-Brazilian to win), and the Electronic Frontier Foundation&#8217;s Pioneer Award. Along with Laura Poitras, \u003cem>Foreign Policy\u003c/em> magazine named him one of the top 100 Global Thinkers for 2013. The NSA reporting he led for \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> was awarded the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for public service.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/02/Glenn-Greenwald-Original_350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"glenn-greenwald","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/GlennGreenwaldPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"734A 3680 A438 DD45 AF6F  5B99 A4A9 28C7 69CD 6E44","pgp_key":"Glenn Greenwald Public Key","twitter":"@ggreenwald","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/glenn-greenwald/","user_group":"founding-editor","user_title":"Co-founding Editor and Columnist"},{"ID":30162,"brief_bio":"","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"David Miranda","email":"amd1144@hotmail.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/david1-1506436322.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"david-miranda","pgp_file":"","pgp_fingerprint":"","pgp_key":"","twitter":"@davidmirandario ","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/david-miranda/","user_group":"","user_title":""}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2huyXiT","categories":[{"name":"Brazil","slug":"brazil"},{"name":"Drug Policy","slug":"drug-policy"},{"name":"Glenn Greenwald","slug":"greenwald"},{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"60","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>On July 1, 2001,\u003c/u> Portugal enacted a law to decriminalize all drugs. Under that law, nobody who is found possessing or using narcotics is arrested in Portugal, nor are they turned into a criminal. Indeed, neither drug use nor possession is considered a crime at all. Instead, those found doing it are sent to speak with a panel of drug counsellors and therapists, where they are offered treatment options.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Seven years after the law was enacted, in 2008, we traveled to Lisbon to study the effects of that law for one of the first comprehensive reports on this policy, the findings of which were published \u003ca href=\"https://www.cato.org/publications/white-paper/drug-decriminalization-portugal-lessons-creating-fair-successful-drug-policies\">in a report\u003c/a> for the Cato Institute. The results were clear and stunning: This radical change in drug laws was a fundamental and undeniable success. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">While Portugal throughout the 1990s was (like most Western countries) drowning in drug overdoses along with drug-related violence and diseases, the country rose to the top of the charts in virtually all categories after it stopped prosecuting drug users and treating them like criminals. This stood in stark contrast to countries that continued to follow a harsh criminalization approach: the more they arrested addicts and waged a “war on drugs,” the more their drug problems worsened.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">With all the money that had been wasted in Portugal to prosecute and imprison drug users now freed up for treatment programs, and the government viewed with trust rather than fear, previously hopeless addicts transformed into success stories of stability and health, and the government’s anti-drug messages were heeded. The predicted rise in drug usage rates never happened; in some key demographic categories, usage actually declined. As the 2009 study concluded: “The data show that, judged by virtually every metric, the Portuguese decriminalization framework has been a resounding success.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class='stylized pull-none'>&#8220;The data show that, judged by virtually every metric, the Portuguese decriminalization framework has been a resounding success.&#8221;\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Over the weekend, New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof, writing from Lisbon, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/22/opinion/sunday/portugal-drug-decriminalization.html?mcubz=3\">re-visited this data\u003c/a>, now even more ample and conclusive than it was back in 2009. His conclusions were even more stark than the Cato report of eight years ago: namely, Portugal has definitively won the argument on how ineffective, irrational, and counterproductive drug prohibition is. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The basis for this conclusion: Portugal’s clear success with decriminalization, compared to the tragic failures of countries, such as the U.S. (and Brazil), which continue to treat addiction as a criminal and moral problem rather than a health problem. Kristof writes:\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\"> After more than 15 years, it’s clear which approach worked better. The United States drug policy failed spectacularly, with about as many Americans dying last year of overdoses — around 64,000 — as were killed in the Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq Wars combined.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\"> In contrast, Portugal may be winning the war on drugs — by ending it. Today, the Health Ministry estimates that only about 25,000 Portuguese use heroin, down from 100,000 when the policy began.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\"> The number of Portuguese dying from overdoses plunged more than 85 percent before rising a bit in the aftermath of the European economic crisis of recent years. Even so, Portugal’s drug mortality rate is the lowest in Western Europe — one-tenth the rate of Britain or Denmark — and about one-fiftieth the latest number for the U.S.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Kristof succinctly identified one key reason for this success: “It&#8217;s incomparably cheaper to treat people than to jail them.” But there are other vital reasons, including the key fact that when it comes to efforts to persuade addicts to obtain counseling, “decriminalization makes all this easier, because people no longer fear arrest.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1000px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/kristof-1506433706.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-large wp-image-148478\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/kristof-1506433706-1000x348.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Perhaps the most compelling evidence highlighting Portugal’s success is not the empirical data but the political reality: Whereas the law was quite controversial when first enacted 16 years ago, there are now no significant political factions agitating for its repeal or for a return to drug prohibition.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cu>This evidence is\u003c/u> of vital importance to the citizens of any country that continues to treat drug users and addicts as criminals. It is simply unconscionable to break up families, force children to remain apart from imprisoned parents, and turn drug addicts into unemployable felons, particularly if the data demonstrates that those policies achieve the opposite results as their claimed intent.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But moral questions aside, the drug-related violence now sweeping Brazil, particularly the horrific war that is engulfing the Rio de Janeiro favela of Rocinha &#8212; just a few years \u003ca href=\"https://lab.org.uk/brazil-the-pacification-of-rocinha/\">after it was declared “pacified”\u003c/a> &#8212; makes these questions of particular urgency for Brazilians and citizens of any country. \u003cspan class=\"s1\">Brazil has witnessed repeated outbreaks of horrific violence in the favelas of its largest cities, many of which have long been ruled not by the government but by well-armed drug gangs. But this past week’s war &#8212; and that’s what it is &#8212; in Rocinha, located in the middle of Rio de Janeiro’s fashionable Zona Sul, has been particularly shocking.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/IMG_2821-39-1506433826.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-148479\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/IMG_2821-39-1506433826-1024x683.jpg\" alt=\"IMG_2821-39-1506433826\" />\u003c/a> \u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Pedro Prado/The Intercept Brasil\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Competing drug gangs have “invaded” the favela and are in open warfare for control of the drug trade, in the process forcing schools to close, residents to cower in their homes, and stores to remain shuttered. As Misha Glenny \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/25/rocinha-favela-rio-de-janeiro-violence/\">reported on Monday\u003c/a> in The Intercept, &#8220;The immediate cause of violence is the ongoing struggle between and now within factions,&#8221; but the violence portends the high likelihood of a wider war for control of the drug trade. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">In the face of drug-related violence, there is a temptation to embrace the seemingly simplest solution: an even-greater war on drugs, more drug dealers and addicts in prison, more police, more prohibition. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Those who peddle this approach want people to believe a simple-minded string of reasoning: the cause of drug-related problems, such as violence from drug gangs, is drugs. Therefore, we must eliminate drugs. Therefore, the more problems we have from drugs, the more aggressively we rid society of drugs and those who sell and use them.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">But this mentality is based on an obvious, tragic fallacy: namely, that the war on drugs, and drug criminalization, will eliminate drugs or at least reduce its availability. Decades of failure prove this will not happen; rather, the opposite will occur. Like the U.S., Brazil has imprisoned hundreds of thousands of citizens for drug-related crimes &#8212; mostly poor and nonwhite &#8212; and the problem has only worsened. Any person with minimal rationality would be forced to admit this string of logic is false.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Supporting a failed policy by hoping that, one day, it will magically succeed, is the definition of irrationality. In the case of drug laws &#8212; which spawn misery and suffering &#8212; it is not only irrational but cruel. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">A \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jun/02/war-on-drugs-not-working\">2011 report\u003c/a> from the Global Commission on Drug Policy &#8212; featuring multiple world leaders including former United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan and former Brazilian President Fernando Henrique Cardoso &#8212; examined all relevant evidence and put it simply: “The global war on drugs has failed, with devastating consequences for individuals and societies around the world.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The primary fact in this conclusion is vitally important. The key cause of all drug-related pathologies &#8212; particularly gang violence of the type now suffocating Rocinha &#8212; is not drugs themselves, but rather the policy of criminalizing drugs and the war waged in its name.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6775-1506434215.jpg\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003c/a>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6775-1506434215.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-148485\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6775-1506434215-1024x684.jpg\" alt=\"EMD_6775-1506434215\" />\u003c/a>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6775-1506434215.jpg\"> \u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Erick Dau/The Intercept Brasil\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cbr />\n\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">\u003cu>The nature of\u003c/u> drugs &#8212; their small size, the ease of smuggling, the natural demand humans have for them &#8212; means they can never be eliminated or meaningfully reduced by force. Only changes in human behavior, which can happen with sustained and professional treatment, can foster those improvements. The only effect of drug criminalization, beyond the massive human and financial waste of imprisoning addicts, is to empower and enrich drug gangs by ensuring that the profits from selling an illegal product remain irresistibly high.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">For that reason, the most devoted opponents of drug legalization or decriminalization are drug gangs themselves. Nothing would erase the power of drug gangs &#8212; such as the ones violently battling for control of Rocinha &#8212; more quickly or severely than the elimination of drug prohibition. As adept businesspeople, drug traffickers know that very well.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class='stylized pull-none'>&#8220;The most devoted opponents of drug legalization or decriminalization are drug gangs themselves.&#8221;\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">In 2016, the journalist Johann Hari, author of one of the most influential books on drug addiction, \u003ca href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johann-hari/the-only-thing-drug-gangs_b_695264.html\">wrote an article\u003c/a> in The Huffington Post titled: “The Only Thing Drug Gangs and Cartels Fear Is Legalization.” As he put it:\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\"> When you criminalize a drug for which there is a large market, it doesn’t disappear. The trade is simply transferred from off-licenses, pharmacists and doctors to armed criminal gangs. In order to protect their patch and their supply routes, these gangs tool up — and kill anyone who gets in their way. You can see this any day on the streets of a poor part of London or Los Angeles, where teenage gangs stab or shoot each other for control of the 3000 percent profit margins on offer.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">We have a perfect historical analogy that proves this point: alcohol prohibition in the U.S. in the 1920s. When alcohol was made illegal, it did not disappear. Control of its sale and distribution simply shifted: from the corner grocery story to violent drug gangs of the type that Al Capone became famous for ruling. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">In other words, making alcohol illegal did not stop people from consuming it. What it did do, though, was empower vicious gangs of organized crime for whom the massive profits of selling illegal alcohol made them willing to do anything, or kill anyone, to protect it.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">What finally eliminated those violent prohibition gangs was not the police or the imprisonment of illegal dealers or alcoholics: During prohibition, when the gangs were’t bribing the police, they were killing them. What eliminated those gangs was the re-legalization of alcohol: by regulating the sale of alcohol, the end of prohibition made the gangs irrelevant, and they thus disappeared. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Violent drug gangs do not fear the war on drugs; to the contrary, as Hari notes, they crave it. It is the criminalization of drugs that makes their trade so profitable. Hari quotes a long-time drug enforcement official in the U.S. as relating: “On one undercover tape-recorded conversation, a top cartel chief, Jorge Roman, expressed his gratitude for the drug war, calling it ‘a sham put on the American tax-payer’ that was ‘actually good for business.’”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-right  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/allen-1506433928.png\">\u003cimg class=\"alignright size-article-medium wp-image-148480\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/allen-1506433928-540x517.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>In 2015, Danielle Allen, a political theorist at Harvard University, wrote \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/how-the-war-on-drugs-creates-violence/2015/10/16/6de57a76-72b7-11e5-9cbb-790369643cf9_story.html?utm_term=.e28c412d5606\">an op-ed in the Washington Post\u003c/a> titled “How the war on drugs creates violence.” In it, she explained that one key reason to “decriminalize drugs flows from how the war on drugs drives violent crime, which in turn pushes up incarceration and generates other negative social outcomes.” As she explained: “You just can’t move $100 billion worth of illegal product without a lot of assault and homicide. This should not be a hard point to see or make.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Why is Rocinha filled with guns and ruled by drug gangs that are capable of such violence? Why can an influential Brazilian politician, linked to some of the most powerful figures in the country, employ a pilot who was \u003ca href=\"http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&amp;objectid=11163376\">caught transporting millions of dollars in cocaine in a helicopter\u003c/a> owned by the politician, with no consequences for anyone? \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The answer is clear: because laws that outlaw drugs ensure that the drug trade is extremely profitable, which in turn ensures that gangs of organized criminals will arm themselves, and will kill, in order to control it. Situated in the middle of Zona Sul with easy exits, Rocinha will inevitably be a drug haven for rich tourists, middle-class professionals, and impoverished addicts. The vast sums of profits created by the war on drugs ensure that police forces will not only be out-armed but also so corrupted that their efforts will inevitably fail.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">It is now undeniably clear that it is the war on drugs itself which is what causes &#8212; not stops &#8212; drug-related violence.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">If you’re horrified by the violence in Rocinha or places around the world like it, the last thing you should do is support more policies that fuel the violence: namely, criminalization and the war on drugs. To do so is like protesting lung cancer by encouraging people to smoke. The data is now sufficient to state confidently: those who support ongoing drug criminalization are the ones abetting this drug violence and the related problems of addiction and overdose.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">It may be slightly paradoxical at first glance, but the data leaves no doubt: The only way to avoid Rocinha-style violence is through full drug decriminalization. We no longer need to speculate about this. Thanks to Portugal, the results are in, and they could not be clearer.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cem>David Miranda is the husband of Intercept co-founder Glenn Greenwald and a city councilmember for Rio de Janeiro (PSOL).\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-09-26T14:20:37+00:00","date_local":"2017-09-26T10:20:37+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The only way to stop drug violence and other drug-related pathologies is by ending drug criminalization.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"148469","language_related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/09/26/a-unica-solucao-para-a-violencia-como-na-rocinha-e-a-descriminalizacao/"],"layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/26/brazils-latest-outbreak-of-drug-gang-violence-highlights-the-real-culprit-the-war-on-drugs/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Spoken outbreak of drug gang warfare highlights the real culprit: the war on Brasil","excerpt":"","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"2003","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619.jpg","width":"3000"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":133,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"EMD_6866-1506433619"},"title":"Brazil’s Latest Outbreak of Drug Gang Violence Highlights the Real Culprit: the War on Drugs","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/26/brazils-latest-outbreak-of-drug-gang-violence-highlights-the-real-culprit-the-war-on-drugs/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/EMD_6866-1506433619.jpg","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Glenn Greenwald and David Miranda: The success of drug decriminalization in Portugal shows more urgently than ever that the war on drugs doesn't work.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Brazil Must Decriminalize Drugs to Stop Gang Violence","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"149054":{"ID":149054,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":7,"brief_bio":"Glenn Greenwald is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Glenn Greenwald","email":"glenn.greenwald@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/glenn.greenwald.5","full_bio":"\u003cp>Glenn Greenwald is one of three co-founding editors of The Intercept. He is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law. His most recent book, \u003cem>No Place to Hide\u003c/em>, is about the U.S. surveillance state and his experiences reporting on the Snowden documents around the world. Prior to co-founding The Intercept, Glenn&#8217;s column was featured at \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> and \u003cem>Salon\u003c/em>. He was the debut winner, along with Amy Goodman, of the Park Center I.F. Stone Award for Independent Journalism in 2008, and also received the 2010 Online Journalism Award for his investigative work on the abusive detention conditions of Chelsea Manning. For his 2013 NSA reporting, he received the George Polk award for National Security Reporting; the Gannett Foundation award for investigative journalism and the Gannett Foundation watchdog journalism award; the Esso Premio for Excellence in Investigative Reporting in Brazil (he was the first non-Brazilian to win), and the Electronic Frontier Foundation&#8217;s Pioneer Award. Along with Laura Poitras, \u003cem>Foreign Policy\u003c/em> magazine named him one of the top 100 Global Thinkers for 2013. The NSA reporting he led for \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> was awarded the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for public service.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/02/Glenn-Greenwald-Original_350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"glenn-greenwald","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/GlennGreenwaldPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"734A 3680 A438 DD45 AF6F  5B99 A4A9 28C7 69CD 6E44","pgp_key":"Glenn Greenwald Public Key","twitter":"@ggreenwald","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/glenn-greenwald/","user_group":"founding-editor","user_title":"Co-founding Editor and Columnist"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2wZCcWx","categories":[{"name":"Glenn Greenwald","slug":"greenwald"},{"name":"Media critique","slug":"media-critique"},{"name":"Russia","slug":"russia"},{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"960","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>Last Friday,\u003c/u> most major media outlets touted a major story about Russian attempts to hack into U.S. voting systems, based exclusively on claims made by the Department of Homeland Security. &#8220;Russians attempted to hack elections systems in 21 states in the run-up to last year&#8217;s presidential election, officials said Friday,&#8221; \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/09/22/wisconsin-one-20-states-targeted-russian-hacking-elections-systems-2016/694719001/\">began the USA Today story\u003c/a>, similar to how most other outlets presented this extraordinary claim.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/usatoday-1506606928.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-149056\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/usatoday-1506606928-1024x719.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>This official story was explosive for obvious reasons, and predictably triggered instant decrees &#8211; that of course went viral &#8211; declaring that the legitimacy of the outcome of the 2016 U.S. presidential election is now in doubt.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 597px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/siskind-1506607201.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-pez-640 wp-image-149058\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/siskind-1506607201.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Virginia&#8217;s Democratic Congressman Don Beyer, referring to the 21 targeted states, announced that this shows &#8220;Russia tried to hack their election&#8221;:\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The same day \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@realDonaldTrump\u003c/a> refers to &quot;Russia Hoax,&quot; Homeland Security Dept. tells 21 states that Russia tried to hack their elections. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/X6UrqFMUTW\">https://t.co/X6UrqFMUTW\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Rep. Don Beyer (@RepDonBeyer) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RepDonBeyer/status/911342530486308864?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 22, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>MSNBC&#8217;s Paul Revere for all matters relating to the Kremlin take-over, Rachel Maddow, was indignant that this wasn&#8217;t told to us earlier and that we still aren&#8217;t getting all the details. &#8220;What we have now figured out,&#8221; Maddow gravely intoned as she showed the multi-colored maps she made, is that &#8220;Homeland Security knew at least by June that 21 states had been targeted by Russian hackers during the election. . .targeting their election infrastructure.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">DHS didn&#39;t bother to tell the 21 states Russia tried to hack during the election until this afternoon. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/48CNZL8MBp\">https://t.co/48CNZL8MBp\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Maddow Blog (@MaddowBlog) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MaddowBlog/status/911402625257529344?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 23, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>They were one small step away from demanding that the election results be nullified, indulging the sentiment expressed by #Resistance icon Carl Reiner \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/carlreiner/status/910368406112735237\">the other day:\u003c/a> &#8220;Is there anything more exciting that [\u003cem>sic\u003c/em>] the possibility of Trump&#8217;s election being invalidated &amp; Hillary rightfully installed as our President?&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>So what was wrong with this story? Just one small thing: it was false. The story began to fall apart yesterday when \u003ca href=\"https://www.apnews.com/10a0080e8fcb4908ae4a852e8c03194d?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&amp;utm_source=Twitter&amp;utm_medium=APCentralRegion\">Associated Press reported\u003c/a> that Wisconsin &#8211; one of the states included in the original report that, for obvious reasons, caused the most excitement &#8211; did not, in fact, have its election systems targeted by Russian hackers:\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/apwis-1506608475.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-149077\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/apwis-1506608475-540x377.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/apwi-1506608331.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-149076\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/apwi-1506608331-1024x556.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>The spokesman for Homeland Security then tried to walk back that reversal, insisting that there was still evidence that some computer networks had been targeted, but could not say that they had anything to do with elections or voting. And, as AP noted: &#8220;Wisconsin’s chief elections administrator, Michael Haas, had repeatedly said that Homeland Security assured the state it had not been targeted.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Then the story collapsed completely last night. The Secretary of State for another one of the named states, California, issued a scathing statement repudiating the claimed report:\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/padilla2-1506608779.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-149080\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/padilla2-1506608779-540x587.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Sometimes stories end up debunked. There&#8217;s nothing particularly shocking about that. If this were an isolated incident, one could chalk it up to basic human error that has no broader meaning.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But this is no isolated incident. Quite the contrary: this has happened over and over and over again. Inflammatory claims about Russia get mindlessly hyped by media outlets, almost always based on nothing more than evidence-free claims from government officials, only to collapse under the slightest scrutiny, because they are entirely lacking in evidence.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The examples of such debacles when it comes to claims about Russia are too numerous to comprehensively chronicle. I wrote about this phenomenon many times and listed many of the examples, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/06/27/cnn-journalists-resign-latest-example-of-media-recklessness-on-the-russia-threat/\">the last time in June\u003c/a> when 3 CNN journalists &#8220;resigned&#8221; over a completely false story linking Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci to investigations into a Russian investment fund which the network was forced to retract:\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-149083\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/russia2-1506609144-540x230.png\" alt=\"\" /> \u003c/div>Remember that time the Washington Post \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/12/31/russia-hysteria-infects-washpost-again-false-story-about-hacking-u-s-electric-grid/\">claimed that Russia had hacked the U.S. electricity grid\u003c/a>, causing politicians to denounce Putin for trying to deny heat to Americans in winter, only to have to issue multiple retractions because none of that ever happened? Or the time that the Post had to \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/russian-propaganda-effort-helped-spread-fake-news-during-election-experts-say/2016/11/24/793903b6-8a40-4ca9-b712-716af66098fe_story.html\">publish a massive editor&#8217;s note\u003c/a> after its reporters made claims about Russian infiltration of the internet and spreading of &#8220;Fake News&#8221; based on an anonymous group&#8217;s McCarthyite blacklist that counted sites like the Drudge Report and various left-wing outlets as Kremlin agents?\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Or that time when Slate claimed that Trump had created a secret server with a Russian bank, all based on evidence that \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/yet-another-major-russia-story-falls-apart-is-skepticism-permissible-yet/\">every other media outlet\u003c/a> which looked at it \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/01/that-secret-trump-russia-email-server-link-is-likely-neither-secret-nor-a-trump-russia-link/?utm_term=.0d6dc14257ad\">were too embarrassed to get near\u003c/a>? Or the time the Guardian \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/12/29/the-guardians-summary-of-julian-assanges-interview-went-viral-and-was-completely-false/\">was forced to retract\u003c/a> its report by Ben Jacobs &#8211; which went viral &#8211; that casually asserted that WikiLeaks has a long relationship with the Kremlin? Or the time that Fortune \u003ca href=\"http://fortune.com/2017/01/12/cspan-rt-interruption/\">retracted suggestions that RT had hacked\u003c/a> into and taken over C-SPAN&#8217;s network? And then there&#8217;s the huge market that was created &#8211; led by leading Democrats &#8211; that \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/world/2017/5/19/15561842/trump-russia-louise-mensch\">blindly ingested every conspiratorial, unhinged claim\u003c/a> about Russia churned out by an army of crazed conspiracists such as Louise Mensch and Claude &#8220;TrueFactsStated&#8221; Taylor?\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>And now we have the Russia-hacked-the-voting-systems-of-21-states to add to this trash heap. Each time the stories go viral; each time they further shape the narrative; each time those who spread them say little to nothing when it is debunked.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&nbsp;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cu>None of this\u003c/u> means that every Russia claim is false, nor does it disprove the accusation that Putin ordered the hacking of the DNC and John Podesta&#8217;s email inboxes (a claim for which, just by the way, still no evidence has been presented by the U.S. government). Perhaps there were some states that were targeted, even though the key claims of this story, that attracted the most attention, have now been repudiated.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But what it does demonstrate is that an incredibly reckless, anything-goes climate prevails when it comes to claims about Russia. Media outlets will publish literally any official assertion as Truth without the slightest regard for evidentiary standards.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Seeing Putin \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ggreenwald/status/913099252326440973\">lurking behind and masterminding\u003c/a> every western problem is now religious dogma &#8211; it explains otherwise-confounding developments, provides certainty to a complex world, and alleviates numerous factions of responsibility &#8211; so media outlets and their journalists are lavishly rewarded any time they publish accusatory stories about Russia (especially ones involving the U.S. election), even if they end up being debunked.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>A \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/technology/twitter-russia-election.html?mcubz=3\">highly touted story yesterday\u003c/a> from the New York Times &#8211; claiming that Russians used Twitter more widely known than before to manipulate U.S. politics &#8211; demonstrates this recklessness. The story is based on the claims of a new group formed just two months ago by a union of neocons and Democratic national security officials, led by long-time liars and propagandists such as Bill Kristol, former acting CIA chief Mike Morell, and Bush Homeland Security Secretary Mike Chertoff. I \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/07/17/with-new-d-c-policy-group-dems-continue-to-rehabilitate-and-unify-with-bush-era-neocons/\">reported on the founding of this group\u003c/a>, calling itself the Alliance for Securing Democracy, when it was unveiled (this is not to be confused with the latest new Russia group \u003ca href=\"http://variety.com/2017/politics/news/rob-reiner-david-frum-committee-to-investigate-russia-1202563293/\">unveiled last week\u003c/a> by Rob Reiner and David Frum and featuring a different former national security state official (former DNI James Clapper) &#8211; calling itself InvestigateRussia.org &#8211; featuring a video declaring that the U.S. is now &#8220;at war with Russia&#8221;).\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Kristol/Morell/Chertoff group on which the Times based its article has a very simple tactic: they secretly decide which Twitter accounts are &#8220;Russia bots,&#8221; meaning accounts that disseminate an &#8220;anti-American message&#8221; and are controlled by the Kremlin. They \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ggreenwald/status/913380227514019840\">refuse to tell anyone\u003c/a> which Twitter accounts they decided are Kremlin-loyal, nor will they identify their methodology for creating their lists or determining what constitutes &#8220;anti-Americanism.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>They do it all in secret, and you&#8217;re just supposed to trust them: Bill Kristol, Mike Chertoff and their national security state friends. And the New York Times is apparently fine with this demand, as evidenced by its uncritical acceptance yesterday of the claims of this group &#8211; a group formed by the nation&#8217;s least trustworthy sources.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But no matter. It&#8217;s a claim about nefarious Russian control. So it&#8217;s instantly vested with credibility and authority, published by leading news outlets, and then blindly accepted as fact in most elite circles. From now on, it will simply be Fact &#8211; based on the New York Times article &#8211; that the Kremlin aggressively and effectively weaponized Twitter to manipulate public opinion and sow divisions during the election, even though the evidence for this new story is the secret, unverifiable assertions of a group filled with the most craven neocons and national security state liars.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>That&#8217;s how the Russia narrative is constantly &#8220;reported,&#8221; and it&#8217;s the reason so many of the biggest stories have embarrassingly collapsed. It&#8217;s because the Russia story of 2017 &#8211; not unlike the Iraq discourse of 2002 &#8211; is now driven by religious-like faith rather than rational faculties.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>No questioning of official claims is allowed. The evidentiary threshold which an assertion must overcome before being accepted is so low as to be non-existent. And the penalty for desiring to \u003cem>see evidence\u003c/em> for official claims, or questioning the validity and persuasiveness of the evidence that is proffered, are accusations that impugn one&#8217;s patriotism and loyalty (simply wanting to see evidence for official claims about Russia is proof, in many quarters, that one is a Kremlin agent or at least adores Putin &#8211; just as wanting to see evidence in 2002, or questioning the evidence presented for claims about Saddam, was viewed as proof that one harbored sympathy for the Iraqi dictator).\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Regardless of your views on Russia, Trump and the rest, nobody can possibly regard this climate as healthy. Just look at how many major, incredibly inflammatory stories, from major media outlets, have collapsed. Is it not clear that there is something very wrong with how we are discussing and reporting on relations between these two nuclear-armed powers?\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-09-28T15:48:06+00:00","date_local":"2017-09-28T11:48:06+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"Now we have the \"Russia-hacked-the-voting-systems-of-21-states\" to add to this trash heap of debunked official claims. Is this a healthy climate? ","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/yet-another-major-russia-story-falls-apart-is-skepticism-permissible-yet/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Smart News","slug":"smart-news"},{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"147943,147889,145514,138888","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/09/24/decline-american-empire-donald-trump/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/22/bernie-sanders-interview-foreign-policy/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/11/make-mark-zuckerberg-testify/","https://theintercept.com/2017/08/02/white-house-says-russias-hackers-are-too-good-to-be-caught-but-nsa-partner-called-them-morons/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Yet another major Russia story falls apart.
