Is Skepticism Permissible Yet?","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/yet-another-major-russia-story-falls-apart-is-skepticism-permissible-yet/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"149674":{"ID":149674,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":101,"brief_bio":"Robert Mackey is a reporter and columnist focused on mining social networks for evidence of news events.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Robert Mackey","email":"robert.mackey@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/robert.mackey.794","full_bio":"\u003cp>Robert Mackey writes about national and international news through the prism of social media. Before joining The Intercept as a Senior Writer, he was a reporter and columnist for the New York Times, where he anchored the newspaper&#8217;s breaking news blog, \u003ca href=\"http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/author/robert-mackey/\">The Lede\u003c/a>, for five years, and wrote a news analysis column, \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/column/open-source\">Open Source\u003c/a>, from 2014 to 2016. His work is focused on making sense of events through the close reading of firsthand accounts, photographs, and video posted on social networks by witnesses and participants.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>His writing has also appeared in the New York Times Magazine, GQ, Slate, and The Guardian.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As a television producer, he has looked at \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mD61YTMiHnw\">the role played by soccer hooligans\u003c/a> in the war between Serbia and Croatia for Britain&#8217;s Channel 4, and spent a year and a half making a series of \u003ca href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MDVaW7CjH4Q\">video letters\u003c/a> from refugees for a United Nations-sponsored program broadcast in Sarajevo, Zagreb, and Belgrade during the wars in the former Yugoslavia.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/ROB-MACKEY.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"robertmackey","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/Robert-Mackey-Public-Key.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"FB79 2352 6F3C BA07 909D  766F 8F6C AB73 335F B9D8","pgp_key":"Robert Mackey Public Key","twitter":"@RobertMackey","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/robertmackey/","user_group":"","user_title":"Senior Writer"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2x6Rqc1","categories":[{"name":"Robert Mackey","slug":"mackey"}],"comments_number":"44","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>Catalonia&#8217;s independence referendum\u003c/u> concluded Sunday night here in Barcelona, the Catalan capital, amid deep uncertainty about everything from the integrity of the vote to the meaning of the result.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Despite claims from Spain&#8217;s central government in Madrid that the referendum was illegal and the result would not be recognized, a spokesperson for the Catalan regional government announced early Monday morning that 2,262,424 valid votes had been cast and counted &#8212; 90 percent of them in favor of independence from Spain.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">&quot;Out of the 2,262,424 ballots that were not seized, 2,020,144 were YES votes, 176,566 were NO votes, 45,586 in blank and 20,129 null votes&quot;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Catalan Government (@catalangov) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/catalangov/status/914619641015697408?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Immediately after the announcement, Spanish reporters pressed the spokesperson, Jordi Turull, to say what it meant for the referendum that the 2,262,424 voters comprised just 42 percent of Catalonia&#8217;s 5,343,358 eligible voters. Turull argued that ballot boxes seized by the Spanish police in an effort to block the referendum could have contained up to 700,000 more votes, meaning that more than 55 percent of the population might have attempted to take part in the referendum.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The counting, under strained circumstances, came at the end of a long day, which began before dawn with voters and poll workers across the region defending polling places from closure by national and regional police forces, acting on \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/29/catalans-defy-court-order-barring-independence-referendum/\">orders from Spain&#8217;s constitutional court\u003c/a> to block the vote.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">100s of referendum supporters wait at a Barcelona polling place where activists spent the night; plan passive resistance when police come \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/9RGf6bWV4B\">pic.twitter.com/9RGf6bWV4B\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/914346061090652161?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Catalan police dispatched to close polling station greeted by chants of &quot;We will vote!&quot; \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/xMmBuYZIv5\">pic.twitter.com/xMmBuYZIv5\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/914359989900365824?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Emotional scenes in Gracia with rounds of applause for elderly voters emerging from polling place for \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanReferendum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferendum\u003c/a> defying police \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/fnvya6NaNB\">pic.twitter.com/fnvya6NaNB\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/914414985413001217?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">54,9% participation \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/ArenysDeMunt?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#ArenysDeMunt\u003c/a> a 6 pm. The main street -la Riera- full of people, and the ballot boxes full of votes. \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanRefer%C3%A8ndum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferèndum\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/q0oLuLzRW4\">pic.twitter.com/q0oLuLzRW4\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Joan Rabasseda (@JoanRabasseda) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JoanRabasseda/status/914525290549870593?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Crits de \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/hemvotat?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#hemvotat\u003c/a> quan passen les 20h a l&#39;escola Antoni Balmanya del Camp de l&#39;Arpa del Clot \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/btvnoticies?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@btvnoticies\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/AOv45zEAHm\">pic.twitter.com/AOv45zEAHm\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Cristina Brotons (@BrotonsCristina) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/BrotonsCristina/status/914552309849485312?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Voters in Barcelona chanted &#8220;We have voted,&#8221; as the referendum ended.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">La plaça Catalunya salta de alegría al escuchar que, según el Govern, 2 millones de catalanes han dicho sí a la independencia. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/aC99niOq5s\">pic.twitter.com/aC99niOq5s\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Guillem Andrés (@Guillem_Andres) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Guillem_Andres/status/914618335245070337?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Activists in Barcelona&#8217;s Plaça de Catalunya erupted as the Catalan government announced that more than 2 million votes had been cast in favor of independence.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The effort to conduct a public exercise in democracy while simultaneously hiding ballot boxes from the police gave rise to surreal scenes across the region.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"fr\" dir=\"ltr\">Vidéo incroyable de la ville d&#39;Igualada, à une heure de Barcelone. Une haie d&#39;honneur et de protection citoyenne pour les urnes, transportées à la mairie pour dépouillement (images Daniel Farre) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/ReferendumCatalan?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#ReferendumCatalan\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/vdqeqd9ptY\">pic.twitter.com/vdqeqd9ptY\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Frédéric Autran (@fredericautran) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/fredericautran/status/914567405262733312?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Poll workers in Igualada, outside Barcelona, raced to prevent the police from confiscating ballot boxes.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>While the atmosphere at many polling places in the region was tense but calm, with limited efforts to block voting by the autonomous Catalan police force, known as the Mossos, images of Spanish police forces from outside the region using violence at a few polling places stunned and angered even those in the region opposed to secession.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1000px;'>\u003cbr />\n\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100117_police-1506883484.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-large wp-image-149710\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100117_police-1506883484-1000x501.jpg\" alt=\"SPAIN OUT. During the '1-O Catalan independence referendum' spanish National Police and Civil guards prevent people from entering to the polling centers to vote. Barcelona, Spain, on October 01, 2017. Photo by Almagro/Sipa USA(Sipa via AP Images)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Spanish police officers used force to keep voters in parts of Barcelona from taking part in a referendum on Catalonia&#8217;s independence on Sunday.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Almagro/Sipa via AP Images)\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Speaking as poll workers counted those ballots that had not been seized by the police, Carles Puigdemont, the leader of the Catalan Generalitat, a local executive with centuries of history, suggested that the next steps could take time. Puigdemont made clear, however, that he expected the vote to result in the formation of &#8220;an independent state.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">(4) Avui Catalunya ha guanyat molts referèndums. Tenim dret a la llibertat, a viure en pau, fora d&#39;un Estat que només etén la imposició \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/WrfclxVQEG\">pic.twitter.com/WrfclxVQEG\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Carles Puigdemont (@KRLS) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/KRLS/status/914599206064676866?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;Today, we have earned our right to sovereignty and respect,&#8221; Puigdemont said, calling on the European Union to help mediate dialogue with Spain. &#8220;This is no longer an internal affair, this is a European affair,&#8221; he added.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Some European leaders, including the Belgian prime minister, Charles Michel, had indeed deplored the use of force by Spanish police officers against Catalan voters.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Violence can never be the answer! We condemn all forms of violence and reaffirm our call for political dialogue \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanReferendum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferendum\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Spain?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Spain\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Charles Michel (@CharlesMichel) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/CharlesMichel/status/914455311553040384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Although an international observer mission of former parliamentarians praised the referendum, the EU released a statement Monday morning making it clear that it would not intervene in what it considers an internal affair of a member state. The European Commission added that in the event of a subsequent referendum considered legal by Spain, Catalonia would find itself outside the EU.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Legal position: If referendum were to be organised in line with the  Spanish Const. = territory leaving would find itself outside of EU.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Another: &quot;they won&#39;t, they&#39;re on our side.&quot;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Zach Campbell (@notzachcampbell) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/notzachcampbell/status/914375987105816578?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Police ask who is in charge at polling place; crowd answers, &quot;Everyone!&quot; \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/UCgtXJevQx\">pic.twitter.com/UCgtXJevQx\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/914387057782423552?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>For this &#8220;passivity,&#8221; the Catalan force was severely criticized by the central government&#8217;s representative in Catalonia, Enric Millo.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The regional government, in turn, called for Millo to resign.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Spokesman Turull: &quot;On behalf of the Catalan Government, we ask \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EnricMillo?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@EnricMillo\u003c/a> to step down as the Spanish state&#39;s delegate in Catalonia&quot;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Catalan Government (@catalangov) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/catalangov/status/914412999892488192?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In response to the violence, the board of Football Club Barcelona &#8212; the team that was, for years under the Franco dictatorship, a focus of Catalan national pride &#8212; demanded that a match scheduled for Sunday afternoon be postponed. The Spanish league, however, denied the request, apparently as part of an official effort to pretend that all was well in Catalonia.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Statement from Barça condemns &quot;today&#39;s actions in Catalunya preventing citizens from exercising and expressing their democratic rights&quot; \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/cfWODWAGb7\">pic.twitter.com/cfWODWAGb7\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; AS English (@English_AS) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/English_AS/status/914489103017807878?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The club then decided to go ahead with the match against Las Palmas, a team from the Canary Islands that had been granted permission to add Spanish flag patches to their jerseys for the game, but in an empty stadium to make it clear that the day was anything but normal.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"fr\" dir=\"ltr\">Busquets scores \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/OjsvcSe8Is\">pic.twitter.com/OjsvcSe8Is\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Sid Lowe (@sidlowe) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/sidlowe/status/914510192968126465?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Among those most clearly moved by the day&#8217;s events was Gerard Piqué, a Catalan native who stars for both the club and the Spanish national team. The defender, who expressed pride when he voted earlier in the day, was visibly shaken as he addressed the media after the game.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Ja he votat. Junts som imparables defensant la democràcia. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/mGXf7Qj1TM\">pic.twitter.com/mGXf7Qj1TM\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Gerard Piqué (@3gerardpique) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/3gerardpique/status/914433491747659776?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">A tearful Gerard Piqué says he will quit the Spain team if his support for the \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanReferendum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferendum\u003c/a> becomes an issue \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/bdMdctJ1v9\">pic.twitter.com/bdMdctJ1v9\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Telegraph Football (@TeleFootball) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TeleFootball/status/914831788207460352?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Piqué, whose Catalan nationalism has led to him being booed by Spaniards when he represents the country, teared up as he said that he would be willing to stop playing for Spain if he is no longer wanted.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Gerard \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Pique?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Pique\u003c/a> in tears: I am proud of \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Catalonia?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Catalonia\u003c/a> \u003cbr />If the national team don&#39;t want me, I&#39;ll leave \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanReferendum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferendum\u003c/a>\u003ca href=\"https://t.co/4g4e8crv5e\">pic.twitter.com/4g4e8crv5e\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Jamie Johnson (@JamieoJohnson) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JamieoJohnson/status/914562548866994178?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Several of the fan-owned club&#8217;s members, including the former captain and manager Pep Guardiola, were angered by the board&#8217;s refusal to simply forfeit the match in protest.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Pep Guardiola: &quot;They said that we attacked police officers. With what? With votes?&quot; \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/CatalanReferendum?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#CatalanReferendum\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; FC Barcelona Fl (@FCBarcelonaFl) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/FCBarcelonaFl/status/914576443820126208?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>One club member who took part in the effort to defend the referendum, and was among those who slept in a polling station the night before, told The Intercept that he was &#8220;ashamed&#8221; FC Barcelona had played the match on a day of such violence against Catalans. &#8220;I will quit FCB if the board does not resign this week,&#8221; the activist said. &#8220;Where is the dignity?&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The wounding of more than 800 voters by Spanish police officers provoked widespread anger and even led to scuffles in some places between officers from the autonomous regional force, the Mossos, and Spain&#8217;s national guard, the Guardia Civil.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">Algunos parecen no tenerlo nada claro. Vergonzoso. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/NinygR2GMy\">pic.twitter.com/NinygR2GMy\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; AUGC Guardia Civil (@AUGC_Comunica) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AUGC_Comunica/status/914476437784158208?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Un \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/guardiacivil?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@guardiacivil\u003c/a> agredeix amb un cop de porra a un \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mossos?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@mossos\u003c/a> a Sant Joan de Vilatorrada quan anava a demanar explicacions als agents. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/8WcrE4fZ3I\">pic.twitter.com/8WcrE4fZ3I\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; SER CATALUNYA (@SERCatalunya) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SERCatalunya/status/914499720718020608?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 1, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Supporters of Catalan independence in Barcelona, who mobilized to defend the polling places, had anticipated the split between local and national police forces. One activist, a researcher named Jordi who requested that his last name not be used, told me at one occupied polling station in Barcelona the night before the vote that a special bond had formed recently between the population and their police force in the aftermath of the deadly Islamist terrorist attack in Barcelona in August.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>When I pointed out that it was natural that the Mossos might react differently than Spanish officers from outside the region since they are Catalan too, Jordi replied that &#8220;the question of who is Catalan is difficult,&#8221; defying simple definition. But the Mossos officers, even those with roots in other parts of Spain, are all &#8220;citizens of Catalonia,&#8221; Jordi continued, and the people expect them to defend their fellow citizens, even against threats to public order prompted by orders from Spain&#8217;s central government.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Update: Oct. 2, 2017, 7:00 a.m.\u003cbr />\n\u003c/strong>\u003cem>This piece was updated to include the referendum result.\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Top Photo: Volunteer poll workers counted referendum ballots by the light of their phones during a blackout at the La Llacuna school in the Poble Nou neighborhood of Barcelona on Sunday Mackey is a reporter and columnist focused on mining social networks for evidence of news events.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Robert Mackey","email":"robert.mackey@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/robert.mackey.794","full_bio":"\u003cp>Robert Mackey writes about national and international news through the prism of social media. Before joining The Intercept as a Senior Writer, he was a reporter and columnist for the New York Times, where he anchored the newspaper&#8217;s breaking news blog, \u003ca href=\"http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/author/robert-mackey/\">The Lede\u003c/a>, for five years, and wrote a news analysis column, \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/column/open-source\">Open Source\u003c/a>, from 2014 to 2016. His work is focused on making sense of events through the close reading of firsthand accounts, photographs, and video posted on social networks by witnesses and participants.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>His writing has also appeared in the New York Times Magazine, GQ, Slate, and The Guardian.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As a television producer, he has looked at \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mD61YTMiHnw\">the role played by soccer hooligans\u003c/a> in the war between Serbia and Croatia for Britain&#8217;s Channel 4, and spent a year and a half making a series of \u003ca href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MDVaW7CjH4Q\">video letters\u003c/a> from refugees for a United Nations-sponsored program broadcast in Sarajevo, Zagreb, and Belgrade during the wars in the former Yugoslavia.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/ROB-MACKEY.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"robertmackey","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/Robert-Mackey-Public-Key.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"FB79 Writer"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2yDRlZL","categories":[{"name":"Robert Mackey","slug":"mackey"}],"comments_number":"15","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>Catalonia remained on\u003c/u> edge Monday, a day after \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/01/spanish-police-beat-catalan-voters-deepening-divide-threatens-spain/\">millions voted for independence from Spain\u003c/a> in a referendum that the central government used force to disrupt, severely limiting turnout but also raising questions about the legitimacy of a democracy that orders the police to beat voters.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As the European Union \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EU_Commission/status/914795139197018114\">spurned an appeal\u003c/a> from the president of the Catalan autonomous region, Carles Puigdemont, to facilitate talks with Spain about what comes next, tens of thousands of students marched through the streets of Barcelona with their mouths taped shut, to express their frustration about the Spanish government denying them a voice.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Vídeo de l&#39;espectacular marxa silenciosa de desenes de milers Paul Mason (@paulmasonnews) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/paulmasonnews/status/914808104172310528?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">Miles d estudiantes llegan a pza Cataluña y por megafonía \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Estaca?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Estaca\u003c/a> d Llach \u003ca Alfonso Congostrina (@alfcongostrina) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/alfcongostrina/status/914815749369339905?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>There was particular outrage at the violence inflicted on voters by members of Spanish police forces who were \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/29/catalans-defy-court-order-barring-independence-referendum/\">called in to block the referendum\u003c/a> after a Spanish court ruled that it was unconstitutional. The images of police officers beating voters and firing rubber bullets at polling places on Sunday stunned and horrified Catalans, and rage at the police only grew on Monday as more video clips were broadcast and circulated on social media.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">¿Alguien puede defender  esto? \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/WOVIYCnmAS\">pic.twitter.com/WOVIYCnmAS\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Carles Garcia (@CarlesGN) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/CarlesGN/status/914843063587131392?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The planned action appears to have widespread support, even from opponents of independence who feel that Spain denied them their democratic rights by hampering the referendum. Major Spanish trade unions refused to sanction the strike, but it was supported by the city of Barcelona and important Catalan cultural and sporting institutions, including FC Barcelona and the Sagrada Familia cathedral.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Demà, aturada general. Se suspenen tots els actes institucionals i els serveis no imprescindibles per al funcionament de la ciutat tancaran.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Ajuntament de BCN (@bcn_ajuntament) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/bcn_ajuntament/status/914876632946573314?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">FC Barcelona joins the country wide strike called for by Table for Democracy and therefore the Club will be closed tomorrow.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; FC Barcelona (@FCBarcelona) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/FCBarcelona/status/914850766220914691?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The Basilica of the Sagrada Família condemns the violence experienced yesterday in Catalonia and will be closed all day tomorrow, 3 October.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; La Sagrada Família (@sagradafamilia) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/sagradafamilia/status/914959182822027264?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The images of police violence enflamed opinion in Catalonia and abroad, yet instilled fear locally and likely had a chilling effect on voter turnout, leaving the legitimacy of the result in doubt.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>A Catalan activist who asked to be identified only by his first name, Jordi, because he feared retribution from the Spanish authorities, told The Intercept that he was distraught to hear that turnout for the referendum had been limited to about 42 percent and blamed the images of police beating voters for convincing many supporters of independence to stay home on Sunday. The activist also said that he feared that the Spanish government might be planning to arrest the Catalan president to provoke a crisis on the streets that would justify calling in a far larger security force, perhaps including the military.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The sense of frustration and hopelessness was expressed across Catalonia on Monday night in a form of noisy protest known as a casserolada, in which keys are shaken and casseroles, pots, and pans are banged on loudly.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">La \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/casserolada?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#casserolada\u003c/a> de \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Lleida?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Lleida\u003c/a> extremadament forta! \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/2O?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#2O\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/diariARA?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@diariARA\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/324cat?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@324cat\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/LleidaTV?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@LleidaTV\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/XBBUVcVkB7\">pic.twitter.com/XBBUVcVkB7\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Marc (@marcballesco) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/marcballesco/status/914946652385021952?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 2, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Casserolada?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Casserolada\u003c/a> a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Banyoles?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Banyoles\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/2Oct?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#2Oct\u003c/a> ? Barcelona.","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"3203","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177.jpg","width":"6407"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":99,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-e1506976219485-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/catalonia-referendum-spain-protests-aftermath-robert-mackey-1506976177-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Aftermath Of The Catalonian Independence Referendum"},"title":"A Mix of Hope, Fear and Anger in Catalonia After Millions Vote for Independence From Spain","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/02/mix-hope-fear-anger-catalonia-millions-vote-independence-spain/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Amid protests over violence by Spanish police, the next steps after Catalonia's referendum are uncertain but may include a general strike.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Hope, Fear and Anger in Catalonia After Independence Vote","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150156":{"ID":150156,"article_length_type":"Long","authors":[{"ID":104,"brief_bio":"Alice Speri is a multimedia journalist with an interest in justice, civil rights, and the struggle for equality.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Alice Speri","email":"alice.speri@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=20742","full_bio":"\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Alice Speri is a multimedia journalist with an interest in justice, civil rights, and the struggle for equality. She has reported on state violence and institutional failure in the U.S. and abroad, from Ferguson, Missouri, to Haiti and Palestine. Her work has appeared in VICE News, Al Jazeera America, the New York Times, and several other publications. She is originally from Italy and lives in the Bronx.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/03/alice-speri.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"alicesperi","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/06/6C2EFD79-1496771825.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"5D24 0C16 CFE3 F8B2 9616  2653 D39F 6457 6C2E FD79","pgp_key":"Alice Speri Public Key","twitter":"@alicesperi","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/alicesperi/","user_group":"","user_title":"Multimedia Reporter"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2kneH3I","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"25","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>As hundreds of\u003c/u> undocumented immigrants were rounded up across the country last February in the first mass raids of the Trump administration, Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials went out of their way to portray the people they detained as hardened criminals, instructing field offices to highlight the worst cases for the media and attempting to distract attention from the dozens of individuals who were apprehended despite having no criminal background at all.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>On February 10, as the raids kicked off, an ICE executive in Washington sent an “URGENT” directive to the agency’s chiefs of staff around the country. “Please put together a white paper covering the \u003cem>three most egregious cases,\u003c/em>” for each location, the acting chief of staff of ICE’s Enforcement and Removal Operations wrote in the email. “If a location has only one egregious case &#8212; then include an extra egregious case from another city.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.53-1507066463.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-150399\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.53-1507066463-540x315.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>The email indicated the assignment was due that night, but a day later, an agent at ICE’s San Antonio office sent an internal email saying the team had come up short. “I have been pinged by HQ this morning indicating that we failed at this tasking,” the agent wrote.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As the hours passed, the pressure on local agents to come up with something grew more intense. “As soon as you come in, your sole focus today will be compiling three egregious case write-ups,” an assistant field office director at the agency’s Austin Resident Office wrote to that team on February 12, noting that the national and San Antonio offices were growing impatient. “HQ and SNA will ping us in the afternoon for sure.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Then the agent added that a team of officers had “just picked up a criminal a few minutes ago, so get with him for your first egregious case.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.51-1507066460.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-150397\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.51-1507066460-540x324.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>A heavily redacted cache of emails, obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request by students at Vanderbilt University Law School and published exclusively by The Intercept, reveals how in the early days of Donald Trump’s presidency, ICE agents in Austin scrambled — and largely failed — to engineer a narrative that would substantiate the administration’s claims that the raids were motivated by public safety concerns. Instead, the emails detail the evolution of ICE’s public statements once it became obvious that the Trump administration’s narrative was not true.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Bob Libal, executive director of Grassroots Leadership, an Austin-based civil rights group, said the emails show just “how aggressive and desperate and duplicitous ICE was during these raids.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“Essentially this is ICE trying to gin up a case for its actions, when really this isn’t at all about public safety,” he told The Intercept after reviewing the correspondence. “We can thoroughly expect that’s what they’re going to try to do again.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>ICE declined to comment for this article.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Starting on February 6, ICE conducted a nationwide sweep of undocumented immigrants in large and small cities across the country, quickly disseminating panic in immigrant communities. The raids — which led to \u003ca href=\"https://www.ice.gov/doclib/news/library/factsheets/pdf/factsheet-fugops.pdf\">680 arrests\u003c/a> nationwide — were the first in an ongoing series of mass enforcement operations ordered by the Trump administration. Last week, \u003ca href=\"https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/ice-arrests-over-450-federal-immigration-charges-during-operation-%E2%80%98safe-city%E2%80%99\">more than 450\u003c/a> people were arrested in a similar sweep the agency dubbed “Operation Safe City.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>At first, immigration officials said they were targeting public safety threats, such as individuals with criminal convictions and gang members. But while they sought to depict those swept up in the raids as dangerous criminals, it immediately became clear that many had only minor violations on their record, and that dozens had no criminal record at all. In Austin, where 51 people were arrested during the February raids, \u003ca href=\"http://www.statesman.com/news/austin-for-non-criminals-arrested-ice-raids/R8suKsN9kUIjnpz10S2DII/\">more than half\u003c/a> had no criminal convictions. Many of those who did have criminal records were found guilty of drunken driving.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Within hours, stories of ICE’s aggressive tactics dominated the media, as Austin residents reported that agents had set up checkpoints on the street, detained a teenager, and mistakenly apprehended a legal resident with no criminal history as he dropped his kids off at school. As anxiety over the raids escalated, elected officials issued public condemnations, and local and national reporters inundated the agency’s Texas offices with requests for comment.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In their first media responses, ICE officials maintained the line that the raids were in the public interest, telling reporters that “by removing from the streets criminal aliens and other threats to the public, ICE helps improve public safety.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As criticism escalated, ICE shifted to downplaying the operation as “no different than the routine,” telling reporters that the raids were the same “targeted arrests carried out by ICE&#8217;s Fugitive Operations Teams on a daily basis,” and suggesting off the record that claims to the opposite were “false, dangerous, and irresponsible.” As it became clear that dozens of individuals with no criminal history had been apprehended, ICE shifted gears and told reporters that in addition to targeting safety threats, the raids were always meant to target those whose only crimes were immigration-related, like re-entering the U.S. after deportation: “The president has been clear in saying that DHS should be focused on removing individuals who pose a threat to public safety, who have been charged with criminal offenses, who have committed multiple immigration violations or who have been deported and re-entered the country illegally.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As they released their own statements, ICE officials were also monitoring elected officials’ public communications — and strategizing about how to respond to them.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.4-1507066458.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-150396\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.4-1507066458-540x386.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>“Congressman Castro is tweeting about ICEs enforcement operations taking place this weekend in south Texas,” an internal ICE email sent on February 10 read, forwarding a reporter’s query about Congressman Joaquin Castro’s \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/joaquincastrotx/status/830191630108000257?lang=en\">statement of concern\u003c/a> over the raids. “I&#8217;m responding to this reporter using our statement. But I&#8217;m not responding to what the Congressman is tweeting.” (Castro did not respond to a request for comment.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“Team, Please be careful.. Austin City councilmember Greg Casar is saying ICE has taken action in the North Lamar/ Rundberg areas arresting people for ‘standing up for our values against people like Abbott and Trump,’” a public information officer emailed in reference to a \u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GregorioCasar/posts/1331625896924655\">Facebook post\u003c/a> by the council member.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“I think what those emails make very clear is that we have a federal law enforcement agency that’s willing to lie, just like Trump is willing to lie, in order to continue the criminalization of immigrant communities,” Casar told The Intercept after reviewing the emails. “We live in a really scary time where a federal law enforcement agency like ICE is essentially operating as a propaganda machine for the Trump administration.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“They specifically went out of their way to mislead the public by searching for egregious cases,” he added. “And then you can see in the emails that they couldn’t find egregious cases.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In fact, ICE’s attempts to provide “egregious” examples of criminals being apprehended in the raids were lagging, the emails suggest. On February 11, an official responded to a colleague’s list of egregious cases by pointing out that they were unrelated to the ongoing operation. “The arrest dates are before any operation and even before the EO&#8217;s. What is up with these cases?” the official wrote.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 540px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.52-1507066461.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-medium wp-image-150398\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/p.52-1507066461-540x246.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Eventually, ICE managed to promote the detention of a Salvadoran man who had pleaded guilty to sexual assault of a child, but the agency failed to provide more egregious examples — and the media focused instead on ICE’s own egregious tactics.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed large-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/austin-santuary-city-ice-raids-1507047041.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150185\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/austin-santuary-city-ice-raids-1507047041-1024x684.jpg\" alt=\"Hundreds of protesters line the balconies of the state Capitol rotunda in Austin on Monday, May 29, 2017, the last day of the legislative session, to protest Senate Bill 4. legislation already passed by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott that compels local police to enforce federal immigration law. (Ricardo Brazziell/Austin American-Statesman via AP)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">Hundreds of protesters line the balconies of the state Capitol rotunda in Austin on May 29, 2017, the last day of the legislative session, to protest Senate Bill 4 legislation already passed by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott that compels local police to enforce federal immigration law.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Ricardo Brazziell/Austin American-Statesman/AP\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\n\u003ch3>Retaliatory Raids\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cu>Of all cities\u003c/u> targeted in the February raids, Austin yielded the highest percentage of non-criminal apprehensions — more than half, according to \u003ca href=\"http://www.statesman.com/news/austin-for-non-criminals-arrested-ice-raids/R8suKsN9kUIjnpz10S2DII/\">a review\u003c/a> by the Austin American-Statesman showing that 28 of the 51 people detained had committed no crime other than entering the country illegally. ICE dismissed such arrests as “collateral apprehensions,” suggesting that those apprehended were picked up because they might have been with someone who was wanted.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But many in the city felt that Austin was being targeted for a different reason — a political one.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Days after Trump’s election, Austin’s Sheriff-Elect Sally Hernandez, a Democrat, reiterated her campaign promise to turn Austin into Texas’s first &#8220;sanctuary city.&#8221; “The sheriff’s office will not be part of a deportation force that sacrifices hundreds and thousands of people, our neighbors, to a broken federal immigration system,” Hernandez \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/11/29/new-sanctuary-cities-in-texas-vow-to-resist-donald-trumps-deportations/\">said in November\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Hernandez, who was dubbed “sanctuary Sally” by conservative media, faced an uphill battle. Texas’s Republican Gov. Greg Abbott called her refusal to honor ICE requests a “betrayal” of her oath and \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/02/03/texas-governor-goes-to-war-with-austin-over-immigration-enforcement/\">cut $1.5 million\u003c/a> in criminal justice-related grants to Travis County. In May, Abbott signed into law Senate Bill 4, or “SB4,” one of the harshest anti-sanctuary legislations in the country, the constitutionality of which is being \u003ca href=\"https://www.aclu.org/blog/immigrants-rights/state-and-local-immigration-laws/fight-kill-texas-anti-immigrant-law-sb4-not\">disputed in court\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But as the battle over sanctuary cities is fought at the state level, the federal government has other ways to go after defiant local officials: It can make their cities targets for enforcement.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In Austin’s case, rumors that the raids there had been in retaliation for Hernandez’s stance against ICE swirled for weeks, and in March, they appeared to be confirmed by a federal judge who said in court that Austin was being targeted “as a result of the sheriff’s new policy.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Andrew Austin, a U.S. magistrate judge in the city, made the remarks during a hearing in the case of Juan Coronilla-Guerrero, an undocumented Mexican immigrant who had been detained during the February raids. Coronilla-Guerrero’s case had alarmed immigrant advocates, lawyers, and — the hearing transcript shows — the judge himself because ICE had apprehended him as he exited a courthouse, where he had gone to clear two unrelated charges.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The hearing transcript reveals a level of confusion as court officials began to face the new administration’s immigration policies.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“So this isn&#8217;t totally germane, but you&#8217;re here and it gives me an opportunity to ask some questions because we&#8217;ve been wondering exactly what the new policies will be because things have changed a bit,” the judge said, addressing ICE agent Laron Bryant, one of the agents who arrested Coronilla-Guerrero, before proceeding to quiz him on what courts might expect to see from the new administration.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In that exchange, Austin also revealed that shortly before the raids had begun, he and a fellow judge had been briefed by a senior ICE agent about the upcoming operation, which came in response to Hernandez’s policy, “because the meetings that occurred between the field office director and the sheriff didn’t go very well,” he said.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In an email to The Intercept, Austin declined to comment &#8220;any further than what was said in court.” Mark Lane, the other federal judge, who, according to Austin, was also briefed by ICE, declined to comment. A spokesperson for Hernandez wrote in an email to The Intercept that the sheriff “won’t comment on an allegation based on supposition.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>ICE denied targeting Travis County, calling statements that the raids were retaliatory “rumors” and “inaccurate.” But by that point, few seemed to believe the agency. “I&#8217;m sorry that ICE lied to me because they told me there was not a target,” said Gerald Daugherty, Travis County’s Republican commissioner. “I have to think a judge is telling the truth.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As accusations that the Austin raids were political payback piled up, the agency issued a statement saying that “more ICE operational activity is required to conduct at-large arrests in any law enforcement jurisdiction that fails to honor ICE immigration detainers.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>That was ostensibly the reasoning behind the raids in September as well, which the agency said “focused on cities and regions where ICE deportation officers are denied access to jails and prisons to interview suspected immigration violators or jurisdictions where ICE detainers are not honored.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Immigration advocates say that the focus on sanctuary cities is “politically motivated.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“Yet again, the Trump administration is attempting to terrorize immigrant communities, keep families in fear, and undermine the trust immigrants have in cities that refuse to subsidize federal immigration enforcement,” said Ana María Archila, co-executive director of the Center for Popular Democracy. “Knowing how often ICE has lied about the true purpose of their raids before, it is hard for us to believe any of their claims about Operation Safe City.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>ICE’s Acting Director Thomas Homan said in a statement announcing the more recent raids that ICE was being “forced to dedicate more resources to conduct at-large arrests in these communities.&#8221; But he was more blunt about the administration’s intention in a \u003ca href=\"http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/ice-chief-80-jump-in-illegal-targets-readies-national-sanctuary-crackdown/article/2629001\">July interview\u003c/a>, in which he called sanctuary cities “ludicrous” and made no secret of why he was going after them. “The president recognizes that you&#8217;ve got to have a true interior enforcement strategy to make it uncomfortable for them.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>That retaliation has already had an inhibiting effect on some local officials, said Casar, the Austin city council member. “They’re not saying they’re deploying extra federal agents to a dangerous area. &#8230; It’s retaliation based on a political reason, not based on any kind of law enforcement purpose,” he said. “These raids really are a terrifying tool and the idea that the Trump administration would specifically use those in places where there’s political disagreement is a really scary thing.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>When he and other local officials take action on immigration issues — for instance, by suing the state over SB4 — they now always ask themselves, “What is the level of potential exposure this has on our constituents?” Casar added. “That’s real political repression, and while it may sound great to say, ‘We just need to do it anyway because we can’t be intimidated by that’ — when you’re in the position of making those decisions, when there are real lives at stake, you really do have to think about it.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>There is no question that there are lives at stake.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>While Austin’s comments on the retaliatory nature of the Travis County raids drew fleeting attention to the politicization of federal enforcement operations, Coronilla-Guerrero, the man whose case was under review that day, was eventually deported, despite his wife telling the judge that his life would be at risk in Mexico, from where he had fled because of gang threats.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Last month, armed men dragged Coronilla-Guerrero out of the relatives’ home where he had been staying in the state of Guanajuato, while he was asleep with one of his children. His body was found on the street the next morning.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top photo: In this photo provided by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, ICE agents at a home in Atlanta, during a targeted enforcement operation on Feb. 9, 2017.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-04T18:41:27+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-04T14:41:27+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"ICE officials were instructed to find examples of \"egregious\" cases in a campaign to portray undocumented immigrants as hardened criminals.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured (Bryan Cox/ICE via AP)","content":"","credit":"Photo: Bryan Cox/ICE/AP","excerpt":"In this photo provided by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, ICE agents at a home in Atlanta, during a targeted enforcement operation on Feb. 9, 2017. ","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"1612","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174.jpg","width":"3223"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-e1507144015634-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/ice-immigration-raid-donald-trump-1507045174-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Immigration Arrests"},"title":"Internal Emails Show ICE Agents Struggling to Substantiate Trump’s Lies About Immigrants","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/ice-raids-trump-immigration-deportation/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Internal follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150158":{"ID":150158,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":101,"brief_bio":"Robert Mackey is a reporter and columnist focused on mining social networks for evidence of news events.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Robert Mackey","email":"robert.mackey@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/robert.mackey.794","full_bio":"\u003cp>Robert Mackey writes about national and international news through the prism of social media. Before joining The Intercept as a Senior Writer, he was a reporter and columnist for the New York Times, where he anchored the newspaper&#8217;s breaking news blog, \u003ca href=\"http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/author/robert-mackey/\">The Lede\u003c/a>, for five years, and wrote a news analysis column, \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/column/open-source\">Open Source\u003c/a>, from 2014 to 2016. His work is focused on making sense of events through the close reading of firsthand accounts, photographs, and video posted on social networks by witnesses and participants.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>His writing has also appeared in the New York Times Magazine, GQ, Slate, and The Guardian.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As a television producer, he has looked at \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mD61YTMiHnw\">the role played by soccer hooligans\u003c/a> in the war between Serbia and Croatia for Britain&#8217;s Channel 4, and spent a year and a half making a series of \u003ca href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MDVaW7CjH4Q\">video letters\u003c/a> from refugees for a United Nations-sponsored program broadcast in Sarajevo, Zagreb, and Belgrade during the wars in the former Yugoslavia.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/ROB-MACKEY.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"robertmackey","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/Robert-Mackey-Public-Key.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"FB79 2352 6F3C BA07 909D  766F 8F6C AB73 335F B9D8","pgp_key":"Robert Mackey Public Key","twitter":"@RobertMackey","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/robertmackey/","user_group":"","user_title":"Senior Writer"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xXXIKh","categories":[{"name":"Robert Mackey","slug":"mackey"}],"comments_number":"15","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cem>Updated: 6:15 p.m. EDT\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cu>Businesses ground to\u003c/u> a halt here in Barcelona and across Catalonia on Tuesday, as a general strike was observed and protesters poured into the streets. Two days after the Spanish government authorized \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/01/spanish-police-beat-catalan-voters-deepening-divide-threatens-spain/\">the use of force\u003c/a> to disrupt a referendum on independence from Spain, Catalans for and against secession remain livid.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The small village of Caldes de Montbui, Barcelona \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/VagaGeneral3O?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#VagaGeneral3O\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/4Oa2gcCJdU\">pic.twitter.com/4Oa2gcCJdU\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; 15MBcn_int (@15MBcn_int) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/15MBcn_int/status/915182238396043264?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Milers de manifestants a la plaça Major i fins el c/Verdaguer de Vic. Directa (@La_Directa) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/La_Directa/status/915145927987523586?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Among the crowds of pro-independence citizens of Catalonia on Tuesday, there were also some who openly opposed secession from Spain, but wanted to voice their disgust at the use of force to block the vote.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/UN?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@UN\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/UNHumanRights?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@UNHumanRights\u003c/a> This peaceful people deserves international mediation NOW! HELP! Not an internal issue! \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/catalanmediation?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#catalanmediation\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/3Oct?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#3Oct\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/pj6yCW9ul0\">pic.twitter.com/pj6yCW9ul0\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Eduard Vidal (@Common_Seny) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Common_Seny/status/915197118196977664?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Apart from anger at the Spanish police, there was also widespread scorn for the role played by Spain&#8217;s newspaper and television journalists, who stand accused by protesters of politically motivated, &#8220;manipulative&#8221; reporting that demonizes Catalan separatists as greedy or violent.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">&quot;Prensa espanyola, manipuladora.&quot; Protesters chanted bitterly against what they called the manipulative reporting of the Spanish press \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/3Oct?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#3Oct\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/KYGhWcSyiL\">pic.twitter.com/KYGhWcSyiL\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/915285165219467265?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In person, however, the peaceful, even joyous nature of this democratic uprising was hard to miss. A spontaneous gathering of young protesters outside Barcelona&#8217;s city hall on Tuesday erupted at times into something more like a party.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Spanish police helicopter hovering over Barcelona&#39;s city hall earlier was probably watching out for trouble, but witnessed joy instead \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/3Oct?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#3Oct\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/UCqOvvYwPV\">pic.twitter.com/UCqOvvYwPV\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Robert Mackey (@RobertMackey) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RobertMackey/status/915289552595628032?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Still, fears that the Spanish government might take further provocative steps to stoke tensions were amplified late on Tuesday when the government chose to have the King of Spain, Felipe VI, deliver \u003ca href=\"https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/10/04/inenglish/1507101494_919786.html\">a strident televised address\u003c/a>, in which he blamed Catalan separatists for provoking the crisis and failed to even mention the police violence.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Felipe Vi, Spanish King, just made a speech on Catalonia without condemning violence and without calling for political dialogue. A Catalan Declaration of Independence is unavoidable.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Aleix Sarri Camargo (@aleixsarri) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/aleixsarri/status/915298477374132230?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;If people thought that he was going to call for dialogue, it didn&#8217;t happen,&#8221; Borja Echevarría, a Spanish journalist who is now the digital editor-in-chief of Univision News in Miami, told The Intercept. &#8220;He backed totally [Prime Minister Mariano] Rajoy&#8217;s position. He condemned Catalan leaders. He didn&#8217;t mention what happened on Sunday, the violence.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The king &#8220;was tough and spoke to those who live in Cataluña or Catalans who feel Spanish,&#8221; Echevarría added. &#8220;He was just speaking to a part of the Catalan population and to Catalan politicians, blaming them. But what happens to those moderates in Cataluña that are fed up of Spanish politicians, and they were not separatists until not so long ago?&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Ramón Lobo, a veteran war correspondent in Madrid, called the king&#8217;s remarks &#8220;disappointing&#8221; and &#8220;very rough,&#8221; in an interview shortly after the broadcast.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>There was no mention at all of dialogue, Lobo pointed out, as if the government was already preparing to invoke Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution, which would permit Spain to suspend the autonomous Catalan government and rule the region directly from Madrid. &#8220;Big mistake,&#8221; Lobo concluded.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Barcelona&#8217;s mayor agreed, calling the speech &#8220;irresponsible and unworthy of a head of state,&#8221; since it offered no solution, made no mention of the wounded and included no appeal for dialogue.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">Ninguna solución. Ninguna mención a los heridos. Ninguna apelación al diálogo. Discurso irresponsable e indigno de un jefe de estado \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/Rey?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Rey\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Ada Colau (@AdaColau) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AdaColau/status/915306712499998720?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Pablo Iglesias, the head of the Podemos party, also denounced the speech, telling the unelected king that, as the head of a parliamentary group representing 5 million Spaniards, he did not spoke for them.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">Como presidente de un grupo parlamentario que representa a más de 5 millones de españoles, le digo al Rey no votado: no en nuestro nombre\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Pablo Iglesias (@Pablo_Iglesias_) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Pablo_Iglesias_/status/915293825232441346?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The king&#8217;s speech was quickly followed by what the Catalans call a cassolada, a form of protest in which dissent is expressed by making a racket, banging on casseroles, pots, and pans.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Cassolada espontània a Sants després del discurs del rei \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/btvnoticies?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@btvnoticies\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/ORtuOlP4g6\">pic.twitter.com/ORtuOlP4g6\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Mercè (@MerceMondelo) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MerceMondelo/status/915292667881369603?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">Cassolada espectacular a Gràcia després del missatge institucional del rei \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/btvnoticies?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@btvnoticies\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/XrqYuQEbf8\">pic.twitter.com/XrqYuQEbf8\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Ainhoa Roca (@ainhoar7) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ainhoar7/status/915293204014096384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The repression of Sunday&#8217;s vote in Catalonia set Spain back 40 years, Albano Dante, a member of the Catalan parliament, observed on Twitter. This speech from the king, he added, set it back another 300 years.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"es\" dir=\"ltr\">El 1-O España retrocedió 40 años. Hoy 300. El Rey Felipe. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/XyDpPEDOTL\">pic.twitter.com/XyDpPEDOTL\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Albano-Dante Fachin (@AlbanoDante76) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AlbanoDante76/status/915293347308347392?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Pro-independence groups mocked the king, with one calling him a &#8220;rat&#8221; imposed by the Franco regime.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"und\" dir=\"ltr\">? A aquesta rata imposada pel franquisme ja fa molt de temps que no li tenim cap mena de por. \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/NiReiNiPor?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#NiReiNiPor\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/GvEhFVKFsW\">pic.twitter.com/GvEhFVKFsW\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Arran #VagaGeneral3O (@Arran_jovent) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Arran_jovent/status/915323713817628672?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Adding to the sense of crisis, the BBC reported that Catalan President Carles Puigdemont saidin \u003ca href=\"http://www.bbc.com/news/av/world-europe-41494090/catalonia-referendum-puigdemont-will-declare-independence-in-matter-of-days\">an interview\u003c/a> recorded earlier on Tuesday that his government would declare independence within days.\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">EXCLUSIVE with Catalan President \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/KRLS?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@KRLS\u003c/a>; Catalan authorities will declare independence from Spain in a matter of days \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/BBCNews?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@BBCNews\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Tom Burridge (@TomBurridgebbc) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TomBurridgebbc/status/915315704110419969?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-03T20:03:01+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-03T16:03:01+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"Catalans Spanish police headquarters in Barcelona as part of a general strike in Catalonia called by Catalan unions on October 3, 2017.Large numbers of Catalans are expected to observe a general strike today to condemn police violence at a banned weekend referendum on independence, as Madrid comes under growing international pressure to resolve its worst political crisis in decades. / AFP PHOTO / LLUIS
