read LLUIS GENE/AFP/Getty Images)","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":700,"path":"wp-content/uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000.jpg","width":1400},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"700","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000.jpg","width":"1400"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/100317_laietana-1507052000-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"SPAIN-CATALONIA-POLITICS-INDEPENDENCE-STRIKE"},"title":"Massive Protests in Catalonia as General Strike Is Observed","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/massive-protests-catalonia-general-strike-observed/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Catalans peacefully expressed their rage in the streets on Tuesday, but their tolerance was severely tested by a provocative speech from the king of Spain.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Massive Protests in Catalonia as General Strike Is Observed","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150231":{"ID":150231,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":59,"brief_bio":"Jon Schwarz is a writer and producer based in Brooklyn.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Jon Schwarz","email":"jon.schwarz@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/tinyrevolution","full_bio":"\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Before joining First Look, Jon Schwarz worked for Michael Moore’s Dog Eat Dog Films and was Research Producer for Moore’s “Capitalism: A Love Story.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">He’s contributed to many publications, including the New Yorker, the New York Times, The Atlantic, the Wall Street Journal, Mother Jones, and Slate, as well as NPR and &#8220;Saturday Night Live.&#8221;\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">In 2003 he collected on a $1,000 bet that Iraq would have no weapons of mass destruction.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/04/Jon-Schwarz_avatar_1429549467-350x350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"jonschwarz","pgp_file":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/04/F0DBCC19.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"7C2A A7C8 D1AF D929 7A04  3C4A 74B5 2358 F0DB CC19","pgp_key":"Jon Schwarz Public Key","twitter":"@tinyrevolution","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/jonschwarz/","user_group":"","user_title":"Senior Writer"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xQHnFa","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"56","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>President Trump arrived\u003c/u> in Puerto Rico on Tuesday and immediately began lauding himself and his administration for their response to Hurricane Maria. But mixed in with the self-congratulation were \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/2017/10/3/16411488/trump-remarks-puerto-rico\">several references\u003c/a> to how much relief efforts were costing.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“Our country has really gone all out,” Trump said. “It&#8217;s not only dangerous, it&#8217;s expensive. But I consider it a great honor.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Trump then explained that Director of the Office of Management and Budget &#8220;Mick Mulvaney is here, and Mick is in charge of a thing called budget. I hate to tell you, Puerto Rico, but you are throwing our budget out of whack. We spent a lot of money on Puerto Rico, and that&#8217;s fine. We saved a lot of lives.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Beyond the gross inappropriateness of “joking” about the money the U.S. government is spending even as American citizens continue to die in Puerto Rico, Trump’s attitude is incredibly bad economics. Moreover, his administration, Mulvaney definitely included, knows this.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Mulvaney let the secret out \u003ca href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/mick-mulvaney-omb-deficits_us_59d3bcf2e4b06226e3f3e34b\">on CNN Sunday\u003c/a> when talking about Trump’s proposed tax cuts:\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote>\u003cp>We need to have new deficits. … We need to have the growth. … If we simply look at [these tax cuts] as being deficit-neutral, you’re never going to get the type of tax reform and tax reductions that you need to get to sustain 3 percent economic growth.\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>This shouldn’t have been remarkable, because by describing federal deficits as a positive good, Mulvaney was essentially saying that the sky is blue. But it was genuinely shocking, because whenever Democrats are in power, the Republican Party unites to chant in unison that the sky is green. And Democrats play along.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>To understand the significance of this, it’s necessary to look back at the past 100 years.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The world learned a counterintuitive but central insight about capitalism during the 20\u003cspan style=\"font-size: 13.3333px\">th\u003c/span> century: \u003cem>It’s just too productive.\u003c/em> It tends to create much more supply than there is effective demand.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>This doesn’t mean that capitalist countries don’t have children who go hungry or people who need to buy a new car but can’t. Far from it. Rather, it means that capitalism is extraordinarily inventive and usually generates the \u003cem>physical ability\u003c/em> to produce that food and those cars &#8212; but not enough customers who can afford to buy it all. Simultaneously, there will be a small number of billionaires at the top with far more money than they could ever spend.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>These frequent gluts of supply are why capitalist economies often fall into slow growth and even long-term recessions and depressions. When there’s more stuff than can be bought, factories fire some of the workers making it, then the workers who were fired are forced to buy less, then the factories fire more people, in an ongoing vicious cycle.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>One of the best weapons against this, as the U.S. and the rest of the world discovered by ending the Great Depression via World War II, is for the government to run deficits by cutting taxes or increasing spending or both. Well-designed deficits will put money in the pocket of people who don’t have much and will spend it.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But even if deficits generally make life better for most people, from the perspective of the 1 percent, they’re politically repellent. A fast-growing economy means low unemployment, which puts more power in the hands of workers and less in the hands of employers. It also may generate higher prices, which reduce the value of most kinds of bonds. (A classic explanation of why we have the ability to choose to create economic booms, and the intense resistance among the rich to their countries making such a choice, is the 1943 article, “\u003ca href=\"http://delong.typepad.com/kalecki43.pdf\">Political Aspects of Full Employment\u003c/a>” by Polish economist Michael Kalecki.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Thus, Republicans pretend to care about deficits during Democratic administrations because they’re desperate to prevent their opponents from benefiting from deficits’ positive effects. Meanwhile, Democratic deficits are often run up with social spending rather than tax cuts, which Republicans oppose because they worry the spending will lead to future tax hikes. (And some just don&#8217;t like social spending, period.) But when the GOP takes power, it immediately discards its rhetoric to try to utilize deficits’ usefulness for themselves.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>For instance, as top GOP conservative Rep. Mark Walker of North Carolina recently explained \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/28/us/politics/trump-tax-cuts-deficit-republicans-congress.html?_r=0\">with admirable frankness\u003c/a>, being against deficits is “a great talking point when you have an administration that’s Democrat-led. … It’s a little different now that Republicans have both houses and the administration.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>This doesn’t mean that the U.S. can afford anything we want. There are physical limits to what countries can produce (although as World War II showed, they’re looser than we may believe). But it’s those physical limits, not abstract numbers on a government ledger, that matter.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Stephanie Kelton, professor of inequality and policy at Stony Brook University, was an adviser to the 2016 Bernie Sanders presidential campaign. She&#8217;s a forceful advocate of this general perspective, known as “\u003ca href=\"https://www.thenation.com/article/the-rock-star-appeal-of-modern-monetary-theory/\">Modern Monetary Theory\u003c/a>,” which says that there are several key measurements to examine to understand how close we are to those limits.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>First, there’s “capacity utilization” &#8212; i.e., how much factories and corporations are producing versus how much they can produce. This graph from the Federal Reserve shows that capacity utilization is 76 percent, a level so low that during the past 50 years it’s usually been reached during recessions. In other words, the U.S. could make far, far more stuff on a moment’s notice.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph1-1507066179.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150393\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph1-1507066179-1024x395.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Then there’s inflation. If we were anywhere near our ability to make things, the government’s spending would be bidding up labor and material, and we’d be seeing a sharp increase in inflation. We’re not.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph2-1507066173.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150392\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph2-1507066173-1024x476.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Then, says Kelton, there’s the U-6 gauge of unemployment. Unlike the U-3 classification that’s generally mentioned in the media, U-6 includes not just people unemployed and actively looking for work, but those who’ve given up looking and part-timers who’d prefer to work more hours. Currently at 8.6 percent, U-6 was almost two percentage points lower during the late 1990s, without any spike in inflation.\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph3-1507066161.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150391\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/fredgraph3-1507066161-1024x476.png\" alt=\"\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\n\u003cp>Taken together, this is a clear snapshot of a country that could easily afford to completely rebuild Puerto Rico, as well as Florida and Houston, and do far, far more besides. The only reason for Trump’s ugly remarks about the cost of keeping Americans alive is that it involves using our nation’s incredible wealth to benefit regular people rather than the ultra-wealthy like himself.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top photo: President Donald Trump takes part in a food and supply distribution at the Cavalry Chapel in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico, on Oct. 3, 2017.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-03T22:27:06+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-03T18:27:06+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The big secret of politics is budget deficits are meaningless. The U.S. could easily afford to rebuild Puerto Rico and far, far more.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/donald-trumps-disgusting-remark-on-puerto-rico-is-more-revealing-than-he-knows/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Medium","slug":"medium"},{"name":"Smart News","slug":"smart-news"},{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"150354,149292,148392,148705","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/we-can-finally-identify-one-of-the-largest-holders-of-puerto-rican-debt/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/puerto-rico-rejects-loan-offers-accusing-hedge-funds-of-trying-to-profit-off-hurricanes/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/u-s-shipping-lobby-letting-foreign-ships-bring-goods-to-puerto-rico-could-endanger-national-security/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/27/puerto-rican-debt-holders-respond-to-catastrophic-hurricane-by-offering-puerto-rico-more-debt/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Trump's disgusting remark on Puerto Rico is more revealing than he knows","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"donald-trumps-disgusting-remark-on-puerto-rico-is-more-revealing-than-he-knows","thumbnail":{"ID":150404,"alt_text":"US President Donald Trump takes part in a food and suplly distribution at the Cavalry Chapel in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico on October 3, 2017.Nearly two weeks after Hurricane Maria thrashed through the US territory, much of the islands remains short of food and without access to power or drinking water. / AFP PHOTO / MANDEL NGAN (Photo credit should read MANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images)","content":"","credit":"Photo: Mandel Ngan/AFP/Getty Images","excerpt":"President Donald Trump takes part in a food and supply distribution at the Cavalry Chapel in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico on Oct. 3, 2017.","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"1392","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026.jpg","width":"2784"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/donald-trump-puerto-rico-hurricane-maria-1507067026-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"WEATHER-US-HURRICANE-PUERTORICO-POLITICS-TRUMP"},"title":"Donald Trump’s Disgusting Remark on Puerto Rico Is More Revealing Than He Knows","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/donald-trumps-disgusting-remark-on-puerto-rico-is-more-revealing-than-he-knows/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The big secret of politics is budget deficits are meaningless. The U.S. could easily afford to rebuild Puerto Rico and far, far more.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Trump's Puerto Rico Remark Is Unintentionally Revealing","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150238":{"ID":150238,"article_length_type":"Long","authors":[{"ID":144088,"brief_bio":"","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Kate Aronoff","email":"karonoff18@gmail.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"Kate Aronoff is a contributor to The Intercept and a writing fellow at In These Times covering climate and American politics ","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/08/headshotKA-copy-1504035322-e1504042247402-440x440.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"kate-aronoff","pgp_file":"","pgp_fingerprint":"","pgp_key":"","twitter":"@katearonoff","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/kate-aronoff/","user_group":"","user_title":""}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xhKKTQ","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"11","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">\u003cu>For bondholders sitting\u003c/u> on Puerto Rican debt, Hurricane Maria may have come just when they needed it, just as a yearslong battle over the fate of the island’s financial future was beginning to turn against them. Or, depending on how the politics shake out, they could see their entire bet go south.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Ahead of Maria, the federally appointed fiscal oversight board now in control of Puerto Rico’s finances had developed a plan that would wipe out 79 percent of the island&#8217;s annual debt payments, taking a massive chunk out of the payday hedge funds had been hoping to land from the island. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">In the wake of the storm, that fight could go one of two ways: Advocates for Puerto Rico are making the case that the devastation means that 79 percent should be ratcheted up all the way to a full debt cancellation. The hedge funds, meanwhile, see an opening to attack the oversight board and reclaim ownership of the process.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">While Congress focuses on the size and shape of the relief package, the battle over the much larger debt &#8212; at least $74 billion &#8212; is being overshadowed. As hedge funds attempt to undermine the board’s legitimacy in the courts, resentment toward the board from a different end of the political spectrum has made the body unpopular for entirely different reasons: It&#8217;s colonial and undemocratic. \u003c/span>The difference between the two? The left wants debt relief for Puerto Ricans. Many bondholders want the opposite.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>President Donald Trump joined the fray Tuesday evening, indicating that he wanted to erase Puerto Rico’s debt. “They owe a lot of money to your friends on Wall Street, and we’re going to have to wipe that out,” Trump said on Fox News. It wasn’t clear from his statements whether he intended a bailout for Puerto Rico or for its creditors. Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-04/trump-suggests-puerto-rico-s-debt-may-need-to-be-wiped-out\">walked back\u003c/a> on Trump’s comments to Fox on Wednesday, apparently under the impression it was the latter. He told CNN, “We are not going to bail them out. We are not going to pay off those debts. We are not going to bail out those bondholders.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">As of now,\u003c/span> though,\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> the decision on how much debt to cancel legally rests with U.S. District Court Judge Laura Taylor Swain, and any formal forgiveness\u003c/span> on the total sum\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> wouldn&#8217;t happen for at least a year. Still, motions in the direction of cancellation could be reflected in an update to Puerto Rico’s current fiscal plan, freeing up millions of dollars for both short and long-term recovery efforts.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“Thousands who lost their homes need urgent shelter, and entire towns are suffering from hunger and dehydration. Inefficiency and the depraved indifference of the Trump administration is rising to the level of criminal negligence,” said Xiomara Caro Diaz, a San Juan resident who is the director of New Organizing Projects at the Center for Popular Democracy. Among the group’s demands is a “complete and irrevocable forgiveness of all Puerto Rican public debt,” alongside a call for a robust relief package and to cut red tape around aid distribution.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Any relief package will come with little assistance from the creditors. \u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/27/puerto-rican-debt-holders-respond-to-catastrophic-hurricane-by-offering-puerto-rico-more-debt/\">\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The Intercept previously surveyed \u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">more than 50 of the island’s known creditors, and none had offered more than thoughts and prayers to the island, and few had even gone that far. David Tepper, the hedge fund manager behind Appaloosa LP, recently made a \u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/puerto-rico-rejects-loan-offers-accusing-hedge-funds-of-trying-to-profit-off-hurricanes/\">\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">$3 million gift to the relief effort, \u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">the lone burst of generosity from creditors to have become publicly known.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">In the meantime, Puerto Rico is still trying to climb out of overlapping crises. As Gov. Ricardo Rosselló said in an interview published Monday by \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">El Nuevo Dia\u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">, his government could run out of funds as early as this month. It currently costs around $70 million a day to run the government, which has around $2 billion in cash on hand. “But let me tell you what $2 billion means when you have zero collection: It’s basically a month government’s payroll, a little bit more,” Rosselló elaborated.\u003c/span>\u003cbr />\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'>\u003cbr />\n\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Gov-Ricado-Rossello-1507067580.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150414\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Gov-Ricado-Rossello-1507067580-1024x772.jpg\" alt=\"20170927, SALINAS, EL GOBERNADOR RICARDO ROSSELLO LLEGA A SALINAS PARA ENTREGAR SUMINISTROS. FOTO: VANESSA SERRA DIAZ (GDA via AP Images)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Gov. Ricardo Rosselló arrives in Salinas, Puerto Rico to distribute supplies to those affected by Hurricane Maria on Sept. 27, 2017.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Vanessa Serra Diaz/GDA/AP\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cbr />\n\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">For the same reasons, the fiscal control board and those paying close attention to Puerto Rico’s financial situation are even more skeptical than they were before the storm that the island can pay back any sizable chunk of its debt. The board met last Friday to reconsider its current fiscal plan for the island in light of storm damage and the revenues likely to be lost as a result, though there are still few details as to what (if anything) was decided. There are also increasing calls for the U.S. government to devote money not just to emergency services but also to general operating expenses, and to help lay the foundation for more resilient infrastructure. A staffer for Puerto Rican-born Rep. Nydia Velázquez, D-N.Y., for instance — one of Congress’s most active members on issues related to the island — told The Intercept that she is requesting that the Treasury extend a line of credit to alleviate Puerto Rico’s liquidity issues.  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Even if the debt is eventually forgiven, the fiscal oversight board will continue to be a presence on the island until the Puerto Rican government maintains a balanced budget for four consecutive years and crafts those budgets in line with the board’s accounting standards. For Puerto Ricans, that could mean austerity measures and a neutered democracy even after the debt is canceled. Yet the hurricane may well have altered the politics around austerity, too, as calls for investment in rebuilding infrastructure could overwhelm the demand for cuts. \u003c/span>With increased attention on Puerto Rico after the storm has also come increased outrage over its economic and political crisis.  VAMOS4PR, a coalition of labor, community, and civil rights groups, is planning rallies in 14 cities today calling for “immediate and sufficient aid to RELIEVE AND REBUILD Puerto Rico,” according to a press release, and to zero-out the debt. The event in New York starts just blocks from Swain’s office.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> The continued presence of the board, however, also means its privatization agenda could continue to play out long after Puerto Rico’s debts are off the books. (The firm handling the oversight board’s communications declined to comment for this story.)\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The trade-off between at least some level of debt forgiveness and undemocratic austerity has been at the core of tensions over the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA), which created the oversight board and allows for more expansive bankruptcy proceedings than other U.S. municipalities have access to. (For\u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2015-12-03/bankruptcy-was-option-for-puerto-rico-before-congress-goof\"> \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">reasons\u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> that remain unknown, Puerto Rico hasn’t been able to declare Chapter 9 bankruptcy like other struggling cities and states since 1984.) When it was passed amid protests last summer, PROMESA put a moratorium on most debt payments that has been in place ever since, though Rosselló has attempted to repay portions of it. Since it was installed, the board has begun outlining and implementing deep cuts to the commonwealth’s public sphere.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">In some ways, the oversight board acts as a kind of mediator between bondholders and the government and people of Puerto Rico, preempting some of the most draconian terms built into bond repayment contracts, now on hold under PROMESA and as the bankruptcy-like negotiations the bill outlines proceed in the courts. One such provision would have mandated that the government pay back general obligation bonds \u003c/span>\u003ci>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">before \u003c/span>\u003c/i>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">providing essential services to its citizens. Though repayment is still on hold, different classes of bondholders are now locked in a legal dispute about which of them is entitled to the revenue from the island’s sales tax, currently set at 11.5 percent. A board-rejected debt restructuring agreement would have mandated that rates automatically rise when demand goes down to satisfy repayment, meaning that, thanks to PROMESA, fewer customers would have to pay drastically higher bills.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Though the board does provide a considerable buffer between bondholders and Puerto Rico, for many residents the body represents just the most blatant iteration yet of the United States’s colonial relationship to the island, which has officially been a U.S. commonwealth since 1952. The arrangement usurps any semblance of local democracy and wrests virtually all decision-making power from the people and to a body that’s only required to have one Puerto Rican member.\u003c/span>\u003cbr />\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed large-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'>\u003cbr />\n\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/PR-fiscal-oversight-board-1507134319.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150632\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/PR-fiscal-oversight-board-1507134319-1024x683.jpg\" alt=\"31 DE MARZO 2017SAN JUAN, PUERTO RICO. SE REUNE LA JUNTA DE SUPERVISION FISCAL EN EL CENTRO DE CONVENCIOSNES PEDRO ROSSELLO. EN LA FOTO ANA J. MATOSANTOS, JOSE B. CARRION III Y DAVID SKEEL.FOTO: GERALD LOPEZ-CEPERO (GDA via AP Images)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">Ana Matosantos, José B. Carrión III, and David Skeel of Puerto Rico’s fiscal oversight board hold a meeting at the Pedro Rosselló convention center in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on March 31, 2017.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Gerald Lopez-Cepero/GDA/El Nuevo Dia/AP\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cbr />\n\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">\u003cu>Creditors oppose the\u003c/u> board for very different reasons. Sensing at least some level of forgiveness on the horizon — and generally frustrated that the board has moved debt negotiations to the courts so quickly — creditors have launched a series of lawsuits aimed at delegitimizing the board and winning more of their money back. \u003c/span>Cate Long, who leads a research service for Puerto Rico bondholders and wrote a recent report for Congress on the status of PROMESA, has been circulating a list of recommendations to lawmakers in Washington in Irma and Maria’s wake, calling for Congress to “consider a tax credit for U.S. multinationals” and the “militarization of the island to provide short to medium [term] security.” The list further suggests that “Congress &#8230; proactively request that President Trump remove &#8230; and replace the [board] with an appointed administrator who has broad authority to execute contracts, coordinate with federal agencies and oversee reconstruction.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In an email to The Intercept, Long wrote, “[The oversight board] is seven volunteers who live all over the US and cannot coordinate easily with all the federal agencies, Congress and White House. They are not prepared for the magnitude of rebuilding Puerto.” The U.S. military, she added, “needs to supplement the 15,000 Puerto Rican police officers to maintain law and order.” Long also said she would be recommending to Congress that U.S. multinationals operating in Puerto Rico be able to write down 100 percent of capital expenditures “required to rebuild after Maria or build new factories within a 2-3 year window.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Perhaps the biggest existential threat to the control board\u003cstrong>, \u003c/strong>which the document above references, is a suit launched by hedge fund bondholder Aurelius Capital Management. Filed in August, the Aurelius suit alleges that the board bypassed the Constitution’s “appointments clause,” a statute mandating that principal officers of the federal government be appointed by the president and then approved by the Senate. Should the case gain traction, it could put debt repayment back on creditors’ terms.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The creditors have good reason to be nervous. “At this point,” Jubilee USA Executive Director Eric LeCompte says, “no investor in Puerto Rico’s debt should be thinking that they will get any return in the near future.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Controversially, Jubilee USA supported PROMESA in the lead-up to its passage last summer, causing tension between the group and other civil society organizations aligned against the measure. As they have in similar kinds of debt negotiations, \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Jubilee USA is \u003c/span>now calling for the cancellation with complete restructuring\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> of Puerto Rico’s debt, and has been tracking developments there and in Washington closely.\u003c/span>\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“Now that the hurricanes have happened, and we understand the level of devastation that has taken place on the island, the bankruptcy process that’s in place under Swain now has to take into account this new reality,” LeCompte tells me. “For Puerto Rico, that means a much bigger haircut than we were looking at beforehand.&#8221; \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">According to LeCompte, there are a couple of ways that forgiveness or cancellation could play out. Beyond outright forgiveness, one idea that’s been popular even among some bondholders is to repackage any remaining debt\u003c/span> into a bond that would only be repaid\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> once Puerto Rico crosses a certain threshold of GDP growth. A less likely scenario — though one LeCompte advised to look out for\u003c/span>\u003cb>, \u003c/b>and Trump himself may have suggested \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">— could see Congress pass a bail-out for bondholders, pouring federal funds into recouping their losses. Another recourse for creditors, he tells me, “is trying to get Congress to amend or change PROMESA legislation to disempower the bankruptcy process.” \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">LeCompte, though, says signals now are stronger than they’ve ever been for cancellation or deep forgiveness — thanks both to Maria’s devastation and to active pressure from Puerto Rican organizers there and in the diaspora. “In a financial crisis, you’re killing people slowly,” he says, “When these hurricanes hit — when there’s no electricity and no power — you’re watching people get killed quickly.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Correction: Oct. 4, 2017, 2:11 p.m.\u003c/strong>\u003cbr />\n\u003cem>An earlier version of this story incorrectly stated that Puerto Rico has officially been a U.S. commonwealth since 1898. Puerto Rico became a commonwealth in 1952. \u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top photo: Irma Maldanado stands with Sussury her parrot and her dog in what is left of her home that was destroyed when Hurricane Maria passed through on Sept. 27, 2017 in Corozal, Puerto Rico.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-04T18:02:23+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-04T14:02:23+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"In Hurricane Maria's aftermath, advocates for Puerto Rico are making the case for full debt cancellation — which is the last thing hedge funds want.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"150231,150354,149292,148392","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/donald-trumps-disgusting-remark-on-puerto-rico-is-more-revealing-than-he-knows/","https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/we-can-finally-identify-one-of-the-largest-holders-of-puerto-rican-debt/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/puerto-rico-rejects-loan-offers-accusing-hedge-funds-of-trying-to-profit-off-hurricanes/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/u-s-shipping-lobby-letting-foreign-ships-bring-goods-to-puerto-rico-could-endanger-national-security/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Puerto Puerto Rico experienced widespread damage including most of the electrical, gas and water grid as well as agriculture after Hurricane Maria, a category 4 hurricane, passed through. Click \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/podcasts/#faq\">here\u003c/a>.\u003c/u>\u003c/p>\n\n\u003c!-- iframe plugin v.2.9 wordpress.org/plugins/iframe/ --\>\n\u003ciframe frameborder=\"no\" height=\"200\" scrolling=\"no\" src=\"https://player.megaphone.fm/PPY1463981678?light=true\" width=\"100%\" class=\"iframe-class\">\u003c/iframe>\n\n\u003cp>&nbsp;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan class=\"s1\">\u003cu>The Coalition of\u003c/u> the Killing — gun lobbyists, politicians, and weapons manufacturers — are the only beneficiaries of the massacre in Las Vegas. This week on Intercepted, Jeremy analyzes the way we talk about mass shootings and the role race plays, and he speaks with Dave Cullen, author of a book on the Columbine school shooting. Trump threw rolls of paper towels at hurricane survivors in Puerto Rico and gave himself an A+ for his (lack of a) response to the disaster. Alynda Segarra of Hurray for the Riff Raff shares stories about exploring her Puerto Rican roots and performs what turned out to be prescient songs from her new album, The Navigator. Former U.S. Army Ranger Rory Fanning talks about how his slain comrade, former NFL star-turned soldier Pat Tillman, supported his decision to become a conscientious objector. And he responds to Trump using Tillman’s name to defend his call for an NFL boycott. Historian Jeanne Theoharis \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"s2\">digs deep into the manufactured and sanitized mythology used by politicians to misuse the legacies of Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, and the civil rights movement. And Donald Trump takes his love of guns into the Twilight Zone.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class=\"promote-embed\" data-alert=\"support-intercepted\">\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>Transcript Coalition of the Killing — gun lobbyists, politicians, and weapons manufacturers — are the only beneficiaries of the massacre in Las Vegas.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/intercepted-podcast-guns-before-country/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Medium","slug":"medium"},{"name":"Smart News","slug":"smart-news"},{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"","related_post_permalinks":"","series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"New @Intercepted: Guns before country","show_donations_promo":false,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"intercepted-podcast-guns-before-country","thumbnail":{"ID":150483,"alt_text":"","content":"","credit":"Photos: Public Domain. Illustration: Elise Swain for The Intercept.","excerpt":"","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"720","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957.jpg","width":"1440"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Episode-30_Guns-Before-Country-1507084957"},"title":"Intercepted Podcast: Guns Before Country","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/intercepted-podcast-guns-before-country/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150318":{"ID":150318,"article_length_type":"Long","authors":[{"ID":160,"brief_bio":"Kim Zetter is an award-winning investigative journalist who has been covering privacy, computer security and national security for more than a decade. She is also author of the book &lt;a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Countdown-Zero-Day-Stuxnet-Digital/dp/0770436196\"&gt;Countdown to Zero Day: Stuxnet and the Launch of the World's First Digital Weapon&lt;/a&gt;, which tells the story of a virus/worm created by the US and Israel to sabotage Iran's nuclear program.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Kim Zetter","email":"kkzetter@gmail.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Kim Zetter is an award-winning investigative journalist who has been covering privacy, computer security and national security for more than a decade. She is also author of the book \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Countdown-Zero-Day-Stuxnet-Digital/dp/0770436196\">Countdown to Zero Day: Stuxnet and the Launch of the World&#8217;s First Digital Weapon\u003c/a>, which tells the story of a virus/worm created by the US and Israel to sabotage Iran&#8217;s nuclear program.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-includes/images/blank.gif","language":true,"nicename":"kimzetter","pgp_file":"","pgp_fingerprint":"","pgp_key":"","twitter":"@kimzetter","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/kimzetter/","user_group":"","user_title":""}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2hL0Y5J","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"29","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp class=\"gmail-p1\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">\u003cu>The growing propensity\u003c/u> of government hackers to reuse code and computers from rival nations is undermining the integrity of hacking investigations and calling into question how online attacks are attributed, according to researchers from Kaspersky Lab.\u003cbr />\n\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p1\">In a paper set for release today \u003ca href=\"https://www.virusbulletin.com/conference/vb2017/abstracts/walking-your-enemys-shadow-when-fourth-party-collection-becomes-attribution-hell/\">at the Virus Bulletin digital security conference in Madrid\u003c/a>, the researchers highlight cases in which they&#8217;ve seen hackers acting on behalf of nation-states stealing tools and hijacking infrastructure previously used by hackers of other nation-states. Investigators need to watch out for signs of this or risk tracing attacks to the wrong perpetrators, the researchers said.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Threat researchers have built an industry on identifying and profiling hacking groups in order to understand their methods, anticipate future moves, and develop methods for battling them. They often attribute attacks by &#8220;clustering&#8221; malicious files, IP addresses, and servers that get reused across hacking operations, knowing that threat actors use the same code and infrastructure repeatedly to save time and effort. So when researchers see the same encryption algorithms and digital certificates reused in various attacks, for example, they tend to assume the attacks were perpetrated by the same group. But that&#8217;s not necessarily the case.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Getting this information right is particularly important because the investigations of security companies are increasingly playing a role in government attribution of hacking attacks. The attacks last year on the Democratic National Committee, for example, were attributed to hacking groups associated with Russian intelligence based in part on analysis done by the private security firm CrowdStrike, which found that tools and techniques used in the DNC network matched those used in previous attacks attributed to Russian intelligence groups.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Although the Kaspersky researchers believe the DNC attribution is correct, they say researchers need to be more cautious about assuming that when the same tools and techniques are being used, the same actors are using them.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Intelligence agencies and military hackers are uniquely positioned to trick researchers through code and tool reuse because of something they do called fourth-party collection. \u003cspan class=\"gmail-m_-7561834827004203066gmail-m_2855357713316683478gmail-m_4030615772783168763gmail-s1\">Fourth-party collection can encompass a number of activities, including\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-m_-7561834827004203066gmail-m_2855357713316683478gmail-m_4030615772783168763gmail-m_-4064159956354974197m_-7676071942573605027gmail-s1\"> hacking the machine of a victim\u003c/span> that other hackers have already breached and collecting intelligence about the hackers on that machine by stealing their tools.\u003cspan class=\"gmail-m_-7561834827004203066gmail-m_2855357713316683478gmail-Apple-converted-space\"> \u003c/span> It can also involve hacking the servers the hackers use to launch their assaults. These machines sometimes store the arsenal of malicious tools and even source code that the attackers use for their attacks. Once the other group&#8217;s tools and source code are stolen, it&#8217;s easy to go a step further and reuse them.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;Agency A could steal another agency&#8217;s source code and leverage it as their own. Clustering and attribution in this case begin to fray,&#8221; wrote Juan Andrés Guerrero-Saade, principal security researcher with Kaspersky, and his colleague, Costin Raiu, who leads Kaspersky&#8217;s global research and analysis team.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;[O]ur point in the paper was: This is what it would look like [if someone were to do a false-flag operation] … and these are the cases where we&#8217;ve seen people trying and failing,&#8221; said Guerrero-Saade.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">The recent WannaCry ransomware outbreak is an obvious example of malware theft and reuse. Last year, a mysterious group known as the Shadow Brokers stole a cache of hacking tools that belonged to the National Security Agency and posted them online months later. One of the tools — a so-called zero-day exploit, targeting a previously unknown vulnerability — was repurposed by the hackers behind WannaCry to spread their attack. In this case, it was easy to make a connection between the theft of the NSA code and its reuse with WannaCry, because the original theft was well-publicized. But other cases of theft and reuse won&#8217;t likely be so obvious, leaving researchers in the dark about who is really conducting an attack.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">&#8220;[I]f a superpower … were to break fully into, let&#8217;s say, the DarkHotel group tomorrow and steal all of their code and have access to all of their [command-and-control infrastructure], we&#8217;re not going to find out about that monumental event,&#8221; \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s2\">Guerrero-Saade told The Intercept, referring to a hacker group that has conducted a series \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/2014/11/darkhotel-malware/\">of sophisticated attacks against guests in luxury hotels\u003c/a>.\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">&#8220;At that point, they&#8217;re in a position to mimic those operations to a T … without anyone knowing.&#8221;\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Screen-Shot-2017-10-03-at-12.18.51-PM-1507065392.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150385\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Screen-Shot-2017-10-03-at-12.18.51-PM-1507065392-1024x560.jpg\" alt=\"Screen-Shot-2017-10-03-at-12.18.51-PM-1507065392\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Juan Andrés Guerrero-Saade, right, principal security researcher at Kaspersky, talks about false-flag operations at the Virus Bulletin conference in Denver last year.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Screenshot: Virus Bulletin YouTube\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3 class=\"gmail-p1\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">Spying on Spies\u003c/span>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p1\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">\u003cu>It&#8217;s no secret\u003c/u> that spies spy on spies. Documents provided by NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden \u003ca href=\"http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/new-snowden-docs-indicate-scope-of-nsa-preparations-for-cyber-battle-a-1013409-2.html\">describe\u003c/a> how the agency and its spying partners routinely inspect the machines of victims they hack to see if other hackers are lurking inside. The NSA has a custom anti-virus-like tool called \u003ca href=\"https://www.eff.org/files/2015/01/23/20150117-speigel-csec_document_about_the_recognition_of_trojans_and_other_network_based_anomaly_.pdf\">ReplicantFarm\u003c/a> that it deploys on systems it hacks to check for the presence of other known actors. The agency does this to ensure that the tools of other actors won&#8217;t interfere with its own operations in the machine, and to study the tools and methods of these actors to inform both offensive operations and its defense of U.S. government networks. The NSA will grab these tools and reverse-engineer them — sometimes copying clever techniques for use in its own operations.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Though copying techniques is common for the NSA, two former NSA hackers tell The Intercept they never saw the agency reuse actual code during their time there and say they doubt the agency would conduct a false-flag operation.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p6\">&#8220;When we catch foreign-actor tools, we&#8217;ll steal the techniques themselves,&#8221; one of the sources told The Intercept. But &#8220;there are a host of issues when you falsely attribute.\u003cspan class=\"gmail-Apple-converted-space\"> &#8230;\u003c/span> You could start a war that way. It&#8217;s probably more prevalent in other countries, but in the U.S. &#8230; the goal is usually to be not attributed, not falsely attributed.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p6\">He said if any U.S. government entity conducts false-flag operations, it would likely be the CIA.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>An ex-CIA official told The Intercept that his former employer does engage in a form of cyber false-flag operations to hide its identity, but not to throw blame on someone else.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">Guerrero-Saade believes the NSA and its partner countries in the &#8220;Five Eyes&#8221; alliance of the U.S., the U.K., Canada, Australia, and New Zealand are likely not the problem when it comes to code and infrastructure reuse for false-flag operations.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p8\">&#8220;The Five Eyes in general is restrained,&#8221; he said. &#8220;[But] we all know that the Chinese groups, the presumably Israeli groups, even the [Russian-speaking] groups, are willing to do whatever. The Israeli groups are &#8230; ballsy to the extreme.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3 class=\"gmail-p8\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-Apple-converted-space\">False Flags in the Wild\u003cbr />\n\u003c/span>\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p10\">\u003cu>The Kaspersky researchers\u003c/u> have seen several examples in the wild where the infrastructure of one nation-state threat actor has been compromised by another. One example involved a backdoor that had been installed on a staging and relay server (used for transmitting stolen data) used by a nation-state group, known as NetTraveler. Kaspersky doesn&#8217;t know who installed the backdoor, but it likely had been installed to monitor the group or steal its tools and the data NetTraveler had stolen from victims.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">Another case involved one threat actor hijacking another&#8217;s infrastructure to secretly launch its own attacks. DarkHotel — believed to be a South Korean operation — routinely compromises websites to launch attacks against Chinese targets. One of these compromised sites turned out to be hosting exploit scripts apparently belonging to another group, which Kaspersky calls ScarCruft. This group used the site to then launch its own attacks against Russian, Chinese, and South Korean targets.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p6\">In yet another case, Kaspersky researchers found a trojan backdoor called Decafett that appeared to be tied to the Lazarus and BlueNoroff groups  —  both believed to be connected to North Korea — while also using an obscure and unusual Dynamic DNS provider that previously had only been used by the DarkHotel group.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p6\">And a mysterious hacking group known as TigerMilk used a digital certificate in attacks on the Peruvian military and government institutions that had famously been used in the Stuxnet assault on Iran&#8217;s nuclear program. The authors of Stuxnet, believed to be the NSA and Israeli intelligence, had signed their malicious code with a digital certificate stolen from a company in Taiwan to trick the machines in Iran into thinking their malicious files were legitimate software from this company.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p6\">TigerMilk used the same certificate to sign its malicious files, but it did so long after the certificate had gained infamy in the Stuxnet attack and long after the certificate had been revoked and made invalid. Because an invalid certificate is of little use to attackers to help them get malicious code on to a machine, the Kaspersky researchers surmised that the only reason TigerMilk used it in their attacks was &#8220;to fool incident responders and researchers into casting blame on the notorious Stuxnet team.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p11\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">It might seem that all attribution becomes suspect if hacking groups steal and reuse the tools of adversaries in order to cast suspicion on them. But the Kaspersky researchers said that true false-flag operations are rare and difficult to pull off. All of these examples they uncovered involved fairly unsophisticated attempts to confuse researchers. To effectively pin an attack on another player, a hacking team has to convincingly copy or mimic \u003ci>all\u003c/i> of the other group&#8217;s \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s2\">tactics, techniques, and procedures\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">, not just some of them. Make one mistake and the illusion can collapse.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p4\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">&#8220;[I]n order to claim an amazing, true … false-flag operation where you genuinely embodied somebody else in every possible way,\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s2\"> y\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">ou have to know how they function in every possible way … how they act when they&#8217;re in the victim boxes, [you need to use] the source code and the payloads and the same encryption, the same command-and-control infrastructure — because any anomalies are the things we latch onto and say, OK that doesn&#8217;t look right,&#8221; said \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s2\">Guerrero-Saade\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\"> \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-p12\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s2\">Guerrero-Saade\u003c/span> pointed to a recent case in which the research community was tracking what appeared to be a previously unknown Russian-speaking nation-state group. For six to eight months, researchers watched the group carefully and suspected it might actually be a well-known Russian-speaking group named Turla — except the code and infrastructure the group used was very different from Turla&#8217;s. The researchers were almost ready to conclude that it was in fact a completely new and different group, until the attackers slipped up and used one of Turla&#8217;s old and well-known tools. Instead of an entirely new Russian-speaking attack group, the researchers concluded that it was simply Turla using a batch of new tools in an attempt to obscure its identity and activity. The incident provides a good illustration for why threat researchers need to be patient and take their time when doing attribution, since hasty work can lead to false conclusions.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"gmail-s1\">\u003cspan class=\"gmail-s1\">Guerrero-Saade said that in talking about code reuse and false-flag operations, he and Raiu aren&#8217;t trying to cast doubt on every investigation that occurs. He thinks false flags are rare and that most attribution that threat researchers do is accurate. \u003c/span>But researchers need to rethink the limitations and parameters of what they can know for sure, &#8220;so that we know when we&#8217;re faltering and so that we know when we&#8217;re being tricked and so we can admit when we cannot know. There \u003ci>are\u003c/i> situations when we cannot know.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-04T10:00:58+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-04T06:00:58+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"Researchers call into question how online attacks are attributed, as hackers increasingly steal tools from one another, obscuring their identities.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/masquerading-hackers-are-forcing-a-rethink-of-how-attacks-are-traced/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Medium","slug":"medium"},{"name":"Smart News","slug":"smart-news"},{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"116523,8282,131302,138888","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/03/10/government-zero-days-7-years/","https://theintercept.com/2014/11/12/stuxnet/","https://theintercept.com/2017/06/05/top-secret-nsa-report-details-russian-hacking-effort-days-before-2016-election/","https://theintercept.com/2017/08/02/white-house-says-russias-hackers-are-too-good-to-be-caught-but-nsa-partner-called-them-morons/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Masquerading hackers are forcing a rethink of how attacks are traced","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"masquerading-hackers-are-forcing-a-rethink-of-how-attacks-are-traced","thumbnail":{"ID":150565,"alt_text":"","content":"","credit":"Illustration: The Intercept","excerpt":"","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"720","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062.jpg","width":"1440"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-e1507137636310-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"final-Hacker-kim-zetter-1507127062"},"title":"Masquerading Hackers Are Forcing a Rethink of How Attacks Are Traced","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/masquerading-hackers-are-forcing-a-rethink-of-how-attacks-are-traced/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Hacker-4-1507132664.jpg","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Researchers call into question how online attacks are attributed, as hackers increasingly steal tools from one another, obscuring their identities.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Masquerading Hackers Can Throw Off Attack Investigations","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150331":{"ID":150331,"article_length_type":"Short","authors":[{"ID":96,"brief_bio":"Zaid Jilani is a journalist who hails from Atlanta, Georgia.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Zaid Jilani","email":"zaid.jilani@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=4944406","full_bio":"\u003cp>Zaid Jilani is a journalist who hails from Atlanta, Georgia. He has previously worked as a reporter-blogger for ThinkProgress, United Republic, the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, and Alternet.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>He graduated from the University of Georgia in 2009 with a Bachelor of Arts in international affairs and received his master&#8217;s in public administration from Syracuse University in 2014.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/12/ZJ-1.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"zaidjilani","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/12/Zaid-Jilani.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"8532 3EB2 AA79 3831 6508  7D20 66FA 341D F8F2 D1F1","pgp_key":"Zaid Jilani Public Key","twitter":"@ZaidJilani","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/zaidjilani/","user_group":"","user_title":"Reporter"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2hKm7gy","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"48","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>Birmingham&#8217;s Mayor William\u003c/u> Bell, first elected in 2010, was supposed to have an easy re-election. A poll released in early August found that \u003ca href=\"http://www.wbrc.com/story/36025927/exclusive-poll-indicates-bell-in-strong-position-to-win-re-election\">57 percent of his city&#8217;s residents\u003c/a> thought he was doing an &#8220;excellent&#8221; or &#8220;good&#8221; job.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But populist challenger Randall Woodfin, a 36-year-old former board of education president endorsed by the Bernie Sanders-backed campaign group Our Revolution, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/08/23/populist-challenger-stuns-in-birmingham-mayoral-election-will-go-to-runoff/\">topped Bell\u003c/a> in the first round of voting in August. On Tuesday night, Woodfin finished the job in the runoff, stunning Alabama and winning the mayor&#8217;s race comfortably — \u003ca href=\"http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2017/10/people_want_change.html\">Woodfin defeated Bell\u003c/a> with 58 percent of the vote.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;We sent nearly 8,000 get-out-the-vote text messages to supporters and sent over 70 volunteers to his campaign,&#8221; Diane May, communications director for Our Revolution, told The Intercept about the group&#8217;s support for the candidate leading up to the first round. In advance of the runoff, they made over 1,000 calls and sent 11,000 text messages to voters. Sanders himself \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MatthewHinshaw/status/915381437507014657\">phoned in robocalls for Woodfin.\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Woodfin campaign&#8217;s director of field operations, activist Daniel Deriso, was an \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Daniel_Deriso/status/915386936860299265\">alum\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/danielbderiso/\">of Sanders&#8217;s 2016 campaign\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Working Families Party, a national progressive organization that was founded in New York but has since expanded nationwide, also played a role in Woodfin’s election. One hundred and twenty-five WFP volunteers contacted 22,000 voters by text and phone, helping push Woodfin over the top. “Randall Woodfin ran on the idea that the people of Birmingham have a right to demand a government that truly works for all its people, and that a city can provide opportunity and lift up those who’ve been left behind,” Joe Dinkin, national spokesperson for the WFP, said in a statement. “Woodfin is part of a wave of local candidates around the nation who are running on bold, transformative, progressive visions and winning.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Woodfin&#8217;s platform is, by itself, far from radical in post-2016 Democratic politics. He seeks to make community college free for students who graduate from Birmingham&#8217;s high schools. He wants to expand pre-K, and invest in public transit and job training. Woodfin-\u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/even-in-red-states-liberal-candidates-are-climbing-into-power-in-the-nations-cities/2017/08/20/a9deac66-850f-11e7-b359-15a3617c767b_story.html?utm_term=.3ae2a920ff56\">backed Democrat Hillary Clinton\u003c/a> in the 2016 primary, making the Our Revolution backing something of a wound-healing exercise.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>He is also looking to boost the city&#8217;s police force; Birmingham has the \u003ca href=\"http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2015/09/4_alabama_cities_in_fbis_top_1.html\">seventh-highest homicide rate\u003c/a> of cities of over 100,000 people. He had his own personal connection to the city&#8217;s sky-high crime: His nephew was \u003ca href=\"http://inthesetimes.com/article/20440/woodfin-political-revolution-mayor-birmingham-election\">shot and killed\u003c/a> during the course of the campaign. The boy’s father, Woodfin’s older brother, was killed in a shooting five years before that.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But Woodfin&#8217;s campaign did not take place in a vacuum. His election comes just months after Jackson, Mississippi &#8212; the state&#8217;s largest city &#8212; elected Chokwe Lumumba Jr., a young populist who has vowed to make it the &#8220;\u003ca href=\"http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2017/06/12/lumumba-jackson-most-radical-city/387058001/\">most radical city on the planet\u003c/a>.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In November, Atlanta&#8217;s voters will go to the polls to choose the next mayor. One of the candidates, former state Senate Democratic whip Vincent Fort &#8212; \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/18/atlanta-mayor-vincent-fort-bernie-sanders/\">a longtime foe of Wall Street and the city&#8217;s Democratic establishment\u003c/a> &#8212; is also being backed by Our Revolution, as well as Sanders. Although the 12-candidate nonpartisan race makes the results difficult to predict, Fort&#8217;s impact on the race can be seen in the changing behavior of the city council &#8212; it recently voted to raise the wages of city workers to $15 an hour and decriminalize small amounts of marijuana, both causes Fort had worked towards for years.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Should Fort succeed, the largest cities in Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia will be run by mayors running from anti-establishment to downright radical &#8212; all within the span of six months of elections.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Update: Oct. 4, 2017, 11:25 a.m.\u003c/strong>\u003cbr />\n\u003cem>This article was updated with the final election results, as well as a statement from the Working Families Party.\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top photo: Birmingham mayoral candidate Randall Woodfin speaks during a meeting of the Downtown Democrats at the Harbert Center in Birmingham, Ala., Sept. 8, 2017.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-04T02:22:43+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-03T22:22:43+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"Randall Woodfin defeated the incumbent mayor of Birmingham, a blow to the establishment and a win for Our Revolution, Bernie Sanders's campaign group.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured ","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"1000","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760.jpg","width":"2000"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-e1507067789952-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Woodfin-Campaign-Birmingham-1507067760-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"MAYORAL CANDIDATES"},"title":"Populists Are on the March in the South: Bernie-Backed Insurgent Randall Woodfin Defeats Birmingham’s Incumbent Mayor","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/populists-are-on-the-march-in-the-south-bernie-backed-insurgent-randall-woodfin-defeats-birminghams-incumbent-mayor/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"Randall
