Birmingham's Incumbent Mayor","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150338":{"ID":150338,"article_length_type":"Short","authors":[{"ID":98,"brief_bio":"Alex Emmons is a reporter covering national security, foreign affairs, human rights, and politics.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Alex Emmons","email":"alex.emmons@theintercept.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Alex Emmons is a reporter covering national security, foreign affairs, human rights, and politics. Prior to joining The Intercept, he worked for Amnesty International and the ACLU on their campaigns against targeted killing, mass surveillance, and Guantánamo Bay.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/01/alex-emmons-v3.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"alex-emmons","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/06/AlexEmmonsPublicKey.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"EF17 7843 95CD 8335 EAF7  605A AA92 4516 F6DC EAF5","pgp_key":"Alex Emmons Public Key","twitter":"@AlexanderEmmons","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/alex-emmons/","user_group":"","user_title":"Reporter"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xWaVD0","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"31","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>President Donald Trump&#8217;s\u003c/u> administration is facing strong backlash from civil rights groups after voting against a U.N. resolution that condemns using the death penalty to punish &#8220;consensual same-sex relations.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The U.N. Human Rights Council approved the measure on Friday with a 27-13 vote, with seven countries abstaining. The United States, led by Ambassador Nikki Haley, voted for an amendment to the resolution that said the death penalty was not necessarily a human rights violation, and voted against \u003ca href=\"http://ilga.org/downloads/HRC36_death_penalty_voting_resolution.pdf\">amendments\u003c/a> urging countries to stop using experimental drugs in executions.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Human Rights Campaign \u003ca href=\"https://www.hrc.org/blog/trump-admin-votes-against-resolution-condemning-death-penalty-for-same-sex\">called\u003c/a> the vote &#8220;beyond disgraceful,&#8221; and former Obama National Security Adviser Susan Rice took aim at Trump:\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Shame on US!  I was proud to lead U.S. efforts at UN to protect LGBTQ people, back in the day when America stood for human rights for all ?? \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/3Y403bP7Wh\">https://t.co/3Y403bP7Wh\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Susan Rice (@AmbassadorRice) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AmbassadorRice/status/915265109768982528?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The Trump administration&#8217;s vote is nothing new &#8212; presidents from both parties have long objected to U.N. resolutions critical of capital punishment. In December 2016, for example &#8212; in the final weeks of Obama&#8217;s presidency &#8212; the U.S. voted against a \u003ca href=\"http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/71/187\">resolution\u003c/a> urging states not to execute minors, pregnant women, and those with intellectual disabilities.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>While last week&#8217;s vote is not evidence of any significant policy change, it does show what kind of company the U.S. keeps among nations that support the death penalty. Twelve other countries joined the United States in voting against the resolution, including Egypt, which \u003ca href=\"https://www.deathpenaltyworldwide.org/country-search-post.cfm?country=Egypt\">executes political dissidents\u003c/a>, Ethiopia, which is \u003ca href=\"http://www.newsweek.com/ethiopias-war-homosexuals-224457\">considering the death penalty\u003c/a> for same-sex activity, and Saudi Arabia, which, in 2015, \u003ca href=\"http://www.newsweek.com/2014/10/24/when-it-comes-beheadings-isis-has-nothing-over-saudi-arabia-277385.html\">beheaded more people than the Islamic State\u003c/a> .\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>A 2014 \u003ca href=\"https://www.amnestyusa.org/files/act500012014en.pdf\">report\u003c/a> by Amnesty International found that even though the death penalty in on the books in one-third of the world&#8217;s countries, only nine countries have regularly used it in past years &#8212; including Iran, Sudan, China, and North Korea. In other words, when the United States defends the death penalty, it defends the practice of some of the world’s worst human rights violators.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The U.S. Mission to the U.N. did not return a request for comment from The Intercept.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top Photo: Nikki Haley, U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, looks on during an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council at United Nations headquarters, July 5, 2017 in New York City.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-03T22:34:46+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-03T18:34:46+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The United Nations floated a resolution condemning the use of the death penalty to punish same-sex relations. The Trump administration voted \"no.\"","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/the-u-s-voted-against-a-u-n-resolution-condemning-death-penalty-for-lgbtq-people/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":[{"name":"Medium","slug":"medium"},{"name":"Smart News","slug":"smart-news"},{"name":"Spoken Layer","slug":"spoken-layer"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"147396,146909","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/09/25/texas-dna-testing-larry-swearingen-execution/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/19/gay-ghana-asylum-us-immigration-ice-deportation/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"The U.S. voted against a U.N. resolution condemning the death penalty for LGBTQ people","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"the-u-s-voted-against-a-u-n-resolution-condemning-death-penalty-for-lgbtq-people","thumbnail":{"ID":150412,"alt_text":"NEW YORK, NY - JULY 5: Nikki Haley, United States ambassador to the United Nations, looks on during an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council at United Nations headquarters, July 5, 2017 in New York City.  The United States requested an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council after North Korea tested an intercontinental ballistic missile earlier this week. (Photo by Drew Angerer/Getty Images)","content":"","credit":"Photo: Drew Angerer/Getty Images","excerpt":"Nikki Haley, United States ambassador to the United Nations, looks on during an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council at United Nations headquarters, July 5, 2017 in New York City.  ","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"1987","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327.jpg","width":"3973"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-e1507067388552-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Nikki-haley-un-1507067327-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"UN Holds Emergency Security Council Meeting After North Korea Missile Launch"},"title":"The U.S. Voted Against a U.N. Resolution Condemning Death Penalty for LGBTQ People","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/the-u-s-voted-against-a-u-n-resolution-condemning-death-penalty-for-lgbtq-people/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The Trump administration voted on U.N. resolution that using the death penalty to punish same-sex relations was not a human rights violation.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"U.S. Does Not Condemn Death Penalty for LGBTQ People","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150354":{"ID":150354,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":87,"brief_bio":"","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"David Dayen","email":"david.dayen@gmail.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/DavidDayen","full_bio":"\u003cp>David Dayen is a contributor to The Intercept and also writes for Salon, the Fiscal Times, the New Republic, and more. His first book, “\u003ca href=\"http://thenewpress.com/books/chain-of-title\">Chain of Title\u003c/a>,” about three ordinary Americans who uncover Wall Street’s foreclosure fraud, was released in May 2016.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/02/david-dayen.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"davidd","pgp_file":"","pgp_fingerprint":"","pgp_key":"","twitter":"@ddayen","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/davidd/","user_group":"","user_title":""}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xf5BqN","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"54","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>For years, the\u003c/u> identity of the owner of one of the largest holdings of Puerto Rican debts has been a mystery.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>That mystery has finally been solved, with the help of the The Baupost Group, who unmasked themselves to The Intercept. The Baupost Group, a Boston-based hedge fund managed by billionaire Seth Klarman, owns nearly $1 billion of Puerto Rican debt, purchased under a shell company subsidiary and hidden from public scrutiny. Baupost acquired the debt through an on-paper Delaware-based corporation named Decagon Holdings LLC, whose beneficial owner had been unknown until now.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“The Baupost Group is a holder of COFINA bonds through the Decagon entities,” said Baupost spokesperson Diana DeSocio. “Baupost regularly makes investments through subsidiary holding entities.” She added that Klarman, \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/pictures/mdg45ekigd/38-seth-klarman/\">one of the richest hedge fund managers in the world\u003c/a>, did not hold any Puerto Rican debt individually.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Though the island, currently recovering from a catastrophic hurricane, has been mired in a borrowing crisis for years, it’s difficult to get precise information about the creditors. Many of them scooped up bonds on the cheap, seeking an astronomical payout by forcing the island to pay them back at par (or 100 cents on the dollar). This has led to widespread suffering, as punishing austerity has been imposed to encourage Puerto Rico to pay back the bondholders in full. (Only now has \u003ca href=\"http://caribbeanbusiness.com/puerto-ricos-fiscal-board-postpones-furloughs-following-hurricane-maria/\">some of this austerity been lifted\u003c/a> in the wake of Hurricane Maria.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Using shell companies to buy Puerto Rican bonds, then, can shield wealthy investors from public knowledge of their complicity in the misery of millions of U.S. citizens.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Julio López Varona, state director of Make the Road Connecticut and a member of the HedgeClippers coalition, which is organized to challenge the concentrated power of hedge funds, said the revelation of Klarman&#8217;s involvement will have political ramifications.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&#8220;What&#8217;s incredible about this is these people were actually hiding,&#8221; said López. &#8220;In the case of this person, he&#8217;s in Boston, which has a large Puerto Rican community. &#8230; Our work right now will be about activating our community in Boston, letting them know this person has been hiding and making sure we go to his houses and his companies to hold them accountable.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In July, as part of a court order to comply with bankruptcy procedures, a coalition of holders of “COFINA” bonds, backed by the island’s sales taxes, were required to supply the names of its members. The largest member in terms of bond value was Decagon Holdings, which had 10 separate purchasing subsidiaries (Decagon 1-10) holding \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/puertorico-debt/hedge-funds-disclose-their-puerto-rico-debt-holdings-idUSL1N1KH1FC\">$911.6 million\u003c/a> in COFINA bonds.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But there was no information about Decagon in the court filing, other than a Boston address of 800 Boylston St. That’s the 52-floor \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prudential_Tower\">Prudential Tower\u003c/a> skyscraper in the Back Bay district. The Intercept sent an associate to the Prudential Tower to find Decagon Holdings’ office, but they were not listed in the directory.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>A \u003ca href=\"http://www.mydecagon.com/\">rather primitive website\u003c/a> for a Decagon Holdings LLC turned out to be for a different company. “This is a start-up organization and has not gained any ground,” a spokesperson for the wrong Decagon Holdings stated to The Intercept. “You aren’t the first to ask these questions.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>It turns out that there were two Decagon Holdings. One, the startup, was \u003ca href=\"https://www.corporationwiki.com/p/2y7o79/decagon-holdings-llc\">incorporated in Nevada\u003c/a> in November 2016. But a second, which includes all 10 entities used by Baupost, was \u003ca href=\"https://icis.corp.delaware.gov/Ecorp/EntitySearch/NameSearch.aspx\">incorporated in Delaware\u003c/a> on August 4, 2015, through an agent called the Corporation Service Company. As usual for Delaware incorporation, almost no information accompanied that registration, including its beneficial owner.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>800 Boylston St. in Boston houses a number of investment firms, though none of them had the kind of assets that would plausibly include $911.6 million in Puerto Rican bonds. However, Kevin Connor, director of the \u003ca href=\"https://littlesis.org/\">Public Accountability Initiative\u003c/a>, directed The Intercept to an \u003ca href=\"http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2016/05/02/opinion-cofina-deal-is-huge-blow-to-dwindling-attractiveness-puerto-ricos-bonds.html\">obscure op-ed\u003c/a> written for Fox News’s since-shuttered Latino news site in May 2016. Iván Rivera Reyes, a Puerto Rican lawyer and politician, wrote that “COFINA was a creation of Wall Street financial whizzes Goldman Sachs and counts large billion-dollar hedge funds like GoldenTree Asset Management, Whitebox Advisors and Baupost Group as bondholders.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But while GoldenTree and Whitebox were known COFINA bondholders, Baupost had never publicly stated that they owned Puerto Rican debt. When Roll Call asked Sean Neary, a spokesperson for the coalition of COFINA bondholders, about Baupost’s role, he would only say, “They are not part of the steering committee group that is the main driver of the coalition.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>This appeared to be a confirmation, or at least a non-denial, of Baupost’s assets. Neary never responded to a request from the Intercept for comment. But contrary to Neary’s claim, Decagon was apparently active in the coalition, according to \u003ca href=\"https://www.elnuevodia.com/english/english/nota/cofinabondholdersheadtoboston-2301236/\">reports in Puerto Rican media\u003c/a> of them “leading” litigation efforts to get repaid.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Baupost had a connection to 800 Boylston, but not through an investment firm. The law office of \u003ca href=\"https://www.ropesgray.com/\">Ropes &amp; Gray\u003c/a> works out of that building, and one of its partners, \u003ca href=\"https://www.ropesgray.com/biographies/k/jeffrey-r-katz.aspx\">Jeffrey R. Katz\u003c/a>, has worked with Baupost in the past. This \u003ca href=\"http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ENZON/5284230234x0xS1061768-14-4/727510/filing.pdf\">SEC filing\u003c/a> about the purchase of shares in a pharmaceutical company lists Katz next to Klarman. It appeared that Baupost used Katz’s address to register the Decagon shell companies.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>When Connor, the public accountability advocate, contacted Katz about Decagon and Baupost, he hesitated and tried to get Connor off the phone. “He got really flustered,” Connor said. “He said, ‘You probably think you’re onto something big, but I’m a lawyer and I have clients.’” Katz never returned an Intercept request for comment.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The current spokesperson for the COFINA bondholders coalition, Greg Marose, did not confirm Baupost’s involvement, but did say, “We have a lot of stakeholders with commercial interests,” which could be read as an excuse for hiding ownership behind a shell corporation. Eventually, Baupost admitted to controlling the Decagon entities and owning the COFINA bonds. The COFINA bondholders group, Marose added in a later interview, has “proactively disclosed its steering committee members in press releases and all institutional members in legal filings.” In the case of Baupost, however, \u003cspan class=\"ydp57f6477fyiv1958036900\">this disclosure \u003c/span>did not reveal the name of the investor behind the shell company.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Klarman, who has been described as the \u003ca href=\"https://www.fool.com/investing/2017/02/17/what-this-legendary-value-investor-thinks-about-th.aspx\">Oracle of Boston\u003c/a>, has a history of buying unpopular or distressed assets on the cheap in hopes of a payday. Baupost manages \u003ca href=\"http://investment-advisors.credio.com/l/29378/The-Baupost-Group-LLC\">over $30 billion\u003c/a> in assets. He is known as the \u003ca href=\"https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/05/18/mass-gop-donors-wary-backing-trump/b3UnY2D9SJJToBoJhVDvEM/story.html\">top campaign contributor in New England\u003c/a> and has been a \u003ca href=\"https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2015/05/29/boston-fund-manager-seth-klarman-opens-about-his-financial-support-gop/AOfozraNcbBsV8HH90ugoO/story.html\">major donor in Republican politics\u003c/a> in Massachusetts, including \u003ca href=\"http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2016/08/19/the-checks-are-pouring-into-charter-fight-but-who-signing-them/eK01A6uECyWvgiDNXGqnqL/story.html?s_campaign=email_BG_TodaysHeadline&amp;s_campaign=\">largely secret\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"http://haveyouheardblog.com/family-affair/\">support for 2016’s Question 2,\u003c/a> an ultimately unsuccessful effort to lift a state cap on charter schools. Klarman \u003ca href=\"http://fortune.com/2016/10/18/wall-street-republicans-political-donations/\">supported Hillary Clinton\u003c/a> in 2016, calling Donald Trump “completely unqualified for the highest office in the land.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Klarman&#8217;s involvement in Puerto Rican debt will surely come as a surprise to activists in Massachusetts and Puerto Rico, who have never mentioned him among the “vultures” who are causing undue pain for the island’s U.S. citizens.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>COFINA bondholders have been sparring with holders of Puerto Rico’s general obligation debt over who has the right to be repaid first from a pool of sales tax revenue. Judge Laura Taylor Swain, currently presiding over the bankruptcy-like process in Puerto Rico, \u003ca href=\"http://www.barrons.com/articles/puerto-ricos-cofina-bond-payments-suspended-by-judge-1496261198\">suspended COFINA payments\u003c/a> in May.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The COFINA group has \u003ca href=\"https://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=F111888%20&amp;year=2017\">spent $610,000\u003c/a> lobbying Congress over the past two years. Last week, after an \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/09/27/puerto-rican-debt-holders-respond-to-catastrophic-hurricane-by-offering-puerto-rico-more-debt/\">Intercept report\u003c/a> about creditor responses &#8212; or the utter lack of them &#8212; to the disaster in Puerto Rico, COFINA bondholders \u003ca href=\"http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cofina-seniors-coalition-issues-statement-of-support-for-puerto-rico-in-the-wake-of-hurricanes-irma-and-maria-300526993.html\">offered\u003c/a> “our heartfelt thoughts and prayers” to those living on the island and promised that “members of the Coalition will be contributing to the Puerto Rico Chapter of the American Red Cross.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The amount was not disclosed, nor whether Seth Klarman and the Baupost Group would be contributing.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cstrong>Update: Oct. 3, 2017\u003cbr />\n\u003c/strong>\u003cem>Politico reporter Marc Caputo adds the context of Seth Klarman&#8217;s political giving.\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">So Seth Klarman buys $1 billion in Puerto Rico debt (breaking news from The \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/theintercept?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@theintercept\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/vhuwT1RlmC\">https://t.co/vhuwT1RlmC\u003c/a>).\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>But there&#39;s more: Klarman showers pols/candidates w/$2.9 million (per Open Secrets) &amp; stops giving 1 month before Congress passes creditor-favored PROMESA Act. \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/ezWnljt1pr\">pic.twitter.com/ezWnljt1pr\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Marc Caputo (@MarcACaputo) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MarcACaputo/status/915328931301031936?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 3, 2017\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class=\"\">\u003cstrong>\u003cspan class=\"\">Update: Oct. 4, 2017\u003c/span>\u003c/strong>\u003c/div>\n\u003cdiv class=\"\">\u003cem>\u003cspan class=\"\">This story has been updated to add an additional quote from COFINA spokesperson Greg Marose about the bondholder group’s disclosures of its steering committee members and institutional members.\u003c/span>\u003c/em>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top Photo: Seth Klarman, founder of the Baupost Group LLC, talks on the phone while arriving to a morning session at the Allen &amp; Co. Media and Technology Conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, on July 10, 2014.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-03T21:11:18+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-03T17:11:18+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The Baupost Group, a Boston-based hedge fund managed by billionaire Seth Klarman, owns nearly $1 billion of Puerto Rico's debt.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured with","article_text_color":"#AAAAAA","homepage_background_color":"#EEEEEE","homepage_featured":"0","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"In partnership with","homepage_text_color":"#111111","module_type":"default","partner":"default","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"150238,147054,150231,149292","related_post_permalinks":["https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/puerto-rico-debt-forgiveness-hurricane-maria/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/19/massachusetts-charter-school-group-fined-new-york/","https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/donald-trumps-disgusting-remark-on-puerto-rico-is-more-revealing-than-he-knows/","https://theintercept.com/2017/09/28/puerto-rico-rejects-loan-offers-accusing-hedge-funds-of-trying-to-profit-off-hurricanes/"],"series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"A secret owner of $1 billion in Puerto Rican debt is secret no more","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"we-can-finally-identify-one-of-the-largest-holders-of-puerto-rican-debt","thumbnail":{"ID":150364,"alt_text":"Seth Klarman, Media And Technology Conference"},"title":"We Can Finally Identify One of the Largest Holders of Puerto Rican Debt","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/03/we-can-finally-identify-one-of-the-largest-holders-of-puerto-rican-debt/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The Baupost Group, a Boston-based hedge fund managed by billionaire Seth Klarman, owns nearly $1 billion of Puerto Rico's debt.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Seth Klarman Is Among Largest Holders of Puerto Rico's Debt","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150534":{"ID":150534,"article_length_type":"Short","authors":[{"ID":101,"brief_bio":"Robert Mackey is a reporter and columnist focused on mining social networks for evidence of news events.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Robert Mackey","email":"robert.mackey@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/robert.mackey.794","full_bio":"\u003cp>Robert Mackey writes about national and international news through the prism of social media. Before joining The Intercept as a Senior Writer, he was a reporter and columnist for the New York Times, where he anchored the newspaper&#8217;s breaking news blog, \u003ca href=\"http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/author/robert-mackey/\">The Lede\u003c/a>, for five years, and wrote a news analysis column, \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/column/open-source\">Open Source\u003c/a>, from 2014 to 2016. His work is focused on making sense of events through the close reading of firsthand accounts, photographs, and video posted on social networks by witnesses and participants.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>His writing has also appeared in the New York Times Magazine, GQ, Slate, and The Guardian.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As a television producer, he has looked at \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mD61YTMiHnw\">the role played by soccer hooligans\u003c/a> in the war between Serbia and Croatia for Britain&#8217;s Channel 4, and spent a year and a half making a series of \u003ca href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MDVaW7CjH4Q\">video letters\u003c/a> from refugees for a United Nations-sponsored program broadcast in Sarajevo, Zagreb, and Belgrade during the wars in the former Minister Theresa May stumbled through a speech at her Conservative Party&#8217;s conference in Manchester on Wednesday, beset by a coughing fit, a failing voice, and the intervention of a satirist who hands as she leads it out of the European Union, but the Conservative conference instead highlighted the disarray at the top level of a government still deeply divided over Something","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/pranks-coughs-and-gags-about-dead-libyans-disarray-in-the-uk-as-brexit-looms/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"British Prime Minister Theresa May stumbled through a speech on Wednesday, beset by a coughing fit, a failing voice, and the intervention of a satirist.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Theresa May Endures Coughing Fit and Prank During Speech","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"150580":{"ID":150580,"article_length_type":"Short","authors":[{"ID":205,"brief_bio":"Aída Chávez is a journalist based in Washington, D.C.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Aída Chávez","email":"aida.chavez@theintercept.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Aída Chávez is a journalist based in Washington, D.C., covering Congress and the impact of public policy on diverse communities. Prior to joining The Intercept, she worked for The Hill and Cronkite News &#8211; Arizona PBS. She graduated from Arizona State University in 2017 with a Bachelor of Arts in journalism and a Bachelor of Arts in political science.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Aida-Chavez-1506009259.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"aidachavez","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/09/Aida-Chavez-Public-Key-1506438613.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"10EF 5E0D CB62 ED5F 677D  7CB9 A655 203A 353D 2999","pgp_key":"Aída Chávez Public Key","twitter":"@aidachavez_","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/aidachavez/","user_group":"","user_title":"Politics Reporter"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"https://interc.pt/2xSMTJO","categories":[{"name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized"}],"comments_number":"6","comments_open":true,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">\u003cu>Senate Republicans have\u003c/u> given up on trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act for now, but that doesn’t mean they’re done messing with health care. Their 2018 budget proposal paves the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut to be offset by massive cuts to Medicaid and Medicare, according to Senate Democrats who are sounding the alarm. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“A lot of attention has been paid to the Republican plan that will cost trillions and trillions of dollars, but not many Americans know that the president and Republicans are going to try to pay for some of those tax cuts by slashing programs seniors and middle-class Americans rely on,” \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said at a news conference Tuesday.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The proposed fiscal 2018 budget resolution Senate Republicans announced last week would lead to \u003c/span>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">a $1 trillion cut to Medicaid and $473 billion cut to Medicare over the next decade, along with slashing other programs low-income individuals rely on,\u003c/span>\u003ca href=\"https://www.sanders.senate.gov/download/2018-budget-analysis?inline=file\"> \u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">according to a new report\u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> prepared by the Senate Budget Committee minority staff.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1024px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Screen-Shot-2017-10-04-at-2.14.48-PM-1507141028.png\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-150684\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/Screen-Shot-2017-10-04-at-2.14.48-PM-1507141028-1024x633.png\" alt=\"Screen-Shot-2017-10-04-at-2.14.48-PM-1507141028\" />\u003c/a> \u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Graph: Senate Budget Committee Minority Staff\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The GOP has not yet publicly outlined the details of its budget proposal, but the report, from Senate Budget Committee ranking member Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., warns the cuts would attack safety net programs.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">On top of giving massive tax breaks to the people “who need it the least,” the proposed budget resolution would result in $1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid, which “will throw 15 million people off of the health insurance they currently have,” Sanders said Tuesday to reporters on Capitol Hill.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“And then on top of that, what they want to do is provide $470 billion in cuts to Medicare, at a time when so many seniors are struggling to keep their heads above water,” Sanders added.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Republicans on Capitol Hill say it&#8217;s unfair to call it a &#8220;cut,&#8221; because it is instead a reduction in the rate of growth. That slowed growth, however, will come as the population is rapidly aging.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">The Republican plan defies President Donald Trump’s\u003c/span> \u003ca href=\"http://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2017/03/10/trump-promises-not-to-cut-medicaid-newday.cnn\">\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">campaign promise\u003c/span>\u003c/a>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\"> to save Medicare and Medicaid “without cuts.”  \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“I was the first &amp; only potential GOP candidate to state there will be no cuts to Social Security, Medicare &amp; Medicaid,” Trump tweeted one month before he formally announced his bid for the presidency. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">I was the first &amp; only potential GOP candidate to state there will be no cuts to Social Security, Medicare &amp; Medicaid. Huckabee copied me.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>&mdash; Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/596338364187602944?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 7, 2015\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cp>\u003cscript async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">Sanders’s report predicts that if the cuts are applied proportionately, Republicans in total would cut at least $5 trillion over the next decade from education, health care, affordable housing, child care, nutrition assistance, transportation, and other programs.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400\">“But it’s not only cuts to Medicaid and Medicare, it is cuts to nutrition programs,” Sanders said. “The [Women, Infants, and Children] program, designed to provide help to low-income pregnant women and newly born babies, will be cut when we have more infant mortality, higher infant mortality, than any other country. Head Start programs will be cut, child care programs will be cut, affordable housing programs will be cut.”\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Top photo: Senate Budget Committee ranking member Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) attends a news conference critical of the Republican tax and budget plan with Rep. Richard Neal (D-MA), Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR) and fellow Democrats at the U.S. Capitol Oct. 4, 2017 in Washington.\u003c/p>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2017-10-04T17:49:28+00:00","date_local":"2017-10-04T13:49:28+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The GOP's proposed 2018 budget would lead to a $1 trillion cut to Medicaid and a $473 billion cut to Medicare over 10 years, according to Senate Democrats.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"default","feature_image_mask":"normal","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured ","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"1085","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617.jpg","width":"2170"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-e1507144756626-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/10/republican-budget-gop-medicaid-cuts-1507144617-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"Senators Schumer, Sanders, Wyden, And Rep. Pelosi Discuss GOP Tax Reform Plan"},"title":"Senate Republicans Are Coming for Medicare and Medicaid, This Time Through Tax Reform","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2017/10/04/senate-budget-tax-cuts-medicare-medicaid-health-care/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The GOP's proposed 2018 budget would lead to a $1 trillion cut to Medicaid and a $473 billion cut to Medicare over 10 years, according to Senate Democrats.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"Republicans Want to Pay for Tax Cuts by Slashing Health Care","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"64771":{"ID":64771,"article_length_type":"Very Long","authors":[{"ID":17,"brief_bio":"Micah Lee is a technologist with a focus on operational security, source protection, privacy, and cryptography.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Micah Lee","email":"micah.lee@theintercept.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Micah Lee is a computer security engineer and an open source software developer. He writes about technical topics like digital and operational security, encryption tools, whistleblowing, and hacking using language that everyone can understand, but without dumbing it down. An avid user of Qubes and Linux, he develops security tools such as \u003ca href=\"https://onionshare.org/\">OnionShare\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Before joining The Intercept, Micah worked as a staff technologist at the \u003ca href=\"https://www.eff.org/\">Electronic Frontier Foundation\u003c/a> where he explained how technologies work to journalists and lawyers, and worked to encrypt the web. He is also a founder and board member of \u003ca href=\"https://freedom.press/\">Freedom of the Press Foundation\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Send encrypted text messages to Micah using \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/07/02/security-tips-every-signal-user-should-know/\">Signal Messenger\u003c/a> at (415) 964-1601.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/01/Micah-Lee-1485659935.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"micah-lee","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/07/MicahLeePGP-1500337941.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"927F 419D 7EC8 2C2F 149C  1BD1 403C 2657 CD99 4F73","pgp_key":"Micah Lee Public Key","twitter":"@micahflee","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/micah-lee/","user_group":"","user_title":"Technology Analyst"},{"ID":45,"brief_bio":"Margot Williams is a journalist and research editor who was part of two Pulitzer Prize-winning teams at the Washington Post.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Margot Williams","email":"margot.williams@theintercept.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Margot Williams is Research Editor for Investigations at The Intercept. Her career at the Washington Post, New York Times, NPR and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists is one of the most respected in the investigative reporting world. She has pursued jihadists online and detainees who died in U.S. immigration detention, investigated Iraq war contractors and followed the money (and private jets) of mayors, governors, senators, presidential candidates, and ex-presidents. And she has spread her passion for investigative journalism — and her incredible ferreting skills — at numerous international workshops over the years.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>During 14 years at the Washington Post, Margot was a member of two Washington Post Pulitzer Prize-winning teams, for a 1998 investigation of D.C. police shootings of civilians and then again in 2001 for national coverage of terrorism. In the aftermath of 9/11 at the Washington Post and later at the New York Times, she investigated the network of jets and shell companies involved in the transport of terrorism suspects among secret prisons around the globe. She compiled the first list of the Guantánamo detainees — years before their names were made public — and created the comprehensive Guantánamo database on the Times website. In 2011, she analyzed the Guantánamo documents leaked by Bradley Manning for NPR and the New York Times.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/margot-350x350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"margotwilliams","pgp_file":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/09/MargotWilliamsPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"D301 003E DD1E 1BEA 6BE0 181B BB58 C7E5 F949 4209","pgp_key":"Margot Williams Public Key","twitter":"@MargotWilliams","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/margotwilliams/","user_group":"","user_title":"Research Editor for Investigations"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"http://interc.pt/27rT0i0","categories":[{"name":"release-may-2016","slug":"release-may-2016"},{"name":"release-may-2016-front","slug":"release-may-2016-front"},{"name":"Snowden Archive","slug":"snowden-archive"},{"name":"The SIDtoday Files","slug":"the-sidtoday-files"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"comments_number":"33","comments_open":false,"content":"\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 720px;'>\n\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/\" target=\"_blank\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65243\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/CYD_logo03.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"720\" height=\"98\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003c/div>\u003cbr />\n\u003cu>In the early\u003c/u> months of 2003, the National Security Agency saw demand for its services spike as a new war in Iraq, as well as ongoing and profound changes in how people used the internet, added to a torrent of new agency work related to the war on terror, according to a review of 166 articles from a restricted agency newsletter.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em> today is releasing the first three months of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>, March 31 through the end of June 2003, using files provided by NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden. In addition, we are releasing any subsequent 2003 installments of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> series that began during this period. \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">The files are available for download here\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>We combed through these files with help from other writers and editors with an eye toward finding the most interesting stories, among other concerns.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> was launched just 11 days into the U.S. invasion of Iraq by a team within the NSA’s Signals Intelligence Directorate. SID is arguably the NSA’s most important division, responsible for spying on the agency’s targets, and \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> became, as Peter Maass documents in an \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies\">accompanying article\u003c/a>, an invaluable primer on how the NSA breaks into and monitors communications systems around the world.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>At the outset, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829957-welcome-to-sidtoday/\">declared\u003c/a> that its mission was to “bring together communications from across the SIGINT Directorate in a single webpage” and that one of its key areas of focus would be providing “information on the Iraq Campaign and Campaign Against Terrorism.” And, indeed, the first issues of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> document how the agency paved the way for the Iraq War with diplomatic intelligence, supported the targeting of specific enemies in Iraq, and continued servicing existing “customers” like the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture, whose appetite for signals intelligence grew sharply after the Sept. 11 attacks.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>While the agency was helping in Iraq, NSA personnel were also involved in interrogations at Guantánamo Bay, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles show, working alongside the military and CIA at a time when prisoners there were treated brutally. \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em>’s Cora Currier \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">describes the NSA’s involvement with the interrogations in a separate story\u003c/a>, one that also documents how the agency helped with the capture and rendition to Guantánamo of a group of Algerian men in Bosnia.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Other highlights from this set of documents follow below, alongside links to the relevant originals.\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed full-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-war-2003.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-65060\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-war-2003.jpg\" alt=\"US Marines from the 2nd Battalion 8th regiment enter in the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah, March 23, 2003.\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">U.S. Marines from the 2nd Battalion, 8th Regiment enter the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah, March 23, 2003.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Eric Feferberg/AFP/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Shock and Awe: The Iraq War in SID\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>In the first months of the Iraq War, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles bragged about the NSA’s part in the run-up to the invasion and reflected the Bush administration’s confidence that Saddam Hussein had hidden weapons of mass destruction.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>At the United Nations, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829994-a-perspective-on-the-nsa-usun-partnership/\">readers were told\u003c/a>, “timely SIGINT played a critical role” in winning adoption of resolutions related to Iraq, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829969-support-to-un-diplomatic-efforts-on-iraq/\">including by providing\u003c/a> “insights into the nuances of internal divisions among the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>When the military deployed to Iraq, SIGINT came too. Maj. Gen. Richard J. Quirk III, then a deputy director of SID, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829958-deployed-sigint-analysts-an-urgent-need/\">put out an “urgent” call\u003c/a> for additional SIGINT analysts to volunteer for 90- to 120-day field deployment, stressing that “SIGINT is wired into our military operations as never before.” NSA’s Iraq War tasks \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830019-ncpac-personnel-deploy-to-support-operation/\">would include\u003c/a> “researching possible locations of stockpiled WMD material.” The Geospatial Exploitation Office, placed on 24/7 watch, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829963-geocell-supports-iraqi-freedom/\">provided\u003c/a> “near-real-time tipping of communications associated with Iraqi leadership and other high-value targets.”\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-right  width-fixed' style='width: 300px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/jessica-lynch.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"alignright wp-image-65064 size-article-medium\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/jessica-lynch-540x360.jpg\" alt=\"jessica-lynch\" width=\"540\" height=\"360\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">POW Pfc. Jessica Lynch being loaded into a military helicopter on her way out of Iraq, April 2, 2003.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: CENTCOM/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Just three days into the campaign, on March 23, 2003, Pfc. Jessica Lynch and five others were taken prisoner after their convoy from the 507th Maintenance Company went off course near Nasiriyah, Iraq, and lost 11 soldiers in the ensuing attack. On April 1, Special Operations commandos rescued Lynch from her bed at the Saddam Hussein General Hospital in Nasiriyah, swooping down in Black Hawk helicopters and firing explosive charges. (It later emerged that Iraqi forces had previously left the hospital.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829980-sid-support-to-pow-rescue/\">SID Support to POW Rescue\u003c/a>,” Chief of Staff Charles Berlin revealed that the Lynch rescue was aided by blueprints from the Japanese construction firm that originally built the hospital, blueprints rounded up as the rescue was being planned and sent “as digital files” to the commandos “literally minutes before the aircraft departed with the strike team” on April 1. Information about the hospital had been collected by a dedicated Underground Facility Support Cell created by the NSA in 2002 as part of an interagency effort to assess “the infrastructure and vulnerabilities of underground facilities used by hostile governments or military forces.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Even before President Bush declared an end to major combat operations in Iraq on May 1, 2003, NSA was preparing its history of the war. Record management officers were given guidance on how to preserve records from the operation, and the general staff was told how to preserve even “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829974-documenting-your-contribution-during-the-iraq/\">seemingly mundane things\u003c/a>.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Soon after the president’s “Mission Accomplished” victory speech, some NSA staff returned from deployment. But the role of signals intelligence in Iraq was not over. \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830086-king-of-diamonds-apprehended-in-iraq/\">The NSA provided “time-sensitive SIGINT” support\u003c/a>, including a “summary of contacts,” to aid the May 22, 2003, capture of a top Baathist official, Aziz Sajih Al-Numan, “king of diamonds” in the deck of playing cards that featured U.S. Central Command’s wanted Iraqis. Al-Numan was caught within 25 hours after the Army contacted NSA to request support. “Well done to all involved in his capture!” a \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> article declared.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In June, the “ace of diamonds,” Saddam’s secretary Abid Hamid Mahmud al-Tikriti, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830096-another-top-iraqi-captured/\">was captured\u003c/a> thanks to “near-real-time tipping [of geospatial intelligence] to the Special Operations Forces engaged in the hunt,” along with rapid translation of intercepted conversations, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> bragged.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>As the end of the quarter approached, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> reported on portents of continued resistance and \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830088-24-hours-in-iraq/\">warned\u003c/a>, “The scope of hostilities is greater than many may realize,” and, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830077-staying-focused-on-iraq/\">separately\u003c/a>, that “Iraq is still a troubled environment and much work needs to be done.&#8221;\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Additional \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles about Iraq are available \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=iraq#archive\">here\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Hunting a Russian Mobster, “Mr. Kumarin”\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>In an example of highly targeted intelligence gathering, the NSA spent “many months” acquiring the phone number of a Russian organized crime figure and began intercepting his calls, according to \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830009-target-development-from-scratch-the-russian/\">a May 2003 article\u003c/a>. The intelligence work was sparked by the State Department, which in 2002 requested information on the leader of the Tambov crime syndicate in Russia, referred to only as “Mr. Kumarin,” and about any links between the syndicate and Russian President Vladimir Putin.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In 2009, the Russian authorities tried and convicted Vladimir Kumarin, who had changed his name to Vladimir Barsukov, for fraud and money laundering. The \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/14/world/europe/14mobster.html\">compared\u003c/a> him to a “Russian John Gotti.” He was \u003ca href=\"http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/barsukov-handed-14-years-for-fraud/389369.html\">sentenced\u003c/a> to 14 years in prison.\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed full-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/north-korea-soldiers.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-65150\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/north-korea-soldiers.jpg\" alt=\"A North Korean soldier looks at the South side through binoculars at the truce village of Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone dividing two Koreas on April 9, 2009. North Korea's parliament re-elected Kim Jong-Il to the country's most powerful post, cementing his authority over the hardline communist state despite lingering health questions.  AFP PHOTO/JUNG YEON-JE (Photo credit should read JUNG YEON-JE/AFP/Getty Images)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">A North Korean soldier looks south through binoculars at the truce village of Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone dividing North and South Korea on April 9, 2009.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Jung Yeon-Je/AFP/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Uncovering North Korean Nuclear Efforts\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>As previously shown, NSA signals intelligence was used to inform negotiations over U.N. resolutions against Iraq in early 2003. But that wasn’t the only time the agency influenced diplomacy: In 2002, signals intelligence ignited a confrontation between North Korea and the U.S., according to \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829973-uncovering-north-korea-nuclear-programs/\">a \u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>article from April 2003\u003c/a>. NSA eavesdroppers discovered that North Korea was developing a uranium enrichment capability in violation of an agreement with the U.S. When the State Department presented the evidence at a meeting in Pyongyang that October, the North Koreans admitted it was true, the article said, setting off the clash.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“The ONLY source of information on this treaty violation was SIGINT derived from North Korean external communications,” an NSA manager wrote in \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>. “This is both a SIGINT success story and an example of how cross-organizational collaboration can produce key intelligence. Hats off to everyone involved!”\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Orbital Signals Intelligence\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>For more than 30 years, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830054-new-release-the-fornsat-plan/\">one \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> article from June 2003 explained\u003c/a>, the NSA had tapped into communications from foreign satellites. Though the program associated with this monitoring, FORNSAT, has been previously \u003ca href=\"https://www.aclu.org/foia-document/primary-fornsat-collection-operations\">disclosed\u003c/a>, this document adds important context. For example, it made FORNSAT sound like an intelligence gold mine, having “consistently provided … over 25 percent of end product reporting.” It also explained what sorts of information the NSA gleaned from satellites — “intelligence derived from diplomatic communications … airline reservations and billing data … traffic about terrorists, international crime, weapons of mass destruction … international finance and trade.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The problem, at the time the article was written, was that FORNSAT was in “dire need of upgrade” because it was “primarily engineered for voice” communications and needed to shift to intercepting more digital communications, including digital video. It also needed to be expanded to tap into mobile satellite phone systems, which “use hundreds of spot beams. Our 13 fixed FORNSAT sites cannot provide the necessary access.”\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Leaks Included in 5,000 “Insecurity Records”\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>Ten years before Edward Snowden gave a trove of NSA documents to journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras, a “chief” within SID’s Communications and Support Operations organization \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829987-profile-intelligence-security-issues/\">described in \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> the great lengths the agency went to in order to track leaks\u003c/a>. In a profile of the Intelligence Security Issues office within CSO, this person said that ISI scanned 350 press items daily for “cryptologic insecurities” and maintained a database called FIRSTFRUIT with “over 5,000 insecurity-related records” ranging from “espionage damage assessments” to “liaison exchanges.” This ISI profile ran as part of a broader \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=communications-and-support-operations-cso#archive\">series on the CSO organization\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Technology Pushed NSA Into the Tablet Era — and Tons of Gear Went Missing\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>One theme that emerges from early 2003 \u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>installments is that the NSA was grappling with how to handle advances in information technology, particularly the proliferation of mobile devices and online networks.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>One article in the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=customer-relations#archive\">“Customer Relations” series\u003c/a> described several “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829992-dynamic-methods-of-interaction-with-new-and/\">dynamic dissemination products\u003c/a>” to help SID “change with … our customers,” including an initiative to distribute “secret-level information” to wireless devices, a technique for disseminating “NSA product” to tablet computers, and a system to view secret documents on unclassified computers over the internet, bypassing the need for a high-security enclosed area known as a SCIF. These efforts foreshadowed Hillary Clinton’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/how-clintons-email-scandal-took-root/2016/03/27/ee301168-e162-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html\">controversial\u003c/a> use, as secretary of state, of a BlackBerry device to traffic in sensitive government information after the NSA reportedly rebuffed her request for a special secure device from the agency.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830027-sid-property-inventory-starts-next-week/\">Another article\u003c/a> highlighted that the NSA was a heavy user of mobile devices even four years before the release of the first iPhone, calling on staffers to help catalogue all computers, including “laptops, palmtops/PDAs, etc.,” for an annual inventory.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The document also stated that $27 million worth of equipment remained “unaccounted for” after the prior year’s audit, which ended just two months earlier.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In addition to making secret information accessible to more people, SID was developing new systems to solve long-standing problems. The JOURNEYMAN program, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830013-what-is-journeyman/\">described in another article\u003c/a>, aimed to develop a system for distributing SIGINT reports to many different recipients at once across different networks with different formatting requirements. \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830069-patenthammer/\">Another system, PATENTHAMMER\u003c/a>, collected cellular, fax, and pager signals for the Special Operations Command and also allowed users to access information collected in the past.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>SID was also still exploring the rapidly evolving internet. One article described how the NSA was improving its integration with the public internet via a program \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830068-outparks-a-new-internet-for-nsa/\">called OUTPARKS\u003c/a>. Another \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830032-sigint-development-2003-conference/\">touted\u003c/a> the NSA’s annual SIGDEV conference, a major event \u003ca href=\"https://niccs.us-cert.gov/news-events/nsa-sigint-development-conference-2015\">in which\u003c/a> analysts from the “\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Eyes\">five eyes\u003c/a>” intelligence agencies in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States share techniques for developing new SIGINT. The article noted that the 2003 SIGDEV would include workshops on “social network analysis,” “internet research,” and “wireless LANs,” that is, wifi networks.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Other NSA staff apparently required more basic forms of training. “Do you know you can make \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> your browser homepage?” asked \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830087-makin-it-easy/\">a June 2003 article\u003c/a>, with instructions on changing the default homepage in the web browsers popular at the time: Netscape and Internet Explorer.\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1000px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/world-trade-center-9-11.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-large wp-image-65085\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/world-trade-center-9-11-1000x1000.jpg\" alt=\"world-trade-center-9-11\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">Sept. 12, 2001, shows an area of white dust and smoke at the location where the 1,350-foot towers of the World Trade Center once stood in New York City.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Spaceimaging.com/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Demand for NSA Intelligence Became “Voracious”\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>The Signals Intelligence Directorate is full of expert spies, but they don’t choose who to spy on themselves. In the corporate lingo of SID, the “customer” decides, customers “including all departments of the executive branch,” according to the agency’s \u003ca href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20160416092433/https:/www.nsa.gov/sigint/\">website\u003c/a>. And the demand from customers exploded in 2003, judging from a \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=customer-relations#archive\">series of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles about the Customer Relationships Directorate\u003c/a>, an office focused on ensuring that NSA’s customers get what they need.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>One driver of this demand was the war on terror; inbound SIGINT requests to the NSA’s National Security Operations Center went from 300 in the two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks to 1,700 by the end of the year, according to \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829985-information-needs-management-careful-planning/\">one \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> article\u003c/a>. Existing customers like the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture “suddenly became voracious consumers” of signals intelligence, as \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829992-dynamic-methods-of-interaction-with-new-and/\">one article from April 2003 \u003c/a>put it, and brand new customers appeared on the scene, such as the newly created Department of Homeland Security. SID also increased its interaction with domestic law enforcement agencies like the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Another driver of heightened SIGINT demand was the war in Iraq. According to the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829994-a-perspective-on-the-nsa-usun-partnership/\">document\u003c/a> describing the NSA’s role in war-related U.N. Security Council resolutions, “The number of timely SIGINT tippers delivered to [the U.S. Mission to the United Nations] during key points in the negotiations increased by a factor of four.”\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Creating a “Plausible Cover” for Sensitive Intelligence Sources\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>Amid strong demand for intelligence, the NSA sometimes needed to alter sensitive information so it could be shared more widely. As part of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>’s explainer series “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=consider-this#archive\">ConSIDer This\u003c/a>,” one unknown author from the SIGINT communications team \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830106-consider-this-what-does-it-mean-to-downgrade/\">explained how to lower the classification level\u003c/a> of intercepted communications, or COMINT, a process known as “downgrading.” The process could involve some subterfuge. “In order to downgrade COMINT, a plausible cover (i.e., collection from a less sensitive source) must exist,” the article stated.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Changing of the Guard at SID\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>As \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> launched in 2003, the Signals Intelligence Directorate was in the midst of a leadership change as Director Maureen Baginski \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829965-sid-leadership-transition-passing-the-baton/\">moved to a new position\u003c/a> as the FBI’s head of intelligence and Maj. Gen. Quirk replaced her. Several other new managers and technical directors introduced themselves in the online newsletter’s series “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=getting-to-know-the-sid-leadership-team#archive\">Getting to Know the SID Leadership Team\u003c/a>.” Also in that series: A senior technical leader \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830080-jack-israel-a-amp-p-s-senior-technical-leader/\">complained\u003c/a> that “voice dominates our reporting today, yet [digital information] is much more prolific in the global net” and explored reasons for this shortcoming.\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed full-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/menwith-hill.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-65080\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/menwith-hill.jpg\" alt=\"The radar domes of RAF Menwith Hill in north Yorkshire dominate the skyline on 30 October, 2007, Harrogate, England. \" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">The radar domes of RAF Menwith Hill in North Yorkshire dominate the skyline, Oct. 30, 2007, Harrogate, England.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Life Stationed Abroad for SID Staffers\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>Throughout the second half of 2003, employees of the Signals Intelligence Directorate contributed articles to the series “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=sid-around-the-world-03#archive\">SID Around the World\u003c/a>,” a sort of collective travelogue on their tours outside the Fort Meade, Maryland, headquarters of the NSA. SID staffers seemed to most enjoy local cuisine: beer, strawberries, chocolates, and ramen, although one touted the possibility of “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830116-spanning-the-globe-misawa-to-menwith-hill-part-2/\">less than a four-hour drive\u003c/a>” from the NSA’s U.K. Menwith Hill site for a “Taco Bell or Cinnabon fix.” Interspersed with recommendations for Rhineland wineries, Japanese communal hot baths, and winter sports in Colorado were some interesting facts about NSA’s global reach in 2003. The majority of signals processed at the Kunia operations center in Hawaii were \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830081-sid-around-the-world-sigint-from-paradise-okinawa/\">collected on Okinawa\u003c/a>. Some of the NSA’s representatives in Mons, Belgium, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830095-sid-around-the-world-a-country-the-size-of/\">worked in an underground bunker\u003c/a>. The Misawa base in Japan had \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830115-spanning-the-globe-misawa-to-menwith-hill-part-1/\">just 25 civilian NSA personnel, while Menwith Hill had several hundred\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>’s “Around the World” to Guantánamo Bay is part of a \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">larger story on the NSA&#8217;s role in interrogations\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>\u003cem>Office Space\u003c/em>: NSA Edition\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>’s \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=a-day-in-the-life#archive\">“A Day in the Life” series\u003c/a> provided first-person accounts of the various jobs within the Signals Intelligence Directorate. For example, one “Day in the Life” \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830111-mathematician-an-insider-s-view/\">described the work of a mathematician\u003c/a> in the field of “diagnosis,” that is, studying encryption systems in order to understand their weaknesses. “During the course of a normal day,” the mathematician wrote, “I run cryptanalytic routines on UNIX desktop workstations, supercomputers, and special-purpose devices using available software tools. The routines employ standard cryptanalytic tests which search for patterns and non-random properties in data.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The series also included \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830102-the-life-of-an-exec/\">an article written by Maj. Gen. Quirk’s executive assistant\u003c/a> — the “conscience” of a “senior leader” — and \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830117-sitting-in-the-soo-s-chair/\">another by a senior operations officer\u003c/a> whose work involved entertaining Fox News personality Tony Snow before he became White House press secretary.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Peer Review for Spies: NSA’s Learned Organizations\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>For an academic, there is no better way to improve your career than to get published in prestigious journals and to win prestigious awards. But what if your research is classified and you can’t ever get the public recognition you deserve without betraying state secrets? If you work for the NSA, you look to one of the agency’s Learned Organizations to receive your academic accolades.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829998-a-look-at-nsa-s-learned-organizations/\">included\u003c/a> a \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/?topic=nsas-learned-organizations#archive\">series of articles that shines a spotlight on NSA’s Learned Organizations\u003c/a>, including the cryptanalysis-focused \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830018-the-kryptos-society/\">KRYPTOS Society\u003c/a>; the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830030-the-crypto-linguistic-association-cla/\">Crypto-Linguistic Association\u003c/a>, focused on language analysis, with events that in 2002 included a luncheon with the director of the \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klingon_Language_Institute\">Klingon Institute\u003c/a>; the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830038-the-collection-association-ca/\">Collection Association\u003c/a>, whose membership evolved from spies gathering intelligence via antennas to also include the monitoring of satellites and internet sleuthing; the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830071-the-crypto-mathematics-institute-cmi/\">Crypto-Mathematics Institute\u003c/a>, NSA&#8217;s oldest Learned Organization, founded in 1957, whose activities included an essay contest; and the \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830082-the-international-affairs-institute-iai/\">International Affairs Institute\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>Related Stories:\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cul>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">Snowden Archive — The SIDtoday Files\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/the-intercept-is-broadening-access-to-the-snowden-archive-heres-why\">The Intercept Is Broadening Access to the Snowden Archive. Here’s Why\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies\">What It’s Like to Read the NSA’s Newspaper for Spies\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">NSA Closely Involved in Guantánamo Interrogations, Documents Show\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2016-05-16T15:37:10+00:00","date_local":"2016-05-16T11:37:10+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"We combed through more than 160 internal NSA documents and found disclosures about interrogations at Guantánamo, the Iraq War, satellite-communications monitoring, the challenges of spying on the internet, and much more.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"","feature_image_mask":"","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Most Intriguing Spy Stories From 166 Internal NSA Reports","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/the-most-intriguing-spy-stories-from-166-internal-nsa-reports/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The
