follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"64776":{"ID":64776,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":11,"brief_bio":"Peter Maass has written about war, media, and national security for a variety of outlets.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Peter Maass","email":"peter.maass@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/peter.maass10","full_bio":"\u003cp>Peter Maass has written about war, media, and national security for\u003cem> The New York Times Magazine\u003c/em>, \u003cem>The New Yorker, \u003c/em>and \u003cem>The Washington Post\u003c/em>. \u003c!-- Read More --\>He reported on both civilians and combatants during the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan. He is the author of \u003cem>Love Thy Neighbor: A Story of War\u003c/em>, an award-winning memoir about the conflict in Bosnia, and he wrote \u003cem>Crude World: The Violent Twilight of Oil\u003c/em>. Peter was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship in 2012. He has taught writing at Princeton and Columbia universities, and had fellowships at the Shorenstein Center at Harvard and the American Academy in Berlin. He is on the advisory boards of the Solutions Journalism Network, and the Program for Narrative and Documentary Practice at Tufts University. A graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, he lives in New York City.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/02/Peter-Mass-Hi-Res-Original-2_350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"peter-maass","pgp_file":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/05/PeterMassPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"0C49 0F9D 179E 263F 9FFE 5080 2198 F5B7 D4E5 391A","pgp_key":"Peter Maass Public Key","twitter":"@maassp","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/peter-maass/","user_group":"","user_title":"Senior Editor"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"http://interc.pt/1TjH3Uf","categories":[{"name":"release-may-2016","slug":"release-may-2016"},{"name":"release-may-2016-front","slug":"release-may-2016-front"},{"name":"Snowden Archive","slug":"snowden-archive"},{"name":"The SIDtoday Files","slug":"the-sidtoday-files"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"comments_number":"11","comments_open":false,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 720px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/\" target=\"_blank\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65243\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/CYD_logo03.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"720\" height=\"98\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>The men and women\u003c/u> who work at the National Security Agency were greeted, on March 31, 2003, with a cheery notice on their office computers. “Welcome to \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>,” a new internal website \u003ca href=\"http://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829957-welcome-to-sidtoday/\">announced\u003c/a>, explaining that the communications team in the Signals Intelligence Directorate, the heart of the NSA, was launching the publication to keep employees abreast of what was happening inside the spy agency.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The website, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>, started modestly. Its \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829956-the-analyst-cockpit/\">inaugural article\u003c/a> blandly described what it called “the analyst cockpit,” a portal for intelligence experts to access their data. The following day, which was April Fools’, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> posted an \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829959-practical-jokes-and-april-fools/\">offbeat story\u003c/a> about practical jokes, recounting how the Germans in World War II built a decoy air base, complete with planes, out of wood; the kicker, according to \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>, was that the British realized the base was a decoy and dropped a wooden bomb on it. (Online fact-checkers have since \u003ca href=\"http://www.snopes.com/military/woodbomb.asp\">declared\u003c/a> the story a “well-traveled anecdote” of dubious accuracy.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The April Fools’ article was at the frivolous end of the \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> spectrum. Because it trafficked in “top-secret” information, \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> lived in a classified environment that, over the years, allowed the agency’s spies to explain to each other, in a non-technical way, a surprising amount about what they were doing, how they were doing it, and why. In the first nine years of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>’s life, \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830625-2012-03-30-SIDToday-Number-9-Number-9.html\">more than 4,500 stories\u003c/a> were posted on the website, a gold mine of often mundane, occasionally revealing articles that made the agency human and comprehensible in a way that technical documents could not.\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-bleed full-bleed width-auto' style='width: auto;'> \u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-64851\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-baghdad.jpg\" alt=\"NASIRIYAH, IRAQ - MARCH 25:  U.S. Marines from the 1st Marine Division pass a sign pointing the way to Baghdad as they continue their march to the capital March 25, 2003 in the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah. After two days of running gun battles, the third day seems to be relatively quiet.  (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)\" />\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption overlayed\">U.S. Marines pass a sign pointing the way to Baghdad as they continue their march to the capital, March 25, 2003, in the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source pullright' style=''>Photo: Joe Raedle/Getty Images\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Functioning like a small-town newspaper, the staff of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> published question-and-answer articles with senior and mid-level officials who described their jobs and their motivations for doing them. Some articles were firsthand descriptions of important missions, as in the case of an NSA employee who went to Baghdad right after the Iraqi capital came under American control. “I rode the whole way in a five-ton truck, with easy access to thermite grenades that could be used to destroy our classified cargo in the event of an ambush,” he \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830628-2003-12-05-SIDToday-Camp-Virginia-to-Camp.html\">wrote\u003c/a> at the end of 2003. Another \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829980-sid-support-to-pow-rescue/\">story\u003c/a>, by SID’s chief of staff, described how the agency helped with the rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch during the invasion (his article is included in the first batch of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles).\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>even assembled a stable of columnists over the course of its first nine years, contributors who wrote as a sideline to their day jobs at the agency. One column, called “Ask Zelda!,” was akin to “Dear Abby” for the intelligence community, written by a mid-level supervisor at the NSA who answered questions from readers, including one about what should be worn to the office on hot summer days. “Shorts and flip-flops don’t exactly convey the image of a fierce SIGINT warrior,” Zelda \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1059979-is-bain-de-soleil-a-bane-on-nsa.html\">noted\u003c/a>. Another column, “SIGINT Philosopher,” delved into the ethics of surveillance (reliably coming out on the favorable side) and was written by a language analyst who described a personal epiphany that came during a polygraph exam. “Signal v. Noise” explored the difficulties involved in collecting large amounts of data, while “SIGINT Curmudgeon” was written by a longtimer who waxed nostalgic about the good old days of eavesdropping. (None of these columns were up and running in the initial batch of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">just released\u003c/a> by \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em>, but I have written previously \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2014/03/07/nsa-advice-columnist-seriously/\">about “Ask Zelda!”\u003c/a> and \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2015/08/11/surveillance-philosopher-nsa/\">the “SIGINT Philosopher\u003c/a>.” In both cases, \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em> simultaneously published copies of the original columns.)\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>One of the cultural revelations in the archives of \u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>is the corporate language that was routinely used. Intelligence reports delivered to other government agencies were described as “products,” and there was a category called the “\u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830623-2009-08-05-SIDToday-Does-NSA-Look-Different-From.html\">Counterterrorism Product Line\u003c/a>.” Government agencies that received these reports were known as “customers,” and the NSA has an entire division called the “Customer Relationship Directorate.” One of the \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles published today was titled “\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2829992-dynamic-methods-of-interaction-with-new-and/\">Dynamic Methods of Interaction With New and Existing Customers\u003c/a>,” and it referred to “product line leaders” at the agency who created “customer support plans” that included details on what “each customer needs.” The customers mentioned in the article included the Department of Homeland Security, Secret Service, Missile Defense Agency, and Federal Reserve. The article was written by an official whose title was “acting chief, customer gateway.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles also convey what officials at the agency were reading in their off-hours. Some articles included references to popular authors like the travel writer \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830626-2010-04-30-SIDToday-Learning-to-Love-English.html\">Bill Bryson\u003c/a>, the \u003cem>New Yorker\u003c/em> writer Malcolm Gladwell, and mid-century economist Herbert Simon. One of the articles released today was an \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830090-book-review-cryptonomicon/\">enthusiastic review\u003c/a> of the Neal Stephenson sci-fi novel \u003cem>Cryptonomicon\u003c/em>, which was described in the article (written by a member of the communications team in the Signals Intelligence Directorate) as “an enthralling work that proves to be as much of a history lesson as an eye-opening thriller.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The articles, almost uniformly glowing about the NSA, serve as reminders that the men and women who surveil the world are not machines; they have good days and bad days, jokes and tears, and strange tales about their lives. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830621-2010-09-03-SIDToday-From-the-SIDtoday-Archives.html\">two\u003c/a>-part \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830622-2005-09-02-SIDToday-Odd-Jobs-Before-NSA-Part-2.html\">article\u003c/a> from 2005, “‘Odd Jobs’ Before NSA,” listed unconventional occupations that some employees had before joining the world’s largest electronic spying organization. The prior jobs included being a craps dealer in Las Vegas, a developer of crossword puzzles for the \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em>, a professional baseball player in the Atlanta Braves farm system, a nanny for the daughter of Sunny von Bülow’s first husband, and a “mosquito bite test count subject” who was paid to visit forests and swamps to take off his shirt for a minute to assess the local mosquito population.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>even offers a window into the hopes and wide-eyed wonder of the agency’s youngest workers, its summer interns. The title of one intern’s article for \u003cem>SIDtoday \u003c/em>in 2004 was “\u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830627-2004-08-13-SIDToday-How-I-Spent-My-Summer-Vacation.html\">How I Spent My Summer Vacation\u003c/a>,” while \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830624-2011-7-27-Culture-Shock-NSA-From-the-Perspective.html\">another article\u003c/a> in 2011 recounted that on their first day of work, a boisterous group of interns stepped into an elevator and got a quick and stern lecture from “an older gentleman” who warned that “the only thing you need to know is that we don’t talk in the elevators, and the extroverts look at \u003cem>other\u003c/em> people’s shoes.” The interns silently shared the same reaction — “\u003cem>What have we gotten ourselves into\u003c/em>\u003cem>?\u003c/em>”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>Related Stories:\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cul>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">Snowden Archive — The SIDtoday Files\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/the-intercept-is-broadening-access-to-the-snowden-archive-heres-why\">The Intercept Is Broadening Access to the Snowden Archive. Here’s Why \u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/the-most-intriguing-spy-stories-from-166-internal-nsa-reports\">The Most Intriguing Spy Stories From 166 Internal NSA Reports\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">NSA Closely Involved in Guantánamo Interrogations, Documents Show\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2016-05-16T15:36:55+00:00","date_local":"2016-05-16T11:36:55+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"An internal website was surprisingly forthcoming about NSA activities.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"","feature_image_mask":"","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":null,"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"","article_text_color":"","homepage_background_color":"","homepage_featured":"","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"","homepage_text_color":"","module_type":"","partner":"","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"","related_post_permalinks":"","series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"The NSA’s newspaper, SIDtoday, reveals the human side of America’s digital spies","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies","thumbnail":{"ID":64967,"alt_text":"","content":"","credit":"Photo: Joe Raedle/Getty Images","excerpt":"NASIRIYAH, IRAQ - MARCH 26:  U.S. Marines from Task Force Tarawa search for Iraqi troops March 26, 2003 in the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah. As night falls on the city, the Marines are on 100 percent alert for a counter attack from Iraqi troops.  (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"720","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5.jpg","width":"1440"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/iraq-soldiers5-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"iraq-soldiers5"},"title":"What It’s Like to Read the NSA’s Newspaper for Spies","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"An internal website was surprisingly forthcoming about NSA activities.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"64780":{"ID":64780,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":41,"brief_bio":"Cora Currier is a journalist with a focus on national security, immigration, and human rights.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Cora Currier","email":"cora.currier@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/cora.currier","full_bio":"\u003cp>Cora Currier is a journalist who writes about national security, immigration, human rights and other topics. She previously worked at ProPublica and the New Yorker, and was a lead researcher on several books of history and politics. She lives in Los Angeles, California.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/08/cora_avatar_1409289060-350x350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"cora","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2017/01/Cora-Currier-1484860003.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"CC23 B6AE D956 A572 4B81  F476 4E1C 9655 0DB0 0F95","pgp_key":"Cora Currier Public Key","twitter":"@coracurrier","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/cora/","user_group":"","user_title":"Story Editor"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"http://interc.pt/1TSu0q5","categories":[{"name":"release-may-2016","slug":"release-may-2016"},{"name":"release-may-2016-front","slug":"release-may-2016-front"},{"name":"Snowden Archive","slug":"snowden-archive"},{"name":"The SIDtoday Files","slug":"the-sidtoday-files"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"comments_number":"23","comments_open":false,"content":"\u003cp>\u003cu>\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 720px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/\" target=\"_blank\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65243\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/CYD_logo03.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"720\" height=\"98\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>Personnel from the\u003c/u> National Security Agency worked alongside the military, CIA, and other agencies on interrogations at Guantánamo in the early days of the war on terror, new documents show.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Entries from an internal NSA publication, which were among the documents provided by whistleblower Edward Snowden, described staffers’ deployments to Guantánamo Bay during a time period when prisoners were subjected to brutal questioning and mistreatment. An NSA employee also described participation in a rendition, when U.S. forces seized six men in Bosnia and secreted them off to Cuba.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>In October 2003, a post in \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>, the online newsletter of the NSA’s Signals Intelligence Directorate, or SID, advertised the “\u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830617-2003-10-29-SIDToday-Can-You-Handle-the-Truth-or.html\">chance to get to GITMO for 90 days!\u003c/a>”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The NSA’s liaison, or NSA LNO, would “coordinate” with interrogators “to collect information of value to the NSA Enterprise and Extended Enterprise” and be “responsible for interfacing with the DoD, CIA, and FBI interrogators on a daily basis in order to assess and exploit information sourced from detainees.” In some instances, the relationship would go the other way, with the NSA providing “sensitive NSA-collected technical data and products to assist JTF-GTMO [Joint Task Force Guantánamo] interrogation efforts.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The post’s title was “Can You Handle the Truth?” — a reference to Jack Nicholson’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FnO3igOkOk\">famous line\u003c/a> in the courtroom drama \u003cem>A Few Good Men\u003c/em>, set in Guantánamo.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Two months later, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830120-sid-around-the-world-a-tdy-to-guantanamo-bay/\">in another post\u003c/a>, an NSA liaison reported back on his trip. “On a given week,” he wrote, he would “pull together intelligence to support an upcoming interrogation, formulate questions and strategies for the interrogation, and observe or participate in the interrogation.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Outside work, “fun awaits,” he enthused. “Water sports are outstanding: boating, paddling, fishing, water skiing and boarding, sailing, swimming, snorkeling, and SCUBA.” If water sports were “not your cup of tea,” there were also movies, pottery, paintball, and outings to the Tiki Bar. “Relaxing is easy,” he concluded.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Other accounts of Guantánamo around the same time were not so sunny.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>FBI agents there \u003ca href=\"https://www.aclu.org/news/fbi-e-mail-refers-presidential-order-authorizing-inhumane-interrogation-techniques\">internally\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14936-2004Dec20.html\">protested\u003c/a> the interrogation tactics they witnessed, describing them as “torture techniques” and “beyond the bounds of standard FBI practice,” including detainees being chained in fetal positions on the floor, without food or water, and the use of strobe lights, loud music, and dogs.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The International Committee of the Red Cross \u003ca href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/30/politics/red-cross-finds-detainee-abuse-in-guantanamo.html\">charged\u003c/a> in a 2004 confidential report that treatment of some prisoners at Guantánamo was “tantamount to torture.” In a June 2004 visit, its investigators reported &#8220;humiliating acts, solitary confinement, temperature extremes, use of forced positions” and “some beatings,” according to a \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> report.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The George W. Bush administration began bringing prisoners to Guantánamo \u003ca href=\"http://projects.nytimes.com/guantanamo/timeline\">in early 2002\u003c/a>, and by the end of the year, over 600 men had been processed at the prison.  Over the next few years, over a hundred more would arrive. Despite the Bush administration’s rhetoric that Guantánamo held “the worst of the worst,” many of them were innocent men, some of whom had been sold for bounty to U.S. forces in Afghanistan. Only a \u003ca href=\"http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article2163210.html\">handful\u003c/a> of them would ever be charged with a crime by the U.S. government.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>It’s not a surprise that the NSA would send representatives to support military operations (as detailed in this Department of Defense \u003ca href=\"https://fas.org/irp/doddir/dod/jp2_02.pdf\">doctrine\u003c/a>), but its role during this controversial period remains murky. In the many investigations into detainee treatment, the NSA has hardly surfaced.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>Neither the Senate Intelligence Committee’s \u003ca href=\"http://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/senate-intelligence-committee-study-on-cia-detention-and-interrogation-program\">report\u003c/a> on the CIA’s detention and rendition program (which \u003ca href=\"http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/guantanamo/article4434603.html\">confirmed\u003c/a> the existence of two CIA facilities at Guantánamo) nor a 2008 Senate Armed Services Committee \u003ca href=\"http://documents.nytimes.com/report-by-the-senate-armed-services-committee-on-detainee-treatment\">report\u003c/a> on detainee abuse by the military addresses the role of the NSA, at least in the heavily censored versions that have been made public.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The NSA declined to comment for this story.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The NSA documents made explicit reference to the CIA working on interrogations at Guantánamo. At the time of the documents, in late 2003, the CIA had just \u003ca href=\"http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/washington/articles/2010/08/07/ap_exclusive_cia_flight_carried_secret_from_gitmo/\">brought\u003c/a> four of its “high-value” prisoners to Guantánamo: alleged al Qaeda operative Abu Zubaydah, Ramzi Binalshibh and Mustafa al-Hawsawi, who helped plan the 9/11 attacks, and Abd Al-Rahman al-Nashiri, accused of planning the bombing of the USS Cole in Yemen in 2000. These men had been subjected to torture in other overseas CIA prisons; Zubaydah, for instance, was \u003ca href=\"https://www.therenditionproject.org.uk/prisoners/zubaydah.html\">waterboarded 83 times\u003c/a>. They were moved out of Guantánamo again in March 2004, when it appeared imminent that the Supreme Court was going to give detainees access to U.S. courts (all four came back in 2006, after Bush \u003ca href=\"http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=2400470\">acknowledged and closed\u003c/a> the CIA black sites).\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 1000px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/algerian-six.jpg\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter size-article-large wp-image-65164\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/algerian-six-1000x819.jpg\" alt=\"FILE-A Bosnian riot police officer guards a car containing some of the six Algerians suspected of having terrorist links, in front of Sarajevo's central prison in this Jan. 18, 2002 file photo. Humanitarian groups in Bosnia are under close scrutiny after the arrests of the six Algerians, five of whom worked for Islamic humanitarian organizations. (AP Photo/Sava Radovanovic, File)\" />\u003c/a>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"caption\">A Bosnian riot police officer in front of Sarajevo&#8217;s central prison guards a car containing some of the six Algerian men suspected of having terrorist links, Jan. 18, 2002.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class='caption source' style=''>Photo: Sava Radovanovic/AP\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>Midnight Convoy in Sarajevo\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>Another \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> entry \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830615-2008-09-03-SIDToday-Longest-Shifts-Working.html\">described a rendition\u003c/a> in which six men were bundled away from Bosnia to Guantánamo in early 2002. Most renditions were CIA-run; this is one of the only such operations known to have been \u003ca href=\"http://www.therenditionproject.org.uk/flights/renditions/USAF-020119.html\">carried out by the military\u003c/a> outside Afghanistan.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The men — natives of Algeria who became known as “\u003ca href=\"http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2007/12/sarajevo-guantanamo-strange-case-algerian-six\">The Algerian Six\u003c/a>” — had been linked to a plot to bomb the U.S. Embassy in Sarajevo, but a Bosnian judge had ordered them released for lack of evidence. But the United States leaned on the Bosnian government to hand them over instead.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The NSA staffer who wrote the \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> piece recounted the operation as part of a series of anecdotes provided by NSA employees about working overtime.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“Because much of the evidence against them came from U.S. intel, the Bosnian government didn’t have access to it, and after a couple of months in custody, the six prisoners were scheduled to be released without trial,” she wrote. “The U.S. did not want to let them go back into the general population,” so the commander of the unit in charge, Lt. Gen. H. Steven Blum, “planned to take the prisoners into U.S. custody as soon as they were released by the Bosnians. The prisoners would be taken from Sarajevo up to Tuzla.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>The staffer was tasked with watching for the possibility of an ambush on the military convoy. The men’s release, she wrote, “was delayed for several hours due to a large demonstration outside the building they were being held in,” and “the convoy did not leave Sarajevo until after midnight.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>“The ‘gentlemen’ in question are still guests of the U.S. government, at Guantánamo Bay,” she wrote in the entry dated September 3, 2008. In fact, just a few months later, a federal judge \u003ca href=\"http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=97264590\">ordered\u003c/a> five of the six men released on lack of evidence. One of them, Lakhdar Boumediene, had brought a suit that led to a \u003ca href=\"https://ccrjustice.org/home/what-we-do/our-cases/boumediene-v-bush-al-odah-v-united-states\">landmark decision\u003c/a> in June 2008 that Guantánamo detainees had the right to challenge their detention in federal court. The last of the men, Belkacem Bensayah, was \u003ca href=\"http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/131208/bittersweet-guantanamo-transfer-follows-decade-long-battle\">released\u003c/a> to Algeria in 2013.\u003c/p>\n\u003ch3>“A Unique Opportunity Awaits You” in Iraq\u003c/h3>\n\u003cp>NSA analysts were also intimately involved in interrogations in Iraq; a December 2003 \u003ca href=\"https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2830616-2003-12-21-SIDToday-Volunteer-Position-for-a-CT.html\">call for volunteers\u003c/a> to deploy to Baghdad as counterterrorism analysts with the \u003ca href=\"http://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/apr/27/iraq.usa\">Iraq Survey Group\u003c/a>, which was leading the search for Saddam’s weapons of mass destruction, said that “the selectee will, in all likelihood, be involved in the interrogation/questioning of potential leads,” as well as “the evaluation and analysis of interrogation reports and other HUMINT-based reports.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>A June 2003 \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/2830094-mg-quirk-leads-group-to-iraq/\">\u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> article\u003c/a> described snapshots of a trip with Maj. Gen. Richard J. Quirk III, then the agency’s director for signals intelligence. The photos for the entry are missing from the file, but one caption described a visit to Abu Ghraib prison, where “the group discussed the role of interrogations and how they can provide links for SIGINT.” In an ironic addition, given that Abu Ghraib would soon become the notorious symbol of prisoner abuse, the newsletter noted the group “also visited one of Saddam’s torture chambers.”\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>Related Stories:\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cul>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">Snowden Archive — The SIDtoday Files\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/the-intercept-is-broadening-access-to-the-snowden-archive-heres-why\">The Intercept Is Broadening Access to the Snowden Archive. Here’s Why \u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/the-most-intriguing-spy-stories-from-166-internal-nsa-reports\">The Most Intriguing Spy Stories From 166 Internal NSA Reports\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies\">What It’s Like to Read the NSA’s Newspaper for Spies\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":["45"],"credit_research_users_object":[{"ID":45,"brief_bio":"Margot Williams is a journalist and research editor who was part of two Pulitzer Prize-winning teams at the Washington Post.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Margot Williams","email":"margot.williams@theintercept.com","facebook":"","full_bio":"\u003cp>Margot Williams is Research Editor for Investigations at The Intercept. Her career at the Washington Post, New York Times, NPR and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists is one of the most respected in the investigative reporting world. She has pursued jihadists online and detainees who died in U.S. immigration detention, investigated Iraq war contractors and followed the money (and private jets) of mayors, governors, senators, presidential candidates, and ex-presidents. And she has spread her passion for investigative journalism — and her incredible ferreting skills — at numerous international workshops over the years.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>During 14 years at the Washington Post, Margot was a member of two Washington Post Pulitzer Prize-winning teams, for a 1998 investigation of D.C. police shootings of civilians and then again in 2001 for national coverage of terrorism. In the aftermath of 9/11 at the Washington Post and later at the New York Times, she investigated the network of jets and shell companies involved in the transport of terrorism suspects among secret prisons around the globe. She compiled the first list of the Guantánamo detainees — years before their names were made public — and created the comprehensive Guantánamo database on the Times website. In 2011, she analyzed the Guantánamo documents leaked by Bradley Manning for NPR and the New York Times.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/margot-350x350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"margotwilliams","pgp_file":"https://firstlook.org/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/09/MargotWilliamsPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"D301 003E DD1E 1BEA 6BE0 181B BB58 C7E5 F949 4209","pgp_key":"Margot Williams Public Key","twitter":"@MargotWilliams","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/margotwilliams/","user_group":"","user_title":"Research Editor for Investigations"}],"credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2016-05-16T15:37:38+00:00","date_local":"2016-05-16T11:37:38+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"The files, from Snowden, show the NSA worked daily with the CIA and military on interrogations at Guantánamo and supported renditions.  ","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"","feature_image_mask":"","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured News","featured_video_url":"","hide_featured_image":false,"inline_featured_image":false,"is_banner_hidden":false,"is_feature":"0","language":{"code":"en","name":"English","slug":"english"},"language_related_post_ids":"","language_related_post_permalinks":"","layout":"default","link":"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show/","meta":{"links":[]},"mobile_thumbnail":null,"partner_feeds":null,"partnership":{"article_logo":"","article_logo_blurb":"","article_text_color":"","homepage_background_color":"","homepage_featured":"","homepage_logo":"","homepage_logo_blurb":"","homepage_text_color":"","module_type":"","partner":"","partner_url":"","video_module_post_description":"","video_module_post_image":"","video_module_post_title":""},"post_type":"post","related_post_ids":"","related_post_permalinks":"","series":"","series_part_number":"","share_twitter_text":"Documents detail the NSA’s role in interrogations at Guantánamo:","show_donations_promo":true,"show_in_recirculation":true,"slug":"nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show","thumbnail":{"ID":64881,"alt_text":"U.S. Naval Base and detention center. Guantanamo, Cuba 2012.","content":"","credit":"Photo: Paolo Pellegrin/Magnum Photo","excerpt":"U.S. Naval Base and detention center. Guantanamo, Cuba 2012.","sizes":{"article_header":{"height":720,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-article-header.jpg","width":1440},"feature_hero":{"height":800,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-feature-hero.jpg","width":1200},"original":{"height":"720","path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign.jpg","width":"1440"},"promo":{"height":220,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-promo.jpg","width":440},"promo_large":{"height":450,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-promo-large.jpg","width":900},"small":{"height":100,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-small.jpg","width":200},"square":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-440x440.jpg","width":440},"top_large":{"height":440,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-top-large.jpg","width":440},"top_small":{"height":200,"path":"wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/guantanamo-sign-top-small.jpg","width":200}},"title":"U.S. Naval Base and detention center. Guantanamo, Cuba 2012."},"title":"NSA Closely Involved in Guantánamo Interrogations, Documents Show","yoast_wpseo_canonical":"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show/","yoast_wpseo_facebook_description":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_facebook_title":"","yoast_wpseo_general_description":"The files, from Edward Snowden, show the NSA worked daily with the CIA and military on interrogations at Guantánamo and supported renditions.","yoast_wpseo_general_title":"","yoast_wpseo_robots":"index, follow","yoast_wpseo_twitter_description":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_thumbnail":"","yoast_wpseo_twitter_title":""},"64797":{"ID":64797,"article_length_type":"Medium","authors":[{"ID":7,"brief_bio":"Glenn Greenwald is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law.","disable_staff_detail":false,"display_name":"Glenn Greenwald","email":"glenn.greenwald@theintercept.com","facebook":"https://www.facebook.com/glenn.greenwald.5","full_bio":"\u003cp>Glenn Greenwald is one of three co-founding editors of The Intercept. He is a journalist, constitutional lawyer, and author of four \u003cem>New York Times\u003c/em> best-selling books on politics and law. His most recent book, \u003cem>No Place to Hide\u003c/em>, is about the U.S. surveillance state and his experiences reporting on the Snowden documents around the world. Prior to co-founding The Intercept, Glenn&#8217;s column was featured at \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> and \u003cem>Salon\u003c/em>. He was the debut winner, along with Amy Goodman, of the Park Center I.F. Stone Award for Independent Journalism in 2008, and also received the 2010 Online Journalism Award for his investigative work on the abusive detention conditions of Chelsea Manning. For his 2013 NSA reporting, he received the George Polk award for National Security Reporting; the Gannett Foundation award for investigative journalism and the Gannett Foundation watchdog journalism award; the Esso Premio for Excellence in Investigative Reporting in Brazil (he was the first non-Brazilian to win), and the Electronic Frontier Foundation&#8217;s Pioneer Award. Along with Laura Poitras, \u003cem>Foreign Policy\u003c/em> magazine named him one of the top 100 Global Thinkers for 2013. The NSA reporting he led for \u003cem>The\u003c/em> \u003cem>Guardian\u003c/em> was awarded the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for public service.\u003c/p>\n","image_350":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2014/02/Glenn-Greenwald-Original_350.jpg","language":true,"nicename":"glenn-greenwald","pgp_file":"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2015/02/GlennGreenwaldPGP.asc","pgp_fingerprint":"734A 3680 A438 DD45 AF6F  5B99 A4A9 28C7 69CD 6E44","pgp_key":"Glenn Greenwald Public Key","twitter":"@ggreenwald","url":"https://theintercept.com/staff/glenn-greenwald/","user_group":"founding-editor","user_title":"Co-founding Editor and Columnist"}],"banner_videokey":"","bitly_url":"http://interc.pt/1WBxZgU","categories":[{"name":"release-may-2016","slug":"release-may-2016"},{"name":"release-may-2016-front","slug":"release-may-2016-front"},{"name":"Uproxx","slug":"uproxx"}],"comments_number":"219","comments_open":false,"content":"\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cdiv class='img-wrap align-center  width-fixed' style='width: 720px;'> \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/\" target=\"_blank\">\u003cimg class=\"aligncenter wp-image-65243\" src=\"https://theintercept.com/wp-uploads/sites/1/2016/05/CYD_logo03.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"720\" height=\"98\" />\u003c/a> \u003c/div>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">\u003cu>From the time\u003c/u> we began reporting on the archive provided to us in Hong Kong by NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden, we\u003cem> \u003c/em>sought to fulfill his two principal requests for how the materials should be handled: that they be released in conjunction with careful reporting that puts the documents in context and makes them digestible to the public, and that the welfare and reputations of innocent people be safeguarded. As time has gone on, \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em> has sought out new ways to get documents from the archive into the hands of the public, consistent with the public interest as originally conceived.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Today, \u003ci>The Intercept \u003c/i>is announcing two innovations in how we report on and publish these materials. Both measures are designed to ensure that reporting on the archive continues in as expeditious and informative a manner as possible, in accordance with the agreements we entered into with our source about how these materials would be disclosed, a framework \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ggreenwald/status/715323533824548864?lang=en\">that he\u003c/a>, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2014/03/23/facts-nsa-stories-reported/\">and we\u003c/a>, have publicly described on numerous occasions.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The first measure involves the publication of large batches of documents. W\u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"s1\">e are, beginning today, publishing in installments the NSA&#8217;s internal \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>\u003c/span> \u003cspan class=\"s1\">newsletters, which span more than a decade beginning after 9/11. We are starting with the oldest \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles, from 2003, and working our way through the most recent in our archive, from 2012. Our first release today contains 166 documents, all from 2003, and we will periodically release batches until we have made public the entire set. \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">The documents are available on a special section of \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em>\u003c/a>.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>\u003c/span> \u003cspan class=\"s1\">documents run a wide gamut: from serious, detailed reports on top secret NSA surveillance programs to breezy, trivial meanderings of analysts’\u003c/span> \u003cspan class=\"s1\">trips and vacations, with much in between. Many are self-serving and boastful, designed to justify budgets or impress supervisors. Others contain obvious errors or mindless parroting of public source material. But some \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em> articles have been the basis of significant revelations from the archive. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">Accompanying the release of these documents are summaries of the content of each, along with a \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">story about NSA’s role in Guantánamo interrogations\u003c/a>, a lengthy roundup of other \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/the-most-intriguing-spy-stories-from-166-internal-nsa-reports\">intriguing information gleaned from these files\u003c/a>, and a \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies\">profile of \u003cem>SIDtoday\u003c/em>\u003c/a>. We encourage other journalists, researchers, and interested parties to comb through these documents, along with future published batches, to find additional material of interest. Others may well find stories, or clues that lead to stories, that we did not. (To contact us about such finds, \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday/about/#contact\">see the instructions here\u003c/a>.) A primary objective of these batch releases is to make that kind of exploration possible.\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">Consistent with the requirements of our agreement with our source, our editors and reporters have carefully examined each document, redacted names of low-level functionaries and other information that could impose serious harm on innocent individuals, and given the NSA an opportunity to comment on the documents to be published (the NSA&#8217;s comments resulted in no redactions other than two names of relatively low-level employees that we agreed, consistent with our long-standing policy, to redact). Further information about how we prepared the documents for publication is available \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/how-we-prepared-the-nsas-sensitive-internal-reports-for-release\">in a separate article\u003c/a>. We believe these releases will enhance public understanding of these extremely powerful and secretive surveillance agencies.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">The other innovation is our ability to invite outside journalists, including from foreign media outlets, to work with us to explore the full Snowden archive.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">From the start of our reporting on the archive, a major component of our approach has been to partner with foreign (and other American) media outlets rather than try to keep all the material for ourselves. We\u003cem> \u003c/em>have collectively shared documents with more than two dozen media outlets, and teams of journalists in numerous countries have thus worked with and reported on Snowden documents (that&#8217;s independent of the other media outlets which have long possessed large portions of the Snowden archive — the\u003ci> Washington Post\u003c/i>, the\u003ci> New York Times\u003c/i>, \u003ci>The Guardian\u003c/i>, \u003cem>ProPublica\u003c/em>). This partnership approach has greatly expedited the reporting, and also ensured that stories that most affect specific countries are reported by the journalists who best understand those countries.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">But allowing other journalists full access to the archive presented security and legal challenges that took time and resources to resolve. We now feel comfortable that we can do so consistent with the responsibility demanded by these materials and our agreement with our source. We have begun to provide archive access to journalists from \u003ci>Le Monde\u003c/i> and other media outlets in collaboration with \u003cem>The Intercept\u003c/em>’s editorial, research, legal, and technology teams. \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"s1\">We are excited by the reporting this new arrangement will generate. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">There are still many documents of legitimate interest to the public that can and should be disclosed. There are also documents in the archive that we do not believe should be published because of the severe harm they would cause innocent people (e.g., private communications intercepted by NSA, the disclosure of which would destroy privacy rights; and documents containing government speculation about bad acts committed by private individuals (typically from marginalized communities), the disclosure of which would permanently destroy reputations). \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">An archive of this significance and size obviously presents complicated questions about how best to report on it. There is rarely one easy, obvious answer how to do it. Different leaks may require different approaches. I’ve always believed that WikiLeaks’\u003c/span> \u003cspan class=\"s1\">reporting on and disclosure of the materials provided by Chelsea Manning and other sources have been superb. But that does not mean that it is the only viable framework, or the optimal tactical approach, for all leaks. Moreover, different whistleblowers have their own conditions and demands for how the material can be disclosed, which any ethical journalist must obviously honor in full.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">We have navigated these difficult and sometimes conflicting values in deciding how best to report on this massive archive. These two new approaches will, we believe, facilitate reporting and disclosure while fulfilling our obligations to the public and to our source. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp>\u003cem>Related Stories:\u003c/em>\u003c/p>\n\u003cul>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/snowden-sidtoday\">Snowden Archive — The SIDtoday Files\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/how-we-prepared-the-nsas-sensitive-internal-reports-for-release\">How We Prepared the NSA’s Sensitive Internal Reports for Release\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/nsa-closely-involved-in-guantanamo-interrogations-documents-show\">NSA Closely Involved in Guantánamo Interrogations, Documents Show\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/15/the-most-intriguing-spy-stories-from-166-internal-nsa-reports\">The Most Intriguing Spy Stories From 166 Internal NSA Reports\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003cli>\u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies/\">The NSA’s Newspaper Reveals the Human Side of America’s Digital Spies\u003c/a>\u003c/li>\n\u003c/ul>\n","credit_additional_reporting":"","credit_additional_reporting_users_object":"","credit_photo_illustration":"","credit_research":"","credit_research_users_object":"","credit_translation":"","credit_translation_users_object":"","date":"2016-05-16T15:37:52+00:00","date_local":"2016-05-16T11:37:52+00:00","documents":"","excerpt":"We’ve begun to release large batches of Snowden documents to the public — and to open the archive to greater access by foreign and U.S. journalists.","excerpt_type":"default","feature_header_background_color":"","feature_header_color":"","feature_header_layout":"","feature_image_mask":"","feature_interactive_url":"","feature_text_color":"","feature_title":"Featured can kill.","wpseo_title":"Taser: All Too Lethal – The Intercept"},"the-fbis-secret-rules":{"ID":788,"about_page_text":"\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">President Trump has inherited a vast domestic intelligence agency with extraordinary secret powers. A cache of documents offers a rare window into the FBI’s quiet expansion since 9/11. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">After the famous Church Committee hearings in the 1970s exposed the FBI’s wild overreach, reforms were enacted to protect civil liberties. But in recent years, the bureau has substantially revised those rules with very little public scrutiny. That’s why \u003ca href=\"https://theintercept.com/2017/01/31/secret-docs-reveal-president-trump-has-inherited-an-fbi-with-vast-hidden-powers/\">The Intercept is publishing this special package of articles\u003c/a> based on three internal FBI manuals that we exclusively obtained. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">These stories illuminate how the FBI views its authority to assess terrorism suspects, recruit informants, spy on university organizations, infiltrate online chat rooms, peer through the walls of private homes, and more. \u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n\u003cp class=\"p1\">\u003cspan class=\"s1\">In addition to the articles collected here &#8212; which include nine new pieces and two that we previously published based on the same source material &#8212; we have annotated the manuals to highlight what we found most newsworthy in them.  We redacted the sections that could be used to identify individuals or systems for the purpose of causing harm. We’re presenting the stories alongside the manuals because we believe the public has a right to know how the U.S. government’s leading domestic law enforcement agency understands and wields its enormous power.\u003c/span>\u003c/p>\n","carousel_image":null,"companion_site_promo":null,"count":11,"credits_and_legal":"\u003cp class=\"p1\">Editor-in-Chief: Betsy Reed. Series Editor: Ryan Tate. Associate Editor: Andrea Jones. Reporters: Trevor Aaronson, Cora Currier, Jenna McLaughlin, Alice Speri. Research: Alleen Brown, Talya Cooper, Danielle Mackey, Eseosa Olumhense,  Miriam Pensack, John Thomason. Art Direction: Stephane Elbaz, Philipp Hubert, Nick Simmons. Additional Photo Editing: Soohee Cho, Shaun Lucas, Chelsea Matiash. Nominations Sought for D&D; Awards"},{"cite_for_public_name":[],"description":"As the result of critical findings from the U.K. inquiry on intelligence regarding weapons of mass destruction in the run-up to the Iraq war, GCHQ will be adding to all intelligence reports \"Intelligence Source Descriptors,\" which describe the access, identity, and reliability of sources. But for situations in which an analyst needs to make a public phone call without leaking their NSA affiliation, the Special Operations Support office has some options: \"Anonymous telephones\" are lines that physically connect to the NSA, but they are registered to \"DoD,\" and only \"examination of vendor-billing records will disclose affiliation with a physical NSA location.\" \"Cover telephones\" are registered using alias names and P.O. boxes, and do a more thorough job at hiding NSA affiliation.","document_date":"02/14/2005","id":"3991105-Lost-in-the-Open","published_online_date":"09/13/2017","related_links":[],"release":5,"tags":["Office Announcements","Systems"],"title":"Lost in the Open"},{"cite_for_public_name":[],"description":"Target Operational Pilot prototypes are a “unique setting” in which to develop incremental solutions to challenges analysts face in processing signals intelligence, according to a staffer in the NSA's “Trailblazer Mission Element.”","document_date":"01/07/2005","id":"3991053-Analysts-Have-Influence-at-the-TOP-Target","published_online_date":"09/13/2017","related_links":[],"release":5,"tags":[],"title":"Analysts Have Influence at the TOP (Target Operational Pilot)"},{"cite_for_public_name":[],"description":"The \"Squirrel Accumulator\" is an electronic list of 184 application-layer protocols that the NSA has prioritized for exploitation. In 2005, it was run by \"one of the world's largest ISPs,\" and the system was shared by the whole U.S. intelligence community. Some users were concerned that all of this internet traffic comes from the same IP address, which could be used to attribute internet traffic to the NSA, however technically there were often multiple IP addresses. The NSA is working on building its own new version of AIRGAP, that it doesn't share with the rest of the intelligence community. \"Despite rules and warnings to the contrary, all too frequently users will use AIRGAP for registering on web sites or for services, logging into other sites and services and even ordering personal items from on-line vendors. The articles are written in accessible, non-technical language and offer a window into the \u003ca href='https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/what-its-like-to-read-the-nsas-newspaper-for-spies'>NSA’s culture and operations\u003c/a>. They originate from within the Signals Intelligence Directorate, or SID, the NSA’s core spying division, and were provided by whistleblower Edward Snowden.\u003cbr/>\u003cbr/>We’ll be releasing these files in large batches, starting with articles from the period after SIDtoday’s inception in March 2003. The articles will be subjected to editorial evaluation, legal review, research, reporting, and redaction, described in this \u003ca href='https://theintercept.com/2016/05/16/how-we-prepared-the-nsas-sensitive-internal-reports-for-release'>overview\u003c/a>. They will be accompanied by related \u003cem>Intercept\u003c/em> news articles when appropriate.\u003cbr/>\u003cbr/>While we have focused on the parts of these documents we find most compelling, we anticipate readers will find other information of interest in the files we are sharing.
